superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter l c
The twenty-third letter of the alphabet; called laAmN. It is one of the letters termed majohuwrap, or vocal, and also belongs to the class of AlHuruwfu AlcRuloqu, or cawolaqiyRap, i. e. letters pronounced by means of the tip of the tongue and the lip; it is one of the letters of augmentation. ＝ -A2- As a numeral it denotes thirty. ＝ -A3- For the particles lA li la, &c., see Supplement.

dictScrap.label: Accord. to some, the words of this art. are from a triliteral root, augmented: AAF, for instance, says that they belong to the same class as sbTr [in which the r is added to the root.] TA.)

superEntry.entry:
R. Q. 1 laOolaOa c
R. Q. 1. laOolaOa, (TA,) and talaOolaOa↓, (S, K,) (tropical:) It (a star, and the moon, TA, and lightning, S, K, and fire, TA) shone, glistened, or was bright: (K:) or shone with flickering light. (TA.) ― -b2- lOlOti AlnRaAru, inf. n. laOolaOapN, (tropical:) The fire burned brightly: (K:) and talaOolaOato↓ it blazed. (TA.) ― -b3- lOlO AldRamoEa, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He let fall the tears (K) upon his cheeks like pearls. (TA.) ― -b4- lOlOt biEayonayohaA (assumed tropical:) She (a woman) opened her eyes wide, and looked intently. (K.) ― -b5- lOlO bicanabihi (assumed tropical:) He (a bull, or a wild bull, vaworN waHoXiIRN, (TA,) or an antelope, K), wagged his tail. ― -b6- laA Mtiyka maA laOolaOati Alfuwru biOaconaAbihaA, (Lh,) or laA OafoEaluhu, (S,) I will not come to thee, or I will not do it, while the gazelles wag their tails: [i. e., I will never come to thee]. (Lh, S.) A proverb. (TA.) ― -b7- lOlOti AlEanozu (tropical:) The she-goat, or doe, desired the male. (K.)

R. Q. 2
R. Q. 2: See 1. ― -b2- Also It (the saraAb [or mirage]) [moved to and fro, undulated, or] came and went. (S in art. rq.)

luWoluWapN c
luWoluWapN A pearl: pl. laWoluWN (S, K) and laMliYu: (S:) [or rather, luWoluWN is a coll. gen. n., of which luWoluWapN is the n. un.]. ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) A wild cow; syn. baqarapN waHoXiyRapN [a species of bovine antelope]. (K.)

lawonN luWoluWaAnN c
lawonN luWoluWaAnN, and luWoluYiIR↓, [A colour like that of pearls]. (K.) Ibn-Ahmar uses the former epithet as a fem. (TA.)

luWoluYiIRN c
luWoluYiIRN: see preceding paragraph; and laORlN.

liYaAlapN c
liYaAlapN [contr. to analogy, unless the radical letters be lOl,] The trade of a seller of pearls. (K.)

laORCN c
laORCN: see laORlN, below.

laORlN c
laORlN (Fr, S, K) and laORLCN↓ and laOolaMCN↓, (K,) all contr. to analogy [if the radical letters be lOlO], and the last a strange form, mentioned by few authors, and disapproved by most: (TA:) the regular from would be luWoluYiIRN; not laORLCN, as J asserts it to be, [unless the radical letters be lOO], nor laORLlN (K) [unless it be from a triliteral root, augmented, and thus rendered a quasi-quadriliteral-radical; (see a remark at the head of this art.; and see HayRapN;) in which case, either the added letter or the last radical letter may be omitted in the formation of this epithet]: (K:) A seller of pearls. (S, K.)

laOolaMCN c
laOolaMCN: see laORlN. ― -b2- Also, A perfect, or complete, rejoicing. (K.) [It may be an inf. n.]

lAFX: See art. lwX.
lOT lOZ lOf: See Supplement.
lOlO: See art. lO.
lOm lOI: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 labVba
1: [labRa, originally labiba,] sec. per. labibota, (S, K,) the most common form of the verb, (TA,) and [labRa, originally labuba, like HabRa, originally Habuba, q. v.,] sec. pers. labubota, aor. yalabRu, (S, K,) in the dial. of El-Hijáz, deviating from rule as aor. of the latter form of the verb; (TA;) inf. n. labaAbapN (S, K) and libRN and labRN; (TA;) and labRa, aor. yalibRu, in the dial. of Nejd; like farRa, aor. yafirRu; (TA;) and [labRa], sec. pers. labibota, aor. yalubRu; [contr. to analogy;] (Yz;) and [labRa], sec. pers. labubota, aor. yalubRu; [agreeably with analogy;] (Yoo;) He was, or became, possessed of lubR, i. e., understanding, intellect, or intelligence. See lubRN. (S, K.) It has been said by some (as the authors of the T, the S, &c.) that labubota, aor. talabRu, has not its like among the class of reduplicative verbs; i. e., in being of the measure faEula in the pret., and yafoEalu in the aor.: but three similar verbs have been mentioned; namely, damumota, Xarurota, and Eazuzati AlXRaApu (meaning “ the ewe, or goat, became scant in her milk ”). (TA.) [This, however, is a mistake: the assertion relates to labubota having for its aor. (regularly) talubRu: see damRa, aor. yadumRu.]) ＝ -A2- labRa, aor.
labiba
; and labolaba↓; He (a goat, and sometimes lblb↓ is used in the same sense with reference to a buck-antelope,) uttered a cry, or sound, at rutting-time. (TA.) ＝ -A3- labRa AllRawoza He broke the almond and took forth its kernel. (TA.) ― -b2- labRahu, (K,) sec. pers. lababotu, aor.
labuba
, inf. n. labRN, (S,) He struck him upon the part called the labRap; (S, K;) i. e., the pit above the breast, between the collar-bones; the place where camels are stabbed. (TA.) ＝ -A4- labRa, aor.
labuba
, It (a house) faced, was opposite to, or stood over against, another house. (Kh, S, K.) ＝ -A5- See 4.

2 lbRb c
2. lbRb, inf. n. talobiybN, He (a man warning, or admonishing, a people, and crying out for aid,) put his quiver and his bow upon his neck, and then grasped his own clothes at the upper part of his bosom: ex.
UinRaA UicaA AldRaAEiI QEotaraI walabRabaA
[Verily we, when a caller comes seeking a kind office, and puts his quiver &c.]: (Lth:) or lbRb here signifies taradRada: see above. (TA.) ― -b2- He drew together his garments at his bosom and breast, in altercation, or contention, and then dragged him along. (S, K.) ― -b3- Also, He put round his neck a rope, or a garment, and held him with it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 5, and talobiybN ＝ -A3- lbRb It (grain) got a lubR, or heart, (S, K,) an edible heart. (TA.) ＝ -A4- lbRb, inf. n. talobiybN, He went backwards and forwards, or to and fro; went and came: syn. taradRada. (K.) ISd says, This is related, but I know not what it is. (TA.) See below.

4 AlbR biAlmakaAni c
4. AlbR biAlmakaAni, inf. n. UilobaAbN; (ISk, S, K;) and labRa bihi↓, [aor.
labuba
,] inf. n. labRN; (Kh, S, K;) He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in the place; (S, K;) kept to it. (S.) Hence, says Fr., the expression labRayoka, q. v. infra. (S, K.) ― -b2- AlbR EalaI AlOamori He kept to the thing, or affair. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AlbR It (growing corn, &c.) had, bore, or produced, the edible substance in the grain: like AHbR. (S.) ＝ -A3- AlbR lahu AlXRaIoCu The thing appeared to him: syn. EaraDa. (K.) ＝ -A4- Oalobabotu AlsRaroja I made a labab (or breast-leather) to the saddle. (TA.) ― -b2- Oalobabotu AldRaAbRapa I put a labab (or breast-leather) on the beast of carriage; (S, K;) as also lababotuhaA↓, aor.
labuba
. (K.)

5 tlbRbt biminoTaqatihaA c
5. tlbRbt biminoTaqatihaA [app. a mistake for biminoTaqihaA] She (a woman) put one end of her scarf over her left shoulder, and drew forth the middle of it from beneath her right arm, and covered with it her bosom, and put the other end also over her left shoulder. (TA.) ― -b2- tlbRb He raised his clothes, or tucked them up: (K:) he girded himself, and raised, or tucked up, his clothes; (S;) a signification assigned in the A to labRaba↓: he girded himself with his garment about his bosom; or wrapped it round him at his bosom: he drew together his garments: he girded himself with a weapon &c.: he armed himself, and raised, or tucked up, his clothes for fight: (TA:) he bound his waist with a rope. (S, in art. Hzm.) ― -b3- talabRaba AlrRajulaAni The two men seized each other at the part called labRap. (TA.) ＝ -A2- tlbRb AlwaAdiI (tropical:) He took his way through the valley: and, in like manner, lbRbwA↓ and AstlbRwA↓ they took their way through it. (A.)

10 AstlbRhu c
10. AstlbRhu He made trial of his understanding, or intelligence. See lubRN. ＝ -A2- And see 5.

R. Q. 1 labolabapN c
R. Q. 1. labolabapN, [inf. n. of labolaba,] The being tender, affectionate, kind, or compassionate, to offspring. (S, K.) ― -b2- labolabato EalaI waladihaA, inf. n. as above, She (a ewe) was tender, or affectionate, to her young one, and licked it, when she brought it forth, (S, K,) making a sound like libo libo. (TA.) ― -b3- See 1. ― -b4- labolaba Ealayohi, inf. n. as above, He was kind, or compassionate, to him; i. e., to a man: he was kind, or affectionate, to him, and aided, or succoured, him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- labolaba It was separated, dispersed, or scattered. (AA, T, K.) (The inf. n., lblbp, is explained by tafarRuqN: but I think it not improbable that this is a mistake for tarafRuqN; and that the meaning is, He was gentle, courteous, or kind.]

labRN c
labRN inf. n. of labRa “ he remained, &c. ” ― -b2- lbRayoka [At thy service! lit., Doubly at thy service!] (S, K, &c.) and labRayohi [At his service: &c.]. (TA.) [See an ex. voce marohuwbN. It is used in the present day like our phrase At thy service, and may well be thus rendered, or with the addition of time after time.] lbRyk is derived from OalabRa [or rather from labRa as syn. with AlbR] “ he remained &c. ”; and means I wait intent upon thy service, or upon obedience to thee: (Fr, S, K;) waiting [at they service] after waiting; [i. e., time after time;] and answering [thy commands] after answering: (K:) it [i. e. the noun without the annexed pron.] is put in the acc. case as an inf. n. [used as an absolute complement of its own verb which is understood], as in HamodFA lilRehi wXukorFA; and the right way would be to say labRFA laka; but it is put in the dual number for the sake of corroboration; meaning UilobaAbFA bika baEoda UilobaAbK, and UiqaAmapF baEoda UiqaAmapK, [waiting at thy service, or in attendance upon thee, or in thy presence, after waiting, or time after time]. (Fr, S.) [See also the similar expression saEodayoka.] Or labRN signifies the obeying, or serving; or obedience, or service; from the original signification of the “ remaining, staying, abiding, or dwelling, ” [in a place]: the dual, in the nom. case, is labRAni; and in the acc. and gen., labRayoni; and the original meaning of lbyk is I have obeyed thee, or served thee, twice: [or I do obey thee, &c.:] the n [of lbRyn] being elided because of its being prefixed to the pron. (IAar.) Or lbRyk is from the saying daAru fulaAnK talubRu daAriI “ the house of such a one faces my house ”; (Kh, S, K;) and the meaning is I present myself before thee, (or repair to thee, K,) doing what thou likest, answering thee [after answering, or time after time]: the I is to form the dual number; and indicates that the noun is in the acc. case as an inf. n. [used as mentioned above]. (Kh, S.) Or it means My love [is given] to thee; from the expression AimoraOapN labRapN “ a woman loving (and affectionate, TA,) to her husband ”: so in the K: but the expression, as related on the authority of Kh, is OumRN labRapN; which is confirmed by a verse that he cites. (TA.) Or the meaning is UixolaASiI laka [My sincere service, or the like, (is given) to thee;] from the expression HasabN lubaAbN “ pure nobility, or the like. ” (K.) Accord. to Yoo, lbRyk is a noun in the sing. number with the pron. annexed to it: this noun is originally labRabN, of the measure faEolalN: (not of the measure faERalN, because this is rare in the language:) the the last b is changed into I to avoid the reduplication; and thus it becomes labRaIN: then the I, being movent, and immediately preceded by fet-hah, is changed into A; and it becomes labRaA [or labRaI, for the I in this case is called A]: then, being conjoined with k in lbRyk, and with h in lbRyh, its A is changed into I; after the same manner as you say Uilayoka and Ealayoka and ladayoka. (TA.) [But see what here follows.] ― -b3- labRaIo yadayoka is a phrase exactly similar to lbRyk, meaning At the service (or, lit. doubly at the service) of thy hands! and this is said, in the S, art. lbI to be at variance with the opinion of Yoo, given above; for, if lbRI were similar to UilaI &c., being prefixed to a noun, not a pron., it would be labRaI yadayoka, not labRaIo.] Accord. to El-Khattá- bee, lbRI ydyk signifies May thy hands be safe and sound! the desinential syntax being disregarded in the saying ydyk, which rightly should be yadaAka, in order that ydyk may match in sound with lbRyk: but Z says, that the meaning is, I will obey thee, and be at thy free disposal, as a thing which thou shalt dispose of with thy hands in whatever manner thou shalt please. (TA.) ― -b4- In like manner you say labRaIo zayodK [At the service (or doubly at the service) of Zeyd]. (Msb.) See art. lbI. ― -b5- labRi, with kesreh for its termination, like Oamos and gaAqi, is also related as having been used: (Sb:) [and it is still used in some parts, as signifying At thy service!]. ＝ -A2- labRN keeping, or adhering, [to a thing]: remaining, or staying. (K.) ― -b2- A camel-driver who keeps constantly to the work of driving the camels, not leaving them. (TA.) ― -b3- rajulN labRN A man who keeps to a thing, or affair, or business; as also labiybN↓; (S, K;) a man who keeps to his art, or craft, or trade, not ceasing from it. (TA.) ― -b4- rjlN labRN TabRN A man who keeps to business, [and is skilful, expert, clever, or intelligent]. (S, TA.) ＝ -A3- lab One who renders himself near to people by affection and friendship [or is friendly and affectionate to them]: courteous, polite, or affable: fem. labRapN: pl. libaAbN. (TA.) ― -b2- AimoraOapN labRapN A woman who renders herself near by affection
and friendship [or is friendly and affectionate], to people; (S;) courteous, polite, or affable: (S, K:) a woman loving to her husband; (K;) affectionate to him: or, accord. to Kh, the expression is OumRN labRapN: see labRN, above. (TA.)

lubRN c
lubRN (S, K) and lubaAbN↓ (Msb) of a nut, an almond, and the like, What is in the inside; (S;) the heart, or kernel: (K:) of a palm-tree, the heart, or pith, called qalobN or qulobN. (S, K.) Pl. of the former lubuwbN. (S.) ― -b2- lubRN (S, K) and lubaAbN↓ (TA) What is pure, or the choice, or best, part, of anything: (S, K:) pl. of the former OalobaAbN. (A'Obeyd.) ― -b3- lubRu AlHinoTapi [The purest substance of wheat: see faAluwcN:] (T, L, art. flc &c.:) [also called AlburRi lubaAbu↓, acc. to Sprenger, “ Life of Mohammad, ” (Allahabad, 1851,) p. 24, note 1.] ― -b4- [Hence,] lubRN of a man, (TA,) (tropical:) Understanding; intellect; intelligence; or mind; syn. EaqolN: (S, K:) the understanding, &c., that is put into the heart of a man: so called because it is the choicest or best part of him: or it is not so called unless it is pure from cupidity, or lust, and foul imaginations; and therefore has a more special sense than Eql: so in the Keshf el-Keshsháf: (TA:) pl. OalobaAbN, and sometimes OalubRN; (S, K;) like as OaboWusN is pl. of buWosN, and OanoEumN of nuEomN; (S;) and OalobubN; (S, K;) the last being used, without incorporating the second b into the first, in case of necessity in poetry. (S.) ― -b5- banaAtu OalobubK Certain veins in the heart; the sources of tenderness, affection, kindness, or compassion. (S, K.) ― -b6- taOobaI lahu celika banaAtu OalobubiI [My tenderness forbids the doing so to him]: said by an Arab woman of the desert, on the occasion of her reproving her son, to one who asked her why she did not curse him. (S.) ― -b7- OaloqaI Ealayohi banaAta Oalobubihi He loved it. (L, art. Xr.) ― -b8- The following words of the poet,
qado Ealimato caAka banaAtu Oalobubiho
signify, accord. to the M, My intellect knew that. (TA.) El-Mubarrad read Oalobabiho in the above words of the poet: (TA:) the meaning of these words, accord. to him, is, The daughters of the most intelligent of his tribe knew this. (S, TA.) ― -b9- If you form a pl. from [the pl.] OalobubN, it is OalaAbibu; and the dim. n. is OulayobibN. (S.) ― -b10- cuw lubRK Possessing, having, or a person of, understanding, or intelligence: pl. OuwluwA QloOalobaAbi [persons of understandings]. (TA.) See also labiybN and malobuwbN. ― -b11- lubRN (assumed tropical:) The self, substance, or essence, of anything. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Poison: (K:) the poison of the serpent is sometimes thus called. (Abu-l-Hasan, L.) ＝ -A3- lubRN, in the dial. of El-Andalus and El-'Adweh, A certain beast of prey, resembling the wolf, said by AHei not to exist in other countries. (TA.)

lababN c
lababN: see labRapN. ― -b2- The breast-girth, or thing that is bound over the breast of a beast, (or a she-camel, S,) to prevent the saddle from slipping back: (S, K:) it is an appertenance to the camel's saddle and to the horse's: (ISd, and others:) pl. OalobaAbN: (S, K:) its only pl. (Sb.) ― -b3- fulaAnN fiI lababK raxiIRK (tropical:) Such a one is in ample circumstances (S,) in the enjoyment of abundance and security. (TA.) ― -b4- raxiIRu AllRababi Having a dilated bosom, or heart: syn. waAsiEu AlSRadori. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A thin tract, or portion, of sand, (S, K,) that has descended from the main heap, and is between the hard and even, and the rugged, parts of the earth: (TA:) or such as is near to an oblong tract of sand: (T:) or lababu kaviybK signifies the fore part of a sand-hill. (TA.) El-Ahmar says, The largest quantity of sand is called EaqanoqalN; what is less than this, kaviybN; what is still less, EawokalN; what is still less, siqoTN; what is still less, EadaAbN; and what is still less, lababN. (S.)

labRapN c
labRapN and lababN↓ The stabbing-place in an animal; (S, L, K;) the middle of the breast: (L:) the pit above the breast, between the collar-bones; the place where camels are stabbed: (see labRahu:) or the bones [probably a mistake for the part next above the bones] that are above the breast, and below the throat, between the collar-bones, where camels are stabbed: he who says that it is the pit in the throat errs: (IKt:) [for it is just beneath the throat:] pl. of the former labRaAtN (S) and libaAbN; and of the latter OalobaAbN. (TA.) Also, both words, (the latter ↓accord. to the S and K, and the former accord. to the TA,) and mutalabRabN↓, (TA,) The place of the breast where the necklace or collar lies, or hangs, (S, K,) in anything; (S;) [i. e., in a human being or a beast:] or the pit above it: (TA:) pl. of lababN, OalobaAbN. (S.) Lh mentions the phrase UinRahaA laHasanahu AllRabRaAti [Verily she is beautiful in the upper part of the breast]: as though the sing. were applied to each portion of it, and the pl. formed to denote the whole. (TA.)

labaAbN c
labaAbN (as in the K) or labaAbapN↓ (as in the L) A little of pasture, or herbage; (K;) what is not extensive thereof. (AHn.) ＝ -A2- labaAbi labaAbi, said by the Arabs to a man on the occasion of becoming favourably disposed towards him, (Yoo,) No harm, No harm. Syn. laA baOosa. (K.) ISd thinks it to be from a preceding meaning; [that of “ keeping, or adhering ”;] observing that when one dispels evil from another, he [the latter] loves to adhere to him: [so that it seems to be an imp. verbal n., like nazaAli &c., meaning keep with me, and fear not]. (TA.)

huwa lubaAbu qawomihi c
huwa lubaAbu qawomihi [He is the choice one, or best, of his people]: and in like manner, humo lubaAbu qawomihimo: and hiIa lubaAbu qawomihaA. (IJ.) ― -b2- lubaAbu AlUibili (tropical:) The best of the camels. (A.) ― -b3- lubaAbu AldRaqiyqi The best and purest of flour; which is white flour. (TA, voce HuwRaAraI.) ― -b4- lubaAbN Finely-ground flour, or meal. (TA.) ― -b5- See lubRN. ― -b6- HasabN lubaAbN Pure nobility, or the like. (S, K.)

labiybN c
labiybN (tropical:) A person of understanding, or intelligence: pl. OalibRaACu. (S, K.) No other broken pl. is formed from it. (Sb.) Fem. with p. (TA.) See lubRN, and malobuwbN. ＝ -A2- In the following verse of El-Mudarrib Ibn-Kaab,
faqulotu lahaA fiyYiI Uilayoki faUinRaniI
HaraAmN waUinRiI baEoda caAki labiybu
by bEd cAk is meant mE cAk; and by lbyb, muqiym, (remaining, or staying,) or, accord. to some, mulabRK, from AltRalobiyap: see art. lbI. (S.)

labaAbapN c
labaAbapN: see labaAbN.

libaAbapN c
libaAbapN What is worn by the mutalabRib [app. meaning him who girds himself, and raises or tucks up his clothes, and arms himself, for fight]: (TA:) [A garment which he who prepares himself for fight puts on over other garments. (Freytag.) App., A piece of drapery thrown over the upper part of the bosom, and over the shoulders. See 5.]

labiybapN c
labiybapN A certain garment, like the baqiyrap, q. v. (S, K.)

labolabN c
labolabN and lubolubN Kind, and beneficent, to his family and his neighbours. (K.)

huwa muHibRN lahu bilabaAlibi qalobihi c
huwa muHibRN lahu bilabaAlibi qalobihi (tropical:) [He loves him with the tenderest affections of his heart]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- labaAlibu (tropical:) The confused noise, and cries, of sheep or goats. (S, K.)

labolabapN c
labolabapN a word imitative of The sound which a he-goat makes at rutting-time. (K.)

labolaAbN c
labolaAbN A certain herb: syn. HaXiyXapN. (TA.) A certain plant, (K,) that twines about trees: (S:) [a species of dolichos, the dolichos lablab of Linn.: accord. to Golius, as from the S, convolvulus, a herb which as it rises embraces a tree: and he adds, pecul., the helxine: (Diosc. iv., 39, Beith:) either as if lflAf, from lf; or from the love with which it seems to embrace the tree; whence it is also called EXqp [q. v.], and is a symbol of love which endures after death.] A well-known herb, or leguminous plant, (bqlp, q. v.,) used medicinally. (TA.) See EuSorN.

lawolabN c
lawolabN A large quantity of water, which, when the aperture (mafotaH, as in the T; or fatoH, as in MS. copies of the K; in the CK futuH;) [mean-
ing the aperture of the tank or the like] carries off thereof what it can, and the hole by which it runs out (Sunobuwruhu, meaning the mavoEab of the water, TA,) is too narrow to admit it freely on account of its abundance, whirls round, and becomes like the spout of a vessel. (T, K.) AM says, I know not whether it be an Arabic word or arabicized; but the people of El-'Irák are fond of using it. (TA.) [It appears to be from the Persian luwlaho, as Golius thinks; and is used in modern Arabic in several other senses; namely, A tube through which water flows: the spout of a ewer, of an alembic, and the like: a cock, or tap: a turning pin, or peg; a screw: and the like. Its more appropriate place, I think, would be in an art. composed of the letters llb (accord. to what is said of mulawolabN in the S, K); or rather, (accord. to its derivation from the Pers.,) lwlb.] Pl. lawaAlibu. (TA.)

OulobuwbN c
OulobuwbN [and also, accord. to Golius, OalobuwbN,] The kernel of the stone of the nabiq [or fruit of the lote-tree]. (K.) It is sometimes eaten: (TA:) and is also called SalRAmN. (TA in art. Slm.)

mulabRN c
mulabRN: see next paragraph.

mulobabN c
mulobabN and mulabRN↓ (K: the former on the authority of ISk; but Ibn-Keysán says that it is wrong; and that the latter is the right: S:) and malobuwbN↓ (IAar, K) A beast of carriage furnished with a labab, or breast-leather. (S, K.)

malobuwbN c
malobuwbN (tropical:) Characterized by understanding, or intelligence. (K.) ― -b2- See preceding paragraph.

talobiybN c
talobiybN The portion of the clothes that is at the part called labab: a subst., like tamotiynN: (K:) pl. talaAbiybu. (TA.) ― -b2- Oaxaca bitalobiybihi He drew together his clothes at the bosom, and seized him, dragging him along: (T:) he took him by the labRap: you also say Axc bitalaAbiybihi. (TA.) See also 2 and 5.

1 labaOahaA c
1. labaOahaA, (S, K,) aor.
labaAa
, inf. n. laboCN; (S;) and AltbOhA↓; (TA;) He milked her; (K;) i. e., a ewe: (TA:) or he milked the biestings from her. (S, L.) ― -b2- labaOa AllRibaOa, inf. n. laboCN, He milked the biestings. (TA.) ― -b3- labaOato (in some copies of the K, erroneously, lbROt, TA,) and AlbOt↓, She (a ewe, S,) suckled her young one with her biestings: (S, K:) or she (a ewe) stood up to suckle her young one with her biestings. (AHát.) ― -b4- labaOa, (S, K,) inf. n. laboCN; and lbRO↓ (TA) and AlbO↓; (K;) He fed people &c. with biestings. (S, K.) ― -b5- The first verb is used by Dhu-r-Rummeh in a similar sense, tropically, with reference to the first of truffles. (TA.) ― -b6- Also, labaOahumo He prepared biestings for them. (TA.) ― -b7- labaOa AllRbaOa, (K,) inf. n. laboCN; (TA;) and AlbO↓; (K;) He prepared (TA) and cooked (K) biestings. (K, TA.) ― -b8- labaOa, (TA,) inf. n. laboCN, (K,) (tropical:) He watered (K) a young palm-tree (TA) for the first time (K) after planting it. (TA.) It is said to be lawful to finish doing this even if the Resurrection take place at the time. (TA.)

2 lbROt c
2. lbROt, (K,) inf. n. talobiICN, (TA,) She (a camel, TA) had biestings in her udder. (K.) ― -b2- See 1. ― -b3- lbO fulaAnN mino hecaA AlTRaEaAmi, inf. n. talobiIoCN, Such a one took much of this food. (ISh.) ＝ -A2- lbRO biAlHajRi, (S, K,) inf. n. talobiYapN, (S,) i. q. labRaI. (S, K.) The latter is the original word: (S:) the former thought to be used, agreeably with several cases, as more elegant. (Fr, S.)

4 AlbOt c
4. AlbOt She (a ewe, or goat, M, TA,) excerned, or yielded, or emitted [either into, or from, her udder] her biestings. (M, K.) ― -b2- OalobaWuwA Their biestings became abundant. (S.) ― -b3- See 1, in two places. ― -b4- AlbO He supplied a person with biestings as a travelling-provision. (K.) ― -b5- AlbO, inf. n. UilobaACN, He bound, (K,) or directed, (S,) a kid, (AZ, S,) or a young camel, (K,) to the extremity of the mother's teat, that it might suck the biestings. (AZ, S, K.) ― -b6- AlbOhu biriyqihi (in a trad. respecting the birth of El-Hasan the son of 'Alee) (assumed tropical:) He poured his saliva into his mouth, as the first milk is poured into the mouth of an infant. (TA.)

8 AltbON c
8. AltbON and AstlbO↓ It (a young one) sucked its mother. (S, K.) The latter is said of a kid when it sucks of its own accord. (S.) ― -b2- AltbO He drank biestings. (TA.) ― -b3- bnawu fulaAnK laA yalotabiYuwna fataAhumo walaA yatagabRaruwna Xayoxahumo (assumed tropical:) The sons (or tribe) of such a one do not marry their youth when young, nor their sheykh when old, from desire of offspring. (TA.) [See also art. gbr.]

libaON c
libaON Biestings; or the first milk (S, K) at the time of bringing forth young; (Lth, S;) before it becomes thin: (IHsh) what issues after this being called fiSoHN: (TA:) it is at most three milkings, and at least one milking. (AZ.) [See also UinfaHapN.]

laboOapN c
laboOapN and lubaOapN and other forms, see labuWapN.

labuWN c
labuWN A lion: (L:) but almost obsolete, or rarely used. (L, TA.)

labuWapN c
labuWapN (Th, S, K, the most approved form, Yoo,) and laboOapN↓ and labaACapN↓ and lubaOapN↓ (K) and labowapN (ISk, S, K, in the dial. of El-Hijáz, TA,) and libowapN and labapN and labuwapN and labaApN (K) A lioness. (K.) Accord. to Fei., it has no masc. of the same root; but this is at variance with the authority of the L. (TA.) Pl. (of labuWapN, TA,) labuWN [or this is a quasi-pl. n., or a coll. gen. n.] and (of [laboOapN and] labaApN, (TA,) laboMtN [or, app., accord. to the L, (a passage from which, quoted in the TA, seems to have been there corrupted by the copyist,) if labaApN be a word of a particular dial., not formed by alleviation of hemzeh from laboOapN, its pl. is labaMtN,] and (of lubaOapN, TA,) lubaON and (of labowapN, TA,) labuwaAtN (K, accord. to the TA, but accord. to MF labowaAtN). [These plurals, with their corresponding singulars, are thus given in the TA &c. In the CK, the pls. are given as follows: laboMtN and lubuwoCN and lubuWN and labuwaAtN.] Each of the singulars may have a perfect, or sound, pl., ending with At. (MF.)

naAqapN mulabRiYN c
naAqapN mulabRiYN A camel (TA) having biestings in her udder. (K.)

EiXaArN malaAbiYN c
EiXaArN malaAbiYN (in the CK mulaAbiYN) Camels near to bringing forth. (S, K.) [See EuXaraMCu.]

bayonahumu AlmulotabiYapu c
bayonahumu AlmulotabiYapu There is fellowship and confidence between them; one not concealing from another. (El-Ahmar.)

1 labata yadahu c
1. labata yadahu, (aor.
labuta
, inf. n. labotN, TK,) He twisted, or wrung, his hand, or arm. (L, K.) ― -b2- labata fulaAnFA He struck, or beat, such a one on his chest and belly and flanks, with a staff or stick. (K, TA.)

labaAta c
labaAta dial. of Himyer for laA baOosa. (Sh, T.)

1 labiva c
1. labiva, aor.
labava
, inf. n. labovN (which is contr. to analogy, because the inf. n. of an intrans. v. of the measure faEila is, accord. to rule, of the measure faEalN, S,) and labayvN (agreeably with analogy, occurring in a verse of Jereer, S,) and labaAvN (S, K) and lubovN (which is the first form given by ISd) TA, [and the most common,]) and lubaAvN and labaAvapN and labiyvapN, (K,) which are all contr. to analogy, (TA,) and lubovaAnN, (ISd,) [this last, which is also contr. to analogy, is said in the TA, to be like sHbAn, but this I suppose to be a mistake for suboHaAn,] or lubovN and labaAvN are substs., (Msb,) He tarried; paused; tarried and waited or expected; was patient, and tarried and waited or expected: (S, K:) he tarried; remained; stayed; stopped; paused; (ISd, Msb;) as also tlbRv↓; (Msb;) bimakaAnK in a place: (ISd, Msb:) or tlbRv↓ signifies he waited; or paused; syn. tawaqRafa (K) ― -b2- mAlabiva Oano faEala kacaA wakacaA He delayed not, or was not slow, to do, or in doing, such and such things. (TA, and the other lexicons passim. ― -b3- Ailobavo Eano fulaAnK Wait for such a one, and leave him, until thy doing so shall manifest the error of his judgement, or opinion. (A.)

2 labRava
2: see 4.

4 Albvhu c
4. Albvhu; and lbRvhu↓, inf. n. talobiyvN; He made him to tarry; to tarry and wait, or expect; to be patient, and tarry, and wait, or expect. (S, K.)

5 talabRava
5: see 1.

10 Astlbvhu c
10. Astlbvhu He deemed him, or it, slow, or tardy. (K, TA.)

lubovN c
lubovN and labaAvN↓ (Msb) A tarrying; a staying; a stopping: (Msb:) and lubovapN↓ a loitering; tarrying; staying; waiting; pausing in expectation. (K.) ― -b2- huwa qaliylu AllRabaAvi, and AllRubovapi↓, [He tarries, or stays, little]. (A.) ― -b3- AalmACu UicaA TaAla lubovuhu Zahara xubovuhu [When water remains long stagnant, its corruptness, or impurity, or foulness, becomes apparent]. (A.)

labivN c
labivN: see laAbivN. ― -b2- Slow; tardy; late. (Fr.)

labovapN c
labovapN A single act of tarrying, staying, or stopping. (Msb.)

lubovapN c
lubovapN: see lubovN.

libovapN c
libovapN A mode, or manner, of tarrying, staying, or stopping. (Msb.)

labaAvN c
labaAvN: see lubovN ― -b2- farasN labaAvN A slow horse: so in some copies of the K: but correctly, qawosN labaAvN, as in the L, a slow bow, accord. to AHn. (TA.)

xabiyvN labiyvN nabiyvN c
xabiyvN labiyvN nabiyvN are said conjointly: so in the K: or najiyvN labiyvN: so in the L. (TA.)

labiyvapN mina AlnRaAsi c
labiyvapN mina AlnRaAsi A company, or an assembly, of people of different tribes; (K;) [as also lawiyvapN].

laAbivN c
laAbivN and labivN↓ Tarrying; tarrying and waiting, or expecting; being patient, and tarrying, and waiting, or expecting: (S, K:) the former word is the more approved. (Fr.)

1 labaja c
1. labaja He beat, struck, or smote, another with a staff, or stick: (K:) or he beat, struck, or smote, continuously, but softly. (TA.) ― -b2- labaja bihi AlOaroDa, aor.
labuja
, He threw him down upon the ground: (S, K:) like labaTa. (S.) ― -b3- labaja binafosihi He (a camel) fell down upon the ground. (TA.) ― -b4- labaja binafosihi AlOaroDa fanaAma He threw himself down upon the ground and slept. (AHn.) ― -b5- lubija bihi, (like EuniIa, [pass. in form but neuter in signification,] K, inf. n., labojN, TA,) He became prostrated, or fell down in a fit of epilepsy, syn. SuriEa; (S, K;) fell down from a standing posture: as also lubiTa bihi. (S.) ― -b6- lubija He (a camel, or a man,) fell down upon the ground by reason of disease or fatigue. (TA.)

labiyjN c
labiyjN A man, or a camel, falling, or fallen, down upon the ground by reason of disease or fatigue. (TA.) ― -b2- barokN labiyjN Camels laying on their breasts with folded legs around a tent: (K:) or all the camels of the tribe so lying around the tents, as though thrown down upon the ground. (S.) ― -b3- labiyjN Remaining, staying, abiding, or dwelling. (AHn.)

labaxN c
labaxN, (L, K,) or laboxN, (as mentioned by AHn., on the authority of another, [but see below,]) [a coll. gen. n., n. un. with p, The persea of Theophrastus and Dioscorides; (De Sacy, “ Relation de l'Egypte par Abd-Allatif, ” in which see a full and learned disquisition respecting this tree, pp. 47 et seqq.)] described to AHn, by a man acquainted with it, as growing at Ansinè, in Upper Egypt, as a kind of large tree, resembling the dulob [or plane-tree], having a green fruit, resembling the date, very sweet, but disagreeable, excellent for pain in the teeth: when it is sawn, it [meaning the saw-dust] makes blood to flow from the nose of him who saws it: it is sawn into planks, and a plank of it obtains the price of fifty deenárs: it is used in the building of ships: they assert that if two planks of it be strongly attached together, and put in water for a year, they unite, and form one plank: in the T it is not said that they are put in water for a year, nor for less, nor for more: some assert that this tree, in Persia, killed; but when transplanted to Egypt, it became such that [the fruit of] it was eaten, without injuring: Ibn-Beytár mentions it. (L, and parts also in the K.) The n. un. is also explained as the name of a certain great tree, like the OavoOabap, or greater, the leaves of which resemble those of the walnut-tree (Aljawoz), having a fruit like that of the HamaAT, bitter in taste, which, when eaten, excites thirst; and when water is drunk upon it, inflates the belly: it is one of the trees of the mountains. (AHn, L.) [In a verse cited by AHn, the coll. appellation of this latter tree is read labax, with fet-h to the l and b.] [The name of labax is now given in Egypt to a kind of acacia; the mimosa lebbeck of Linnæus: and labaxu Aljabal, to the menispermum leæba of Delile; the leæba of Forskal. See also lubaAjN.]

lubaAxN c
lubaAxN: see lubaAxiyRapN.

lubuwxN c
lubuwxN Fleshiness of the body. (K.)

labiyxN c
labiyxN A fleshy man. (L, K.)

lubaAxiyRapN c
lubaAxiyRapN A fleshy woman: (L, K:) bulky, or corpulent: tall, and large in body: (L:) perfect [in body or make]: as though it were a rel. n. from AllRubaAx↓, [which is app. a word of no meaning; or perhaps, but this I think improbable, another name of the great tree called labox, or labax, or the name of a place]. (S, L.)

1 labida c
1. labida, aor.
labada
, inf. n. labadN, It (a thing) stuck, clave, or adhered. (Msb.) ― -b2- labada biAlOaroDi, aor,
labuda
, inf. n. lubuwdN; (S, L;) and bihaA Albd↓; (L;) and bihaA tlbRd↓; (S;) It (a thing) stuck, clave, or adhered, to the ground. (S, L.) ― -b3- biAlOaroDi tlbRd↓ He (a bird) lay upon his breast, cleaving to the ground. (S, L, K.) ― -b4- (tropical:) He clave to the ground, concealing his person. (A.) ― -b5- Hence the proverb taSayRadiI talabRadiI↓, [for tataSayRadiI, (tropical:) Cleave thou (addressed to a female) to the ground: thou wilt take, or catch, or snare, or entrap, game]. (A.) ― -b6- Hence also, tlbRd↓ (tropical:) He remained fixed, or steady, and looked, or considered. (A.) ― -b7- labada biAlmakaAni, (L, K, *) aor.
labuda
, inf. n. lubuwdN; and labida, aor.
labada
, inf. n. labadN; (L, K;) and Albd↓; (S, L, K;;) (tropical:) He remained, continued, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in the place; (S, L, K; *) and clave to it. (L, K. *) ― -b8- labada EalaI EaSaAhu, inf. n. lubuwdN, (assumed tropical:) He (a pastor) leaned upon his staff, remaining fixed to his place. (L.) ― -b9- labida, aor.
labada
, (S, L,) inf. n. labadN, (S, L, K,) He (a camel) became choked by eating much of the plant called SilRiyaAn, suffering a contortion in the [part of the chest called] Hayozuwm and in the [part of the throat called] galoSamap: (ISk, S, L, K: *) or had a complaint of the belly from eating of the qataAd [or tragacantha]. (AHn, L.) ― -b10- See 4.

2 lbRdhu c
2. lbRdhu, inf. n. talobiydN, He stuck it, one part upon another, so that it became like libod [or felt]. (Msb.) ― -b2- lbRd AlSRuwfa He made the wool into libod [i. e., a compact and coherent mass; or felt]. (A.) [And He, or it, rendered the wool coherent, compact, or matted.] ― -b3- lbRd AlOaroDa, (inf. n. talobiydN, L,) It (rain, S, A, or a scanty rain, L,) rendered the ground compact, so that the feet did not sink in it. (S, * A, * L.) ― -b4- lbRd, (L,) or lbRd XaEarahu, (L, Msb,) inf. n. talobiydN, (S, L, Msb,) He (a pilgrim, S, L, Msb, in the state of UiHoraAm, S, L,) put upon his head some gum, (A 'Obeyd, S, L, K,) or xiTomiIR or the like, (Msb,) or honey, (A 'Obeyd, L,) or something glutinous, (L,) in order that his hair might become compacted together, (A 'Obeyd, S, L, Msb, K,) to preserve it in the state in which it was, (S, * L,) lest it should become shaggy, or dishevelled, and frowzy, or dusty, (S, L, Msb,) or lousy, (A 'Obeyd, L,) during the state of AHrAm. (S, L.) The Arabs in the time of paganism used to do thus when they did not desire to shave their heads during the pilgrimage. Some say, that it signifies He shaved the whole of his hair. (L.) ＝ -A2- lbRd EajaAjatahu: see art. Ej.

4 Oalobada
4:: see 1. ― -b2- Albd XayoYFA biXaIoCK He stuck a thing to a thing; (K;) as also labadahu, inf. n. labodN: (TA:) or he stuck a thing firmly to a thing. (L.) ― -b3- He put the milking-vessel close to the udder [lit., stuck it to the udder] in order that there might
be no froth to the milk. (TA, art. nfj.) ― -b4- Albd He (a camel) struck his hinder parts with his tail, having befouled it with his thin dung and his urine, and so made these to form a compact crust upon those parts. (S, L.) ― -b5- Albd baSaruhu (assumed tropical:) His sight, or eye, (meaning that of a person praying,) remained fixed upon the place of prostration. (K.) ― -b6- Albd (tropical:) He lowered, or stooped, his head, in entering (A, K) a door. (A.) ＝ -A2- Albd AlsRaroja; (S, IKtt, K;) and labadahu↓, inf. n. labodN; (IKtt;) He made for the saddle a libod [or cloth of felt to place beneath it]: (S, IKtt, K:) and in like manner, Albd AlxufRa, and labadahu↓, he made a libod [or lining of felt?] for the boots. (IKtt.) ― -b2- Albd Alfarasa He bound upon the horse a libod [or saddle cloth, or covering of felt]: (S, K:) or put it upon his back. (A.) ― -b3- Albdti AlUibilu (assumed tropical:) The camels put forth their soft hair (S, L, K) and their colours, (S, L,) and assumed a goodly appearance, (L,) and began to grow fat, (S, L, K,) by reason of the [season, or pasture, called] rabiyE: (S, L:) as though they put on OalobaAd [or felt coverings]. (L.) ― -b4- Albd Alqirobapa He put the water-skin into a juwaAliq [or sack]: (K:) or into a labiyd, or small jwAlq: (S:) the labiyd is a libod [or covering of felt] which is sewed upon it. (L.)

5 talabRada
5: see 1. ― -b2- tlbd It (wool, A, L, K, and the like, K, as common hair, A, L, and the soft hair of camels or the like, L,) became commingled, and compacted together, or matted, coherent; (S, * A, * L, K;) as also Altbd↓. (L.) [Both are also said of dung, and of a mixture of dung and urine, meaning It caked, or became compacted, upon the ground &c.] ― -b3- It (the ground, L, or the dust, or the sand, A,) became compact, so that the feet did not sink in it, by reason of rain. (S, * A, * L.) ― -b4- [Also, app., He shrank, by reason of fear: see habiytN: in the present day it is used to signify he hid, or contracted, himself, by reason of fear, or for the purpose of practising some act of guile.]

8 Altbdt AlXRajarapu c
8. Altbdt AlXRajarapu The tree became dense, or abundant, in its foliage. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- Altbd Alwaraqu The leaves became commingled, and compacted together. (S, L, K.) See 5.

libodN c
libodN Hair or wool commingled, and compacted together, or coherent; [felt;] (L, Msb, K;) as also libodapN↓; (L, K;) or this is a more particular term; [meaning a portion of such hair or wool; a piece of felt;] (S, Msb;) and lubodapN↓: (L, K:) pl. of libodN, (or of lbdp, as though the p were imagined to be elided, M,) lubuwdN (S, A, L, K) and OalobaAdN. (L, K.) ― -b2- libodN A well-known kind of carpet [and cloth, made of felt]. (L, K.) ― -b3- libodN [or libodapN, (S, art. wvr,)] What is beneath the saddle; [a saddle-cloth; a housing; a cloth of felt, which is placed beneath the saddle, and also used as a covering without the saddle]. (S, * L, * K.)

labadN c
labadN Wool. (S, K.) Hence the saying maA lahu sabadN walaA labadN He has neither hair nor wool: (S:) or, neither what has hair nor what has wool: or, neither little nor much: (TA:) or, he has not anything: (S:) for the wealth of the Arabs consisted of horses, camels, sheep and goats, and cows; and all of these are included in this saying (TA.) See also sabadN.

lbd c
lbd [app. labidN] Compact, or cohering, ground, upon which one may walk, or journey, quickly. (L.)

labidN c
labidN (S, K) and lubadN↓, (S, A, L, K,) the former of which is preferable, accord. to A'Obeyd, (S,) (tropical:) One who does not travel, (S, L,) nor quit his abode, (S, * L, K,) or place, (A,) nor seek sustenance. (L, K.) Hence, (A,) the last of Lukmán's [seven] vultures [with whose life his own was to terminate] was called lubadN↓, (S, A, L, K,) because he thought that is would not go away nor die. (L.) Thus applied, it is perfectly decl., because it is a word not made to deviate from its original form. (S, L.) ― -b2- Also lubadN↓ A man who does not quit his camel's saddle. (L.)

lubadN c
lubadN (S, L) and libadN, which is pl. of libodapN↓, (L,) and lubRadaI↓, (L, K,) and libodapN↓, and lubodapN↓, (L,) (tropical:) A number of men collected together, (S, L, K,) and [as it were] compacted, one upon another: so the first and second of these words, accord. to different readings, signify in the Kur., lxxii., 19: (L:) or libadN signifies collected together like locusts, (T, L,) which are app. thus called as being likened to a congregation of men; (ISd, L;) pl. of libodapN, (L,) which signifies a locust. (K.) [See a verse cited voce SaAba.] ― -b2- maAlN lubadN, (S, A, K, &c.,) and lubRadN↓, (Aboo-Jaafar, K,) and lubudN↓, (El-Hasan and Mujáhid,) and lubodN↓, (Mujáhid,) (tropical:) Much wealth; (S, K, &c.;) so in the Kur., xc., 6; (S, TA;) as also laAbidN↓: (K:) or wealth so abundant that one fears not its coming to an end: (A, L:) some say that lubadN is a pl., and that its sing. is lubodapN: others, that it is sing., like quvamN and HuSamN: OamowaAlN and maAlN are sometimes used in the same sense: lubRadN seems to be pl. of laAbidN: (L:) so is lubudN, and so lubodN: (El-Basáïr:) also, mAl libadN, which is accord. to the reading of Zeyd Ibn-'Alee and Ibn-'Omeyr and 'Ásim, signifies collected wealth; libadN being pl. of libodapN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See lubadN.

libodapN c
libodapN (tropical:) The mass of hair between the shoulderblades of the lion, (S, A, K,) intermingled, and compacted together: (A:) and the like upon a camel's hump: (T, L:) pl. libadN. (S.) Hence the proverb, huwa OamonaEu mino libodapi AlOasadi [He, or it, is more unapproachable, or inaccessible, than the mass of hair between the shoulder-blades of the lion]. (S, A.) Hence also cuw libodapK is an appel-lation of the lion; (T, S, A, K;) and so cuw libadK. (T, A,) ― -b2- See libodN and lubadN.

lubodapN c
lubodapN: see lubadN.

naAqapN labidapN c
naAqapN labidapN A she-camel choked by eating much of the plant called SilRiyaAn: pl. labaAdaI: [see labida:] (S:) or UibilN labidapN, and labaAdaI, camels having a complaint of the belly from eating of the qataAd [or tragacantha]: and in like manner you say nAqp labidapN. (AHn, L.)

labiydN c
labiydN A juwaAliq [or sack]: (K:) or a small jwAlq: (S, IKtt, L:) or a large jwAlq: a libod [or covering of felt] which is sewed upon a qirobap [or water-skin]. (L.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) or labiydapN, (L,) A [fodder-bag of the kind called] mixolaAp. (L, K.)

labRaAdN c
labRaAdN A maker, or manufacturer, of libod [i. e., hair or wool commingled, and compacted together; or felt]. (K.)

lubRaAdapN c
lubRaAdapN A garment of felt (mino libod, S, or lubuwd, L, K,) worn on account of rain, (S, L, Msb, K,) to protect one therefrom: (TA:) a garment of the kind called qabaMC. (L.)

lubRaAdaI c
lubRaAdaI: see lubadN.

laAbidN c
laAbidN see lubadN. ― -b2- AllRaAbidu, and Almulobadu↓, and Oabuw lubadK, and Oabuw libadK, (tropical:) The lion. (K.)

mlobadN c
mlobadN A horse having a libod [or saddle-cloth, or covering of felt] bound upon him. (S.) ― -b2- See AllaAbidu, and mulobidN.

mulobidN c
mulobidN A camel (L, K) or stallion-camel, (T, L,) striking his thighs with his tail, (L, K,) and making his dung to stick to them. (L.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A man cleaving to the ground, and making himself inconspicuous: (TA:) (tropical:) a man cleaving to the ground by reason of poverty. (A.) ― -b3- mulobidN, or mulobadN↓, applied to a tank, or cistern: see mubolidN.

mulabRidN c
mulabRidN Scanty rain [that renders the soft ground compact, so that the feet do not sink in it]. (L.)

xufRN mulabRadN c
xufRN mulabRadN, and malobuwdN↓, A pair of boots made of libod [or felt]. (A.) See also 4.

malobuwdN c
malobuwdN (assumed tropical:) A he-goat compact in flesh. (L.) ― -b2- See preceding paragraph.

1 labisa AlvRawoba c
1. labisa AlvRawoba, aor.
labasa
, inf. n. lubosN (S, M, A, Msb, K) and libaAsN, (M,) [He put on, or wore, the garment.] You also say, Ailobaso Ealayoka vawobaka [Put on thee thy garment]. (M.) And labisa AlsRilaAHa [He wore, or put on, the weapon, or weapons]. (S, K, in art. slH, &c.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- labisa AlHayaMCa libaAsFA (assumed tropical:) [He put on pudency as a garment;] he protected himself by pudency. (IKtt.) ― -b3- labisa lahu Oucunahu (tropical:) He feigned himself inattentive to him, or heedless of him. (M. [See also OucunN.]) And labisotu EalaI kacaA OacuniI (tropical:) I was silent respecting such a thing, and feigned myself deaf to it. (A.) [Contr. of naXarotu lahu OucuniI.] ― -b4- labisa QmoraOapF (tropical:) He had the enjoyment of a woman, or wife, [meaning, of her converse and services,] for a long time. (K, TA.) And labisa fulaAnapa Eumorahu (tropical:) He had such a girl, or woman, with him during the whole period of his youth. (K, TA.) And labisa AlnAsa (tropical:) He lived with the people. (A.) And labisa qawomFA (tropical:) He lived, or enjoyed, a period of time, or a long period of time, (dahorFA,) with the people. (K, * TA.) [And labisa OabaAhu, which is explained in the TA by malRahu, which I also find in a copy of the A thought to have been used by the author of the TA: but, from what follows, it appears to me that the right reading is mulRiyahu, and the meaning, (tropical:) He enjoyed long life with his father: or he lived the period that his father lived: or he lived with his father all his (the latter's) life: see a verse of Ibn-Ahmar cited voce OabolaI in art. blw. See also a verse of El-'Ajjáj cited voce xalaja.] You say also, labisotu fulaAnFA (tropical:) I took, or chose, such a one particularly, or specially, as a friend or companion. (Er-Rághib in TA art. bTn.) And Ailobasi AlnRaAsa EalaI qadori OaxolaAqhimoi (tropical:) Consort thou with men [according to their natural dispositions]. (A, TA.) And labisotu fulaAnFA EalaI maA fiyhi (tropical:) I tolerated such a one, and accepted him, [and continued to associate with him, notwithstanding what was in him.] (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- labasa Ealayohi AlOamora, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
labisa
, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. labosN, (S, M, Msb,) He made, or rendered, the thing, or case, or affair, confused to him: (S, M, Msb, K:) and lbRshu↓, (A, Msb,) inf. n. talobiysN, (S, K,) signifies the same in an intensive degree: (S, * Msb, K: *) or the former signifies either as above, or he concealed the thing, or case, or affair, from him: (R, MF:) and [in like manner] talobiysN is syn. with tadoliysN, (K,) or is similar thereto: (S:) and the former also signifies he made, or rendered, the thing, or case, or affair, dubious to him; (TA;) [as also lbRshu↓: both signify he involved the thing, or case, or affair, in confusion, or doubt, to him: and he concealed, disguised, or cloaked, it to him.] It is said in the Kur., [vi. 9,] walalabasonaA Ealayohimo maA yalobisuwna And we would make confused to them what they make confused: (S, Msb:) or make dubious to them what they make dubious, and would make them to err like as they have made to err. (TA.) And again, [ii. 39,] walaA talobisuwA QloHaqRa biQlobATili And do not ye confound the truth with falsity. (Ibn- 'Arafeh.) And again, [vi. 82,] walamo yalobisuwA UiymaAnahumo biZulomK And have not mixed up their belief with polytheism. (TA.) And again, [vi. 65,] Oawo yalobisakumo XiyaEFA Or to confuse your case, [making you to be of different parties,] with the confusion of discordance and of agreement. (TA.) You say also, labasaniI, meaning, He, or it, made me to become confounded, or in doubt, (jaEalaniI Oalotabisu,) respecting his case, or affair. (TA, from a trad.)

2 labRasa
2: see 4: ― -b2- and see also labasa, in three places. [talobiysN, alone, often signifies The involving a thing in confusion, or doubt: and the practising concealment, or disguise.] ＝ -A2- See also 8.

3 lAbs AlrRajula c
3. lAbs AlrRajula, [inf. n. mulaAbasapN and libaAsN,] He mixed, consorted, or held social intercourse, with the man; syn. xaAlaTahu. (M, A, Msb. *) [Hence, app., it is said that] AllRibaAsu signifies, (K,) or is from AlmulaAbasapu, which signifies, (Ibn-'Arafeh) The mixing one's self and congregating: or the being mixed and congregated. (Ibn-'Arafeh, K.) You say, laA basotuhu HatRaI Earafotu duxolatahu I mixed with him [until I knew his mind, or inward state or circumstances]. (A.) And laA basotuhu [alone] signifies I knew his mind, or inward state or circumstances. (S, K.) ― -b2- lAbs AlOamora, and lAbs Eamalahu: see 5. ― -b3- [mulaAbasapN often signifies A close, or an intimate, connexion between two things.] See also 8.

4 Albshu AlvRawoba c
4. Albshu AlvRawoba [He put on him, or clad or decked him with, the garment, and so, vulg., lbRshu↓]. (M, Msb.) ― -b2- Albshu also signifies He, or it, covered him, or it: (K:) or overspread him, or it; i. e. covered the whole thereof. (AA.) You say, AlHarRapu AlOaroDu AlRatiI OalobasatohaA HijaArapN suwdN [The HrRp is ground which black stones have covered, or covered the wholly]. (TA.) And Oalobasati AlsRamaMCa AlsRaHaAbu. (TA,) or Oalobasa, (AA,) [The clouds covered the sky, &c.;] but you do not say, labisa AlsRamaMCu AlsRaHaAba. (AA.) And OalobasanaA AllRayolu [The night covered us, &c.]; but not labisonaA AllRayola. (AA.) And Albshu AlXRabaAbu: see 1 in art. gTw and gTI. ＝ -A2- Oalobasati AlOaroDu The land became covered by plants, or herbage. (M.) ＝ -A3- See also 8.

5 tlbRs biAlvRawobi c
5. tlbRs biAlvRawobi (S, K) He clad himself [lit. mixed himself, being explained by UixotalaTa,] with the garment. (K.) You say, tlbRs bilibaAsK HasanK and libaAsFA HasanFA [He clad himself with goodly clothing]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] tlbRs biAlOamori (S, K) [and bihi Altbs↓] He employed, busied, or occupied, himself [lit. mixed himself] with the affair; engaged in it; entered into it; became involved in it, or implicated in it; (K;) and [in like manner] AlOamora laAbasa↓, syn. xaAlaTahu. (S, K. *) You say also, Eamalahu laAbasa↓ and bihi Altbs↓ and tlbsR bihi [He employed, busied, or occupied, himself with his work, or the like]. (A, TA.) [See 8.] ― -b3- tlbRs AlTRaEaAmu biAlyadi The food stuck to the hand. (K.) ― -b4- tlbRs biIa AlOamoru The thing, as, for instance, love, mingled with me, and clung to me. (M.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce EaTofapN.]

8 Altbs c
8. Altbs It (spun thread) became entangled. (Lth, Az, Sgh, in TA, art. Esr.) ― -b2- It (a thing, or an affair, or a case) became [involved, complicated,] confounded, or confused, (S, M, Msb, *) and dubious; (S, Msb;) as also Oalobasa↓, (TA,) and labRasa↓, which last belongs to the class of bayRana in the phrase
qado bayRana AlSRuboHu liciI Eayonayoni
(M, TA.) [You say, Altbs AlXRaIoCu biXaIoCK Mxara The thing became confounded with another thing; as, for instance, a subst. with a part. n. when both are written in the same manner, as in the case of kaAhilN.] And Altbs Ealayohi AlOamoru The thing, or affair, became confused and dubious to him. (S.) And jaEalaniI Oalotabisu fiI Oamorihi [He, or it, made me to become confounded, or in doubt, respecting his case, or affair]. (TA.) And Aulotubisa biI I was, or became, disordered in my mind. (K, * TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- Altbs biEamalihi &c.: see 5. ― -b4- Ailotabasato bihi Alxayolu (tropical:) The horsemen overtook him. (A, TA.) ― -b5- [Altbs bihi also signifies He, or it, made it to be, or had it, as an accompaniment, or an adjunct. Hence, one of the uses of the preposition bi is explained by some as being liloAilotibaAsi: by others, lilomulaAbasapi↓, or lilomuSaAHabapi: all of which signify nearly the same. For instance, it is said in the Mgh, art. twj, that in the phrase AltRamaAviylu biAltiyjaAni “ the effigies with the crowns ” upon pieces of money, bAltyjAn is used as a denotative of state, meaning mulotabisapF biAlitRyjaAni and maqoruwnapF maEahaA accompanied with the crowns, as their attributes: and nusabRiHu biHamodika “ we declare thy remoteness from evil, with the praising of Thee, ” in the Kur ii. 28, is explained by Bd and others as meaning, mulotabisiyna biHamodika making the praising of Thee to be as an accompaniment, or an adjunct, to our doing that: and tanobutu biQldRuhoni “ growing, with oil ”, in the same, xxiii. 20, as meaning, mulotabisFA
biAldRuhoni having oil as an accompaniment to its growth. Sometimes, in such instances, we find mutalabRisFA and mutalabRisiyna in the places of mulotabisFA and mulotabisiyna: see 5.]

labosN c
labosN Confusedness of a thing or an affair or a case; as also labasN↓: (M:) [and lubosN↓ and lubosapN↓ and labuwsapN↓ and lubuwsapN↓ have the same, or a similar, signification.] You say, fiI raOoyihi labosN In his judgment, or opinion, is confusedness. (K.) And fiI AlOamori lubosapN↓ (S, M, * A, Msb, K *) and lubosN↓ (M, A, Msb.) In the thing, or affair, or case, is confusedness, and dubiousness; (S, M, Msb, K; *) obscureness, or want of clearness. (S, A.) And fiI Hadiyvihi lubosapN↓ In his discourse is confusedness and dubiousness; it is not clear. (TA.) And fiI kalaAmihi labuwsapN↓ and lubuwsapN↓ In his language is confusedness and dubiousness. (M.) ― -b2- Also, The confusedness of darkness, or the beginning of night. (S.)

lubosN c
lubosN: see labosN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see libaAsN.

libosN c
libosN: see libaAsN, in five places: ― -b2- and see libosapN.

labasN c
labasN: see labosN.

labisN c
labisN A man possessing clothing, dress, or apparel: a possessive epithet. (Sb, M.)

labosapN c
labosapN [A single art of putting on, or wearing, a garment]. You say, labisotu AlvRawoba labosapF waAHidapF [I put on, or wore, the garment once]. (TA.)

lubosapN c
lubosapN: see labosN, in three places.

libosapN c
libosapN A mode, or manner, of putting on, or wearing, apparel; or of dressing one's self. (IAth, K.) [Hence the saying,] likulRi zamaAnK libosapN (tropical:) For every time there is a mode of attiring one's self, according as it is a time of straitness or of plenty. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- A certain sort of garments, or cloths; as also libosN↓. (K.)

libaAsN c
libaAsN [Clothing; dress; apparel;] what is worn; as also libosN↓, and malobasN↓ (S, M, * Msb, K) and milobasN↓ (K) and labuwsN↓; (S, K;) or the last signifies garments, or pieces of cloth: (M:) the pl. of the first is lubusN, like as kutubN is pl. of kitaAbN: and that of malobasN is malaAbisu. (Msb.) Hence, labAsu AlkaEobapi, and Alhawodaji, (Msb,) or AlkaEobapi libosu↓, and Alhawodaji, (S, M, A, K,) The clothing, (S, Msb, K,) or covering of pieces of cloth, (M,) of the Kaabeh, and of the [camel-litter called] hwdj. (S, M, Msb, K.) And libaAsu AltRaqowaI, in the Kur [vii. 25,] (TA,) [(assumed tropical:) The apparel of piety: or] (tropical:) thick, or coarse, and rough, and short, apparel: (S:) or (tropical:) the covering of that portion of the person which modesty forbids one to expose; (K;) at which the preceding words of the verse glance; indicating that this is the main purpose of clothing; the additional purpose being to beautify and adorn one's self, and to repel heat and cold: (TA:) or (tropical:) honest shame, or the shrinking of the soul from foul conduct, through fear of blame; syn. AlHayaMCu: (S, M, A, K:) or (tropical:) righteous conduct: (TA:) or (tropical:) faith. (Es-Suddee, K.) And AllRibosu↓, (K,) written by Sgh AllRubosu↓, (TA,) or libosu AlEaZomi, (A, TA,) (tropical:) i. q. AlsRimoHaAqu [The pericranium]: (A, K:) to which is added, in some of the copies of the K, in the handwriting of the author, i. e., a thing pellicle that is between the skin and the flesh. (TA.) ― -b2- The covering of anything. (M.) [Hence,] libaAsu AlnRawori The outer coverings, or calyxes, of flowers. (M.) It is said in the Kur [lxxviii. 10,] wajaEalonaA QlolRayola libaAsFA (assumed tropical:) [And we have made the night to be a covering]: i. e., it covers, veils, or conceals, you by its darkness. (TA.) ― -b3- A man's wife; (S, M, * K; *) like UizaArN: (M:) and a woman's husband: (S, M, * K: *) occurring in the Kur ii. 183: (S, M:) or there meaning like a garment: (M, TA:) because each embraces the other: or because each goes to the other for rest, and consorts with (yulaAbisu) the other: (Zj, M, Bd, * TA:) from AlmulaAbasapu, signifying “ the mixing one's self and congregating, ” or “ the being mixed and congregated: ” (Ibn-'Arafeh, TA:) or because each conceals the state of the other, and prevents the other from acting viciously. (Bd.) ― -b4- libaAsu AljuwEi (tropical:) The utmost degree of hunger; (K, TA;) when people are so hungry that they eat camels' fur with blood: (TA:) so termed because all-involving. (K.) It is said in the Kur [xvi. 113,] faOacaAqahaA QllReha libaAsa QlojuwEi waQloxawofi (tropical:) [So God made her to taste the utmost degree of hunger and of fear]. (K, * TA. [See also 4 in art. cwq.])

labuwsN c
labuwsN: see libaAsN. ― -b2- A coat of mail: (S, M, K:) in which sense it is fem: (M:) [and, like diroEN, sometimes masc.: see an instance voce masoruwdN:] or coats of mail: (so in one copy of the S:) so in the Kur xxi. 80. (S, TA.) ― -b3- A weapon: in which sense it is masc. (M.) ＝ -A2- See also labRaAsN.

labiysN c
labiysN Much, or often, worn: (Msb:) or worn-out: (M, A, K:) applied to a garment: (M, Msb, K:) and to [the kind of garment called] a miloHafap: (M:) and to [the kind called] a mulaMCap: (A, TA:) without p: (M, * A, * TA:) and to [a leather water-bag such as is called] a mazaAdap: (M, A;) meaning used until worn-out: (M:) and to a rope; meaning used: (AHn, M:) and to a house (dAr); [meaning impaired by time;] likened to a worn-out garment: (M:) pl. lubusN; and, when the sing. is applied to a mzAdp, the pl. is labaAYisu. (M.) ＝ -A2- A like: (K:) from AlmulaAbasapu, signifying “ the mixing ”, or “ consorting ”. (Aboo-Málik.) You say, layosa lahu labiysN He, or it, has not a like. (K.)

labuwsapN c
labuwsapN and lubuwsapN: see labosN; each in two places.

labRaAsN c
labRaAsN A man having many clothes; (K;) as also labuwsN↓: (M, TA:) or who wears much clothing; syn. kaviyru AllRubosi: (so in the K accord. to the TA:) or who confuses, or confounds, much; syn. kaviyru AllRabosi: (so in a copy of the K [and this signification seems to be implied by what immediately precedes, and by what follows, rajulN labRaAsN in the S: in the CK, AllRabosi, which is evidently a mistake:]) you should not say mulabRisN; (S, K;) for this is vulgar. (TA.)

jaMCa laAbisFA Oucunayohi c
jaMCa laAbisFA Oucunayohi (tropical:) He came feigning himself inattentive, or heedless. (M.) [Contr. of naAXirFA Oucunayohi.]

malobasN c
malobasN: see libaAsN. ― -b2- maA fiI falaAnK malobasN (tropical:) There is no profit (musotamotaEN) in such a one, (S, M, A, [but in the M and A, maA is omitted, and the only explanation is the word which I have given in Arabic.]) ― -b3- UinRa fiyhi lamalobasFA Verily in him is no pride, or greatness; expl. by maA bihi kiborN, or kibrN, accord. to different authorities [and different copies of the K]: this explanation is by AZ. (TA.) ― -b4- OaEoraDa vawobu Almalobasi and Almilobasi↓ and Almulobisi↓ (IAar, K) and Almulotabisi↓: (TA:) see EaruDa, under which it is explained.

mulobisN c
mulobisN: see mulotabisN: and malobasN.

milobasN c
milobasN: see libaAsN: and malobasN.

mulabRisN c
mulabRisN: see labRaAsN.

OamorN mulotabisN c
OamorN mulotabisN A confounded, or confused, and dubious, thing affair, or case; as also mulobisN↓. (K, TA. [In the CK, biAlAamori is wrongly inserted after mltbs.]) ― -b2- See 8. ― -b3- And see also malobasN.

1 latRa c
1. latRa, (aor.
latuta
, TA,) inf. n. latRN, He bruised, or brayed, or broke up into small fragments, or particles. (A, M, K.) He (an ass) broke in pieces, or bruised, with his hoof, the pebbles over which he passed. (TA.) ― -b2- I. q., fatRa, He crumbled a thing, or broke it into small pieces, with his fingers: or broke a thing with his fingers: &c. (K.) ― -b3- He pounded, or bruised, small; he pulverized; syn. saHaqa. (Sgh, K.) ＝ -A2- latRa AlsRawiyqa, aor.
latuta
, inf. n. latRN, He moistened the swyq with a little water, [or clarified butter, or fat of a sheep's tail, &c. (see lutaAtN)]: (Msb:) it signifies less
than basRa: (Lth, Msb:) he stirred it about with water &c. until they became of a uniform consistence; or stirred it about with a mijodaH; i. q. jadaHahu: (S:) and in like manner, AlOaqiTa and the like: (TA:) or [simply] he moistened the swyq: (Lth:) or he moistened the swyq in the manner termed basRN, with water and the like: (TA:) [accord. to present usage, he moistened, and beat up, or mingled, the swyq with water &c.] ― -b2- latRa viyaAbahu, [aor.
latuta
,] inf. n. latRN, (assumed tropical:) It (a rain) wetted his clothes. (A.) ＝ -A3- latRa, (aor.
latuta
, S,) inf. n. latRN He bound a thing. (As, S, K.) ― -b2- lutRa fulaAnN bifulaAnK Such a one was joined, connected, coupled, or associated, with such a one; expl. by luzRa bihi waqurina maEahu. (S, K.)

lutaAtN c
lutaAtN What is crumbled, or broken into small pieces, with the fingers, (maA futRa,) of the barks of trees: (K:) i. e., what is so crumbled, or broken, of the dry, outer bark: but Az says, I know not whether it be litaAtN or lutaAtN. (TA.) Esh-Sháfi'ee is related to have pronounced the performance of tayamRumK therewith not allowable. (TA.) ― -b2- maA OaboqaI minRiI UilRaA lutaAtFA, occurring in a trad., means, It (the disease) left nothing remaining of me but dry skin like the bark of trees. (TA.) ＝ -A2- That with which one moistens [sawiyq &c.]; expl. by maA yulatRu bihi: (K:) anything with which swyq &c. are moistened; such as clarified butter, and the fat of a sheep's tail. (Lth.)

latolatapN c
latolatapN An oath that plunges the swearer thereof into sin, and then into hell-fire: or, by which he cuts off the property of another, for himself; an intentionally false oath: syn. yamiynN gamuwsN. (IAar, Sgh, A, K.)

AllRaAtRu c
AllRaAtRu, occurring in the Kur [liii. 19,] (TA,) so accord. to the reading of Ibn-'Abbás and 'Ikrimeh and some others, (K,) and so originally accord. to Fr.: (TA:) afterwards contracted into AllRaAtu: (Fr, K:) which is the common reading: (Fr:) A certain idol; thus called by the appellation of a man who used to moisten sawiyq with clarified butter at the place thereof: (K:) the man who did this was thus called, and afterwards the idol itself. (TA.) Some of the lexicologists say, that it was a mass of rock, at the place whereof was a man who used to moisten swyq for the pilgrims, and which, when he died, was worshipped: (L:) but ISd says, I know not what is the truth in this case. (TA.) In the R it is said, that the man who used to do this was 'Amr Ibn-Lu-eí; that when the tribe of Khuzá'ah obtained the dominion over Mekkeh, and banished the tribe of Jurhum, the Arabs made him a Lord, or an object of worship; and that he was El-Látt, who used to moisten swyq for the pilgrims upon a well-known rock, called Sxorapu AllRaAtRi: or, it is said, that the man in question was of the tribe of Thakeef; and that when he died, 'Amr Ibn-Loheí (lHI: so in the TA) said to the people, “ He hath not died, but hath entered the rock: ” and ordered them to worship it, and built over it a house called AllAt: it is also said to have continued thus during the life of this man and that of his son, for three hundred years: then that rock was named AllRaAtu, without teshdeed to the t, and was taken for an idol, to be worshipped. (TA.) It is disputed whether it were [an idol] of the tribe of Thakeef at Et-Táïf, or of the tribe of Kureysh at En-Nakhleh. (MF.) Some say, that the t is originally without teshdeed, and to denote the fem. gender: Ks used to pronounce the word in a case of pause AllRaAho; and Aboo-Is-hák [Zj] says, that this is agreeable with analogy; but that the more approved mode is to pronounce it in such case with t. AM says, that the manner in which Ks pronounced it in a case of pause shows that he did not derive it from latRN. The polytheists who worshipped this idol used to compare its name with the name of AllReh. It is also said, that AllRaAtu, without teshdeed, is of the measure faEalapN [originally AllRawayapu] from the root lwI; [and that the said idol was so called] because they used to compass it, or perform circuits round it. (TA.) [See art. lwI: and see also arts. lwh and lyh: and AlrRabRapu, in art rb.]

1 lataOah fiI Sadorihi c
1. lataOah fiI Sadorihi, aor.
lataAa
, (K,) inf. n. latoCN, (TA,) He thrust him on his breast. (K.) ― -b2- lataOa He hit, struck, or hurt; syn. OaSaAba. (TA.) ― -b3- lataOa bisahomK He shot an arrow. (K, * TA.) ― -b4- lataOahu biHajarK He cast a stone at him. (S, K. *) ― -b5- lataOato bihi (tropical:) She (a woman) brought him forth. (S, K. *) ― -b6- laEana AllRehu OumRFA lataOato bihi, and lakaOato bh, (S,) (tropical:) God curse the mother that cast him forth (from her womb)! a tropical expression, from casting a stone, or shooting an arrow. (TA.) ― -b7- lataOa, (S, K,) inf. n. latoCN, (TA,) Inivit feminam. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- lataOa He lessened, or diminished; syn. naqaSa. (K.) ― -b2- Pepedit. (K.) ― -b3- Excrevit merdam. (K.) ― -b4- He, or it, passed, or went away; syn. maDaI. (CK.) ＝ -A3- lataOa biEayonihi, (TA,) or ltO alone, (K,) inf. n. latoCN, (TA,) He looked intently. (K.) ― -b2- lataOahu biEayonihi He looked intently at him. (S.)

latiICN c
latiICN Remaining fixed, or keeping, to his place: (K:) or thrown down, or hit, or struck, and remaining fixed, or keeping, to his place. (TA.) [In the TA, one of the words by which it is explained is malotiIRN↓; which is for malotuwCN; like maqoriIRN for maqoruwCN.]

malotiIRN c
malotiIRN: see latiICN.

1 lataba c
1. lataba, aor.
latuba
, inf. n. latobN and lutuwbN, He, or it, was, or remained, fixed, settled, or firm: (As, S, K:) adhered, clave, or stuck. (K.) ＝ -A2- lataba, inf. n. latobN and lutuwbN, He bound, tightened, or made fast. (K.) ― -b2- lataba Ealayohi viyaAbahu He bound his clothes upon him. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, inf. n. as above; and Alttb↓; [in the CK, for UilotitaAbN, is put UilotiyaAbN;) He put on his clothes. (K.) ― -b4- lataba Ealayohi vawobahu He put on his garment, as though he did not desire to take it off. (TA.) ― -b5- lataba AljulRa EalaI Alfarasi, inf. n. as above; and ltRbhu↓, inf. n. talotiybN; He bound the covering upon the horse. (K.) ＝ -A3- lataba fI manoHari AlnRaAqapi He stabbed, or stuck, the she-camel [in the part immediately above the breast-bone]: like latama. (S.)

2 latRaba
2: see 1.

4 Altbhu Ealayohi c
4. Altbhu Ealayohi, (inf. n. UilotaAbN, TA,) He imposed it (a thing, or affair, TA,) upon him, as obligatory, or as a thing that must be done. (K.)

8 Uilotataba
8: see 1.

laAtibN c
laAtibN Being, or remaining, fixed, settled, or firm: adhering, cleaving, or sticking: (As, S:) i. q. laAzibN. (Fr.) ― -b2- Darobapu laAtibK i. q. Drbp laAzbK. (Fr.) See art. lzb.

milotabN c
milotabN One who keeps to his house, or dwelling, avoiding seditions, or disturbances. (K.)

malaAtibu c
malaAtibu Worn-out garments of the kind called jibaAbN, pl. of jubRap: (K:) or garments of the kind so called, and worn-out garments. (Lth.)

1 latiHa c
1. latiHa, aor.
lataHa
, (inf. n. lataHN, S,) He hungered; was hungry. (S. K.)

latoHaAnu c
latoHaAnu Hungry: fem. latoHaI. (S, K.)

superEntry.entry:
1 lavRa c
1. lavRa, [aor.
laviva
,] inf. n. lavRN; (K;) and AlvR↓ (in the T Oalovava,) inf. n. UilovaAvN; and lavolava↓, inf. n. lavolavapN; (As, S, K;) He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt; (As, S, K;) bimakaAnK in a place; (As, S;) and quitted it not. (TA.) So in the words of a trad., laA tulivRuwA bidaAri maEojazapK, and maEojizapK, (S,) [Remain ye not in a dwelling of impotence]: i. e., remain not in a dwelling where ye cannot obtain sustenance: or remain not on the frontiers,
having your households with you. (TA.) ― -b2- lavRa, [aor.
laviva
,] inf. n. lavRN; (K;) and AlvR↓, inf. n. UilovaAvN; (S, K;) and lavolava↓, inf. n. lavolavapN; (K;) It (rain) continued (S, K) for days, incessantly: (S:) and in like manner a cloud. (TA.) ― -b3- lavRa AlXRajara, [aor.
lavuva
,] It (dew, or day-dew, lavRN,) fell upon the trees. (K.) The noun is in the acc. case. (TA.) ― -b4- lavRa Ealayohi, [aor.
laviva
,] inf. n. lavRN; (K;) and Elyh AlvR↓, inf. n. UilovaAvN; (AA, S, K;) and lavolava↓, inf. n. lavolavapN; (K;) He importuned him; was urgent with him. (AA, S, K.)

4 Oalovava
4: see 1, in three places.

R. Q. 1
R. Q. 1: See 1. ＝ -A2- lavolava, inf. n. lavolavapN, He, or it, was weak. (K.) ― -b2- lavolava and talavolava↓ It (a mist, and a cloud,) went to and fro, coming again whenever it was thought to have gone. (TA.) ― -b3- lavolava fiI AlOamori, (inf. n. lavolavapN; K;) and talavolava↓, He wavered, or vacillated, (taradRada), in the affair. (A'Obeyd, S, K.) ― -b4- lavolava, inf. n. lavolavapN, He did not make [his] speech clear, or distinct: (K:) you say lavolava kalaAmahu He did not make his speech clear, or distinct. (TA.) ― -b5- lavolavahu Eano HaAjatihi, (S,) inf. n. lavolavapN, (K,) He withheld him, restrained him, or debarred him, from the thing that he wanted. (S, K.) ― -b6- lavolava, inf. n. lavolavapN, He rolled a thing over in the dust. (K.) ＝ -A3- lavolavotu AlbaEiyra [signifies, accord. to the CK and a MS copy of the K, kadadotuhu: accord. to the TA, ladadotuhu: but the right reading is said in the TK to be karadotuhu, meaning I drove the camel]. ＝ -A4- lavolivuwA binaA (or lvlvwA bnA saAEapF, T, art. mv, and TA,) Grant ye to us a little rest; expl. by rawRiHuwA binaA qaliylFA: (K:) i. q. mavomivuwA and vamovimuwA and jafojifuwA. (T, art. mv.)

R. Q. 2 talavolava biAlmakaAni c
R. Q. 2. talavolava biAlmakaAni He became withholden (taHabRasa) in the place, and tarried, or remained, in it. (TA.) ― -b2- talavolava fiI Oamorihi He was slow, or tardy, in his affair. (TA.) ― -b3- See R. Q. 1. ― -b4- talavolava He rolled himself over in the dust. (A'Obeyd, S, K.)

lavRN c
lavRN Dew; or day-dew; syn. nadFI. (K.)

lavolaAvN c
lavolaAvN (so in the K, but in the L and other lexicons lavolavN, TA,) and lavolaAvapN↓ One who is slow, or tardy, (in every affair, TA,) drawing back whenever thou thinkest that he hath consented to do what thou wantest. (K.)

lavolaAvapN c
lavolaAvapN: see lavolaAvN.

saHaAbN mulivRu AlEazaAlaI c
saHaAbN mulivRu AlEazaAlaI [Clouds continuing to pour down rain]. (TA.)

1 lavaOa c
1. lavaOa, aor.
lavaAa
, He (a dog) put his muzzle into a vessel &c., and lapped. (K.) Omitted by J because held by him incorrect. (TA.)
