superEntry.entry:
1 lajRa c
1. lajRa, sec. pers. lajijota, aor.
lajaja
, inf. n. lajaAjN and lajaAjapN (S, K) and lajajN; (M, A:) and lajRa, sec. pers. lajajota, aor.
lajija
; (S, K;) He persisted, or persevered, fiI OamorK in an affair: (Msb:) or he persisted in an affair, and refused to turn from it: (M:) or he persisted obstinately in an affair, even if it became manifest that it was wrong: (the Towsheeh:) or he persevered, or continued, in opposition, in contention, litigation, or wrangling: (TA:) or he persisted in contention, litigation, or wrangling; (Msb, TA;) and so lAjR↓, inf. n. mulaAjRapN: (S:) or he contended, litigated, or wrangled. (K.) [Hence, lajRa faHajRa, a prov.: see art. Hj.] See also, for an ex., 8 in art. Ewd. ＝ -A2- See 4.

2 ljRj c
2. ljRj, (inf. n. talojiyjN, K,) It (a ship, S) entered the lujRap [or main sea, or the fathomless deep, or the great expanse of sea of which the limits could not be seen]. (S, K.) ― -b2- lajRuwA [perhaps a mistake for OalajRuwA] They entered the lujR [or main sea, &c.]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- OalajRuwA↓ and lajRajuwA They embarked upon the ljp [or main sea, &c.]. (TA.)

3 laAojaja
3: see 1. ― -b2- laAjRati AlOalosunu fiI AlxuSuwmaAti (S, art. mrs,) or talaAjRat↓ (M, same art.,) [The tongues persisted in wranglings, quarrellings, or contentions]. ― -b3- And laAjRa fulaAnFA [He wrangled, quarrelled, or contended, with such a one]. (AHeyth, K in art. grw.)

4 OalajRahu c
4. OalajRahu He continued him, or made him to persevere, or persist, in a thing: accord. to Lh.: for he explains yamudRuhumo in the Kur, ii., 14, by yulijRuhumo: but ISd doubts whether he had heard this from the Arabs: and adds, that he, himself, had not heard Oalojajotuhu. (L.) ＝ -A2- AljR Alqawomu The people cried out; raised a cry. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, and Alqawomu ljR↓, The people uttered confused cries. (TA.) ― -b3- AljRt AlUibilu The camels uttered cries: (K:) and in like manner Alganamu, the sheep or goats. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See 2.

5 tljRj fiI Sadorihi c
5. tljRj fiI Sadorihi It (a thing) fluctuated in his bosom, or came and went repeatedly. (Msb.)

6 talaAojaja
6: see 3. ― -b2- talaAjRN The wrangling, quarrelling, or contending, one with another. (KL.) You say, talaAjRaA [They wrangled, &c., each with the other.] (M in art. Xq.)

8 AltjR Almawoju c
8. AltjR Almawoju The waves became great and confused. (TA.) ― -b2- AltRj AlbaHoru, inf. n. UilotijaAjN, (S,) The sea became tumultuous, its waves dashing together: (TA:) the main part, or fathomless deep, of the sea became vast, and very tumultuous. (A.) ― -b3- AltjRt AlOaSowaAtu The voices, or sounds, were confused: (S, K:) or, rose high, and were confused. (L.) ― -b4- AltjR AlZRalaAmu (tropical:) The darkness became intricate and confused. (TA.) ― -b5- AltRj AlOamoru (assumed tropical:) The affair became great and confused. (TA.) ― -b6- UicaA AltjR AldRayaAmiymu, in a verse of Dhu-rRummeh, (tropical:) When the wide deserts become scenes of mirage like lujR [or great expanses of sea of which the extremities cannot be seen]. (AHát.) ＝ -A2- UinRahu laXadiydu QlotijaAji AlEayoni Verily he has an intensely black eye. (L.)

R. Q. 1 lajolaja c
R. Q. 1. lajolaja inf. n. lajolajapN, He spoke with an indistinct utterance: he spoke with a heavy tongue, and was defective in speech, not uttering one part of what he said immediately after another; he hesitated in speech, by reason of a natural defect: (Lth:) or he reiterated, or stammered, or stuttered, (taradRada) in his speech; as also talajolaja↓. (S, K.) ― -b2- lajolaja AlmuDogapa fiI fimihi He moved the morsel of meat backwards and forwards in his mouth, to chew it. (S.)

R. Q. 2
R. Q. 2: see R. Q. 1.

lujRN c
lujRN The side of a valley. (K.) ― -b2- The side, or shore, of a sea. (L.) [See also lujRapN.] ― -b3- A rugged part of a mountain. (K.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A sword: (S, K:) app. from lujRN with reference to the sea, because of its terribleness: (As:) thought by ISd to occur only in one instance, in a trad.: said to be of the dial. of Teiyi; or of Hudheyl, and of some of the people of El-Yemen. (TA.) ― -b5- Also lujRapN, (tropical:) A mirror. (K.) ― -b6- And (tropical:) Silver. (K.)

lajRapN c
lajRapN Voices, cries, clamour, confused noise, or a mixture of voices, (S, K,) of men, (S,) and sometimes of camels. (TA.)

lujRapN c
lujRapN and lujRN↓ The main body of water, (S, K,) or of the sea: [the deep:] or the depth, or deep, of the sea, of which the bottom cannot be reached; the fathomless deep: (L:) also, lujRapN (TA) and baHorK lujRu↓ (L) a great expanse of water, or sea, of which the extremities cannot be seen: (L, TA:) pl. lujRN and lujajN and lijaAjN; the last pl. of lujRapN. (TA.) ― -b2- fulaAnN lujRapN waAsiEapN (tropical:) [Such a one is a wide fathomless deep]: a phrase by which one is likened to a sea, in amplitude. (TA.) ― -b3- kaOanRa
Eayonahu lujRapN (assumed tropical:) [As though his eye were a fathomless sea]: i. e., intensely black. (L.) ― -b4- AlZRuEonu tasobaHu AlsRaraAbi fiI lujRi↓ (tropical:) The women in the camel-litters swim in the great expanse of mirage. (TA.) ― -b5- lujRapu AlZRalaAmi (tropical:) The depth of the darkness. (TA.) ― -b6- AllRayoli lujRu↓ (assumed tropical:) The depth of night; its intense darkness and blackness. (TA.) ― -b7- jamalu Oadohamu lujRN (assumed tropical:) A deep black, or intensely black, camel. (K.) ― -b8- lujRapN and lujRN↓ (tropical:) A numerous assembly, company, troop, or congregated body: (K:) from lujRapN with reference to the sea. (TA.) ― -b9- lujRapN OamorK (assumed tropical:) The main part of an affair. (TA.)

lujajapN c
lujajapN: see lajuwjN.

baHorN lujRiIRN c
baHorN lujRiIRN, (S, K,) and lijRiIRN↓, (K,) and lujaAjN↓, (L,) A vast and deep sea. (S, L, K.) In lijiIRN↓, the first vowel is assimilated to the second to make the word more easy of pronunciation. (TA.)

lijiIRN c
lijiIRN: see lujiIRN.

lujaAjN c
lujaAjN: see lujiIRN.

lajuwjN c
lajuwjN and lajuwjapN↓ (in which the p is added to give [double] intensiveness to the signification, S) and lujajapN↓ (S, K) and milojaAjN↓, (L, A,) [intensive] epithets from lajRa “ he persisted, &c. ” [One who persists in an affair much: or who does so refusing to turn from it: or who does so even if it have become manifest that it is wrong: or who perseveres, or continues, much, in opposition, in contention, or the like: or who persists much, or is very pertinacious, in contention, or the like: or very contentious or litigious, or a great wrangler]. (S, M, K, &c.) The first is a masc. and fem. epithet: and is applied to a human being and to a horse. (TA.)

lajuwjapN c
lajuwjapN: see lajuwjN.

AlHaqRu Oabolaju waAlbaATilu lajolajN c
AlHaqRu Oabolaju waAlbaATilu lajolajN (AZ, S) [Truth is apparent, manifest, or evident, or clear, and falsity is a cause of embarrassment, or hesitation, to the speaker]: i. e., the latter is agitated to and fro, without having utterance: (S:) or truth is lucid and direct, and falsity is confused and indirect. (TA.)

lajolajapN c
lajolajapN A mixture, or confusion, of voices or sounds. (L.)

lajolaAjN c
lajolaAjN One who speaks with an indistinct utterance: (TA:) or who has naturally a heavy tongue and a defective speech, (T,) so that he does not utter one part of what he says immediately after another, who has a natural hesitation in his speech: or who reiterates, or stammers, or stutters, (ytrdRd,) in his speech: or, as some say, whose tongue rolls about between the sides of his mouth. (TA.)

milojaAjN c
milojaAjN: see lajuwjN.

EayonN mulotajRapN c
EayonN mulotajRapN (tropical:) An eye intensely black. (K.) ― -b2- OaroDN mulotajRapN (tropical:) Land intensely green, (K,) whether its herbage be tangled or not: or land of which the herbage is compact and tall and abundant. (TA.) ― -b3- OaroDN baqoluhaA mulotajRN Land of which the leguminous plants are compact, or dense. (TA.)

yalanojuwjN c
yalanojuwjN and yalanojajN and OalanojajN, (S, L,) or yalanojuwju and yalanojaju and Oalanojaju, [all three imperfectly declinable, as being generic proper names and of foreign origin, borrowed from the Persian language,] and OalanojuwjN and yalanojajN and yalanojuwjN [which last is omitted in the CK] and yalanojuwjiIRN (K) and OalanojajN and OalanojiyjN, (TA,) Aloes-wood; syn. Euwdu AlTRiybi, (L,) or Euwdu Albaxuwri: (K:) or the wood of another tree with which one fumigates: (L:) a certain wood with which one fumigates. (S.) The A and I in Alnjj and ylnjj [&c.] are augmentative letters added to make these words quasi-coordinate to the class of quinqueliteral-radical words: an augmentative letter is not used for such a purpose at the beginning of a word unless there is also with it another augmentative letter: and such, here, is the n. (IJ.) Lh uses ylnjwj and Alnjwj and Alnjyj as epithets, writing EuwdN ylnjwj &c. (TA.) The wood thus called has a very beneficial effect upon a relaxed stomach, (K,) when eaten; and of the beneficial effects for which it is most celebrated are those which it produces upon the brain and the heart, when used for fumigation and when eaten. (TA.)

1 lajaOa Uilayohi c
1. lajaOa Uilayohi, aor.
lajaAa
, (S, K,) inf. n. lajoCN (TA) or lajaON (S) and lujuwoCN (TA) and malojaON; (S;) and lajiYR, aor.
lajaAa
, (K,) inf. n. lajaON; (TA;) and AltjO↓; (S, K;) He had recourse to it, or betook himself to it, or repaired to it, (i. e. a thing or a place, TA) for refuge, protection, preservation, concealment, covert, or lodging. (K.) See 4. ― -b2- lajaOa Uilayohi, and AltjO↓, and tljRO↓, He relied upon, and sought aid from, him. (TA.) ― -b3- lajaOa Eanohu, and AltjO↓, and tljRO↓, and tljO minohu, He declined, or turned away, from him, UilaI gayorihi to another, [and had recourse to the latter.] (TA.)

2 ljRO c
2. ljRO, inf. n. talojiYapN, He forced a person to do a thing against his will: (S, K:) or, to do a thing which was contrary to what it appeared to be. (AHeyth.) ― -b2- talojiYapN is also explained as signifying The leaving one's property to some one or more of his heirs, in preference to, or to the exclusion of, the other or others. ljRO He so left his property. (ISh.) ― -b3- See 4.

4 AljOh UilI XaIoCK c
4. AljOh UilI XaIoCK He constrained, compelled, forced, drove, or necessitated, him to have recourse to, or to betake himself to, or to repair to, or to do, a thing; he impelled him, or drove him, against his will, to it, or to do it; (S, * Mgh, Msb, K, * TA;) as also Uilayohi ljRAhu↓. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- AljO Oamorahu UilaI AllRehi, (S, K,) and [UilaI AllRehi] lajaOa↓, and AltjO↓, and tljRO↓ (TA,) He referred, or committed, his affair to God. (S, K.) ― -b3- AljOh He protected him, defended him. (K.) Also said of a place, [It protected him; afforded him refuge.] (K, art. Hrz.) ― -b4- AljOh UilaI XaIoCK is also said when one has defended another, [as] in a place of refuge; [and app. may be rendered He caused him to have recourse to a thing, as to a place of refuge]. (TA.)

5 talajRaAa
5: see 1 and 4.

8 UilotajaAa
8: see 1 and 4.

lajaON c
lajaON and malojaON↓ (S, K) and mulotajaON↓ (K, art. lHd; &c.) A place to which one has recourse for refuge, protection, preservation, concealment, covert, or lodging; a place of refuge; an asylum; a refuge. (S, K.) The hemzeh of the ↓second is sometimes elided; and this is done to assimilate the word to manojaA, when it is used therewith; like as mnjA is written with hemzeh to assimilate it in the like case to malojaON. ― -b2-
[mljON↓ is often applied to a man: and you say also,] fulaAnN Hasanu AlmalojaUi↓ [Such a one is a good person to whom to have recourse for protection or concealment]. The pl. of lajaON is OalojaMCN. (TA.) ― -b3- lajaON (assumed tropical:) A wife. (L.) ― -b4- An heir. (ISh.) [See 2.] ＝ -A2- The frog: (K:) or a kind of tortoise, that lives on the land and in the sea: (M:) fem. with p. (K.) The ljOp of the sea (AllRajaOapu AlbaHoriyRapu) is asserted to have a tongue in its breast, and to kill the animal that it strikes. (Dmr.)

malojaON c
malojaON and mulotajaON: see lajaON.

1 lajiba c
1. lajiba, aor.
lajaba
, inf. n. lajabN, It [a number of men] cried out, or vociferated; raised a clamour, or confused noise. (S, K.) See also art. jlb. ― -b2- lajiba, inf. n. lajabN, It (a clamour, or confused noise,) rose. (TA.) ― -b3- lajiba, inf. n. lajabN, It (the sea) was agitated, or in commotion; its waves conflicting, or dashing together. (K.) ＝ -A2- lajubato, aor.
lajuba
, (inf. n. lujuwbapN, TA;) and ljRbt↓, inf. n. talojiybN; She (a sheep or goat) had little milk; (S, K:) or her milk dried up, in consequence of her having passed four months since bringing forth. (S.) See lajobapN. ＝ -A3- In a trad. respecting Moses and the stone, occur the words, falajabahu valaAva lajabaAtK, which IAth says he cannot
explain, unless the right reading be falaHatahu vlAv laHataAtK [And he struck it three blows]. (TA.)

lajabN c
lajabN A crying, or vociferation; a clamour, or confused noise. (S, K.) The sound, or noise, of soldiers; and the neighing of horses. (TA.) Agitation, or commotion, of the waves of the sea. (K.) The rising of a clamour, or confused noise. (TA.) ― -b2- baHorN cuw lajabK A roaring, tumultuous, or boisterous, sea. (S.)

jayoXN lajibN c
jayoXN lajibN A clamourous, or noisy, army. (S, K.) ― -b2- In like manner this epithet is applied to thunder, and to a cloud or rain accompanied with thunder; in each case after the manner of a rel. n. (TA.)

lajobapN c
lajobapN and lujobapN↓ and lijobapN↓ (S, K) and lajabapN↓ [but see what is said respecting the last of the pls. mentioned below] and lajibapN↓ and lijabapN↓ (K) the last two from Th. (TA.) A sheep or goat (XAp, K), or a sheep only, not a goat, (ISk, S,) of which the milk has become little in quantity: (S, K:) or a sheep or goat (XAp) which has passed four months since her bringing forth, and of which the milk has in consequence dried up: (As, S:) or it is an epithet applied specially to a goat: (K:) a poet (Muhelhil, TA,) says,
Eajibato OabonaAWunaA mino fiEolinaA
Uico nabiyEu Alxayola biAlmiEozaI AllRijaAbo
[Our sons wondered at our action, in our selling horses for goats of which the milk had become little, or dried up]: (S:) and contr., abounding with milk: (K:) a poet applies the two epithets lajobap and HaAXikap to the same sheep or goat; but he may mean that her milk was little at one time, and abundant at another. (TA.) Pl. [of lajobapN] lijaAbN (S, K) and lajobaAtN (this being allowed by Mbr, agreeably with analogy, TA) and lajabaAtN (S, K): the last dev. with respect to rule; for by rule it should be lajobaAtN; unless it be originally a subst. used as an epithet, like as one says UimoraOapN kalobapN; or unless lajabapN↓ be a syn. of the sing. (S.) Sb says, that lajabaAtN is used as pl. because some of the Arabs used lajabapN↓ as sing. (TA.) ― -b2- AllRjb [app. AllRajabu, a quasi-pl. n.,], occurring in the following words of a trad., fayaboduw OamovaAlu Alljbi mina AlcRahabi, is said to be pl. of lajobapN: or it is AllRijabu, like as qiSaEN is pl. of qaSoEapN. (TA.) ＝ -A2- In a trad. respecting Ed-Dejjál, according to one reading, occur the words, bljbtI AlbAbi: but Aboo-Moosà says, that the right reading is with f [instead of the b, and with I before it: i. e. bilajiyfataI AlbAb: see art. ljf]. (TA.)

lujobapN c
lujobapN: see lajobapN.

lijobapN c
lijobapN: see lajobapN.

lajabapN c
lajabapN: see lajobapN.

lajibapN c
lajibapN: see lajobapN.

lajabapN c
lajabapN: see lajobapN.

milojaAbN c
milojaAbN An arrow feathered, but without the point: (K:) pl. malaAjiybu. (TA.) minojaAbN is the more common word; and the l appears to be substituted for the n. (ISd.)

lujoHN c
lujoHN A thing in the lower part of a well, and of a valley, like what is called a daHol: (S, K:) or, in the lower part of a well, and of a mountain, like a naqob: (L:) originally luHojN, from which it is formed by transposition: (T:) pl. OalojaAHN. (L.)

1 lajaca c
1. lajaca, (L, K,) aor.
lajuca
, (K,) inf. n. lajocN; (L, K;) and lajica, aor.
lajaca
; (K;) He ate (L, K) food. (L.) ― -b2- He (a beast) began to pasture. (L, K.) ― -b3- He (a beast) ate herbage: (L:) you say, when beasts have eaten herbage, lujica AlkalaOu: (S, L:) or ate it with the extremity of his tongue, (L, K,) it being such as did not allow him to take it with his teeth: (L:) accord. to As, lajacahu signifies i. q. lasRahu [he plucked it with the fore part of his mouth.] (S, L.) ― -b4- He licked: in this sense, the inf. n. is lajocN and lajacN: (K:) you say, lajica Alkalobu AlUinaMCa, inf. n. lajocN and lajacN, the dog licked the vessel (AHát, S, K) inside: (L:) [J says,] I have transcribed it from the Kitáb el-Abwáb, without having heard it: (S:) and lajica Alkalobu the dog put his tongue into a vessel and lapped; as also lajida and lajina. (AA, L.) ― -b5- He took little. (L, K.) ― -b6- He asked often after having been given once: (K:) lajacaniI, aor.
lajuca
, inf. n. lajocN, signifies he asked me, and did so much, after I had given him: (S:) or he asked me after he had asked me and I had given him: (AZ, L:) or he asked me, and did so much, after he had asked me and I had given him. (As, L.) ― -b7- He instigated; incited; excited. (K.)

lijaAcN c
lijaAcN Glue; syn. giraMCN [for which Freytag seems to have read UigoraMCN]. (K.)

daAbRapN milojaAcN c
daAbRapN milojaAcN A beast of carriage that takes the leguminous herbage with the fore part of its mouth, (K,) and the extremities of its teeth. (TA.)

nbotN majoluwcN c
nbotN majoluwcN A plant which the teeth cannot crop, by reason of its shortness, and which the camels therefore pluck with the fore part of the mouth. (L.)

1 laHiHato Eayonuhu c
1. laHiHato Eayonuhu, (S, L, K,) aor. taloHaHu, inf. n. laHaHN; (L;) and laHRato; (L;) [as also laxixato:] His eyelids stuck together, by reason of a white thick matter collected in their corners: (S, L, K:) or, by reason of pain: or, by reason of many tears: (L:) the former is one of those verbs which retain their original forms, like Dabiba in the phrase Dabiba Albaladu, with the reduplication distinct: (S:) also, laHRato Eayonuhu his eye shed many tears, and its lids became thick, or rough; like laxRato. (L.) ― -b2- laHRati AlqaraAbapu bayonanaA, inf. n. laHRN, The relationship between us was close. (Aboo-Sa'eed, K.) See laHRN.

4 AlHR c
4. AlHR, (inf. n. UiloHaAHN, Msb,) It [a cloud) rained continually, or incessantly. (S, Msb, K) Hence the phrase AlHR ElI XI [q. v. infra]. (Msb) ― -b2- AlHR Ealoyhi, (inf. n. UiloHaAHN, L,) He importuned him; plied him; plied him hard; pressed him; pressed upon him; pressed him hard; was urgent with him; persecuted, or harassed, him, (L,) biQlomasoOalapi, (S, L,) or fiI AlsRaWaAli, (K,) in asking, begging, or petitioning; like OaloHafa. (S, L, K.) AlHR ElI gariymihi He pressed his creditor perseveringly, assiduously, or constantly. (L.) And OaloHaHotu EalaI fulaAnK fiI AlAitRibaAEi HatRaI Qxotalafotuh, i. e. [I pressed upon such a one in following] until I made him to be behind me. (ISk, TA in art. xlf.) AlHR EalaI XaIoCK [and fiI XaIoCK] He applied himself to a thing perseveringly, persistently, assiduously, or constantly, (Msb,) or incessantly. (L.) AlHR fiI XaIoCK He asked, begged, or petitioned, for a thing much, or frequently; as though he stuck to it. (L.) AlHR EalaI gayRihi [and fI gayRihi He persevered, or persisted, in his error]. (Msb, art. mdI.) ― -b3- It (a cloud) remained, or stayed, bimakaAnK in a place; like OalavRa. (As, S.) ― -b4- AlHR (tropical:) He (a camel) was restive, or refractory, and would not move from his place; (S, L, K;) like as you say of a she-camel xalaOato, (As, S,) and of a horse and the like Hazana: (As:) and AlHRt she (a camel) did the same; (L, K;) accord. to some, and so used in a trad. (TA.) ― -b5- AlHRti AlmaTiIRu (tropical:) The beasts of carriage, or the
camels, were fatigued, and became slow, or tardy. (K.) ― -b6- AlHR (tropical:) It (a saddle of the kind called qatab, L, K, and a raHol, and a horse's saddle, L) wounded the back. (L, K.) See miloHaAHN.

R. Q. 1 laHolaHuwA c
R. Q. 1. laHolaHuwA, (K,) and talaHolaHuwA↓, (S, K,) They remained fixed, or firm, in their place; did not quit it. (S, K.) ― -b2- talaHolaHa↓ He (a camel) stayed, and remained fixed, or firm. (L.) ― -b3- Also tlHlHwA↓ They became dispersed; formed by transposition from tHlHlwA. (L.)

R. Q. 2
R. Q. 2: See R. Q. 1.

huwa Qbonu EamRiI laHRFA c
huwa Qbonu EamRiI laHRFA [He is my cousin on the father's side,] closely related: (S, K:) from the phrase laHiHato Eayonuhu. (S.) Here lHRA is put in the acc. case as a denotative of state, because what precedes it is determinate. (S.) And you say huwa Qbonu EamRK laHRK [He is a cousin on the father's side,] closely related, (S, K,) in an indeterminate phrase employing laHRK as an epithet to EamRK. (S.) You say the same in the case of the fem. and dual and pl.; (S;) making no difference between the sing. and dual and pl. and fem. (L.) Lh says, that one says, [of two persons who are cousins, one to the other,] humaA QbonaA EamRK laHRK, and laHRFA; and in like manner hmA AbnA xaAlapK; but not hmA AbnA xaAlK laHRFA, nor AbnA EamRapK laHRFA. (L.) When the Abn EmR is not in the state termed laHR, but is of the EaXiyrap, you say huwa Qbonu EamRi AlkalaAlapi, and Abnu EamRK kalaAlapN. (S, K.) [See also dinoyFA; and the contr., ZohrFA.]

laHiHN c
laHiHN and laHolaHN: see laAHRN.

laAHRN c
laAHRN (S, K) and laHiHN↓ and laHolaHN↓ (K) A strait, or confined, place. (S, K.) Also, laAHRN, A valley with tangled, confused, intertwined, or complicated, trees, which stick together: or strait, or confined, and abounding with tangled trees, and stones. In both senses, applied to a place and a valley, it is also written laAxRN, with x. (L.) [See laAxRN.]

OalaHRu c
OalaHRu [More, and most, importunate, pressing, persevering, &c.]. (TA, art. xnfs; see the same article in the present work.)

muliHRN c
muliHRN That stands still by reason of fatigue, and will not move from its place. (TA.) ― -b2- A beast of carriage which, when it lies down, remains immovable, and will not be roused up. (L.)

miloHaAHN c
miloHaAHN A cloud continually, or incessantly, raining. (L.) ― -b2- A man [very] importunate, pressing, persevering, assiduous, or constant, in asking, begging, petitioning, or seeking. (L.) ― -b3- raHFI miloHaAHN EalaI maA taToHanuhu (S) A mill-stone that presses hard upon that which it grinds. (A.) ― -b4- miloHaAHN (tropical:) A saddle of the kind called qatab that wounds the back; (K;) that wounds the camel's withers; (S;) that sticks close to the camel's back, and wounds it; and in like manner a saddle of the kind called raHol, and a horse's saddle. (L.) ― -b5- Whatever is slow, or tardy. (L.)

1 laHaba c
1. laHaba, aor.
laHaba
, (S, K,) inf. n. laHobN; (S;) and AltHb↓; (K;) He trod, and passed along, a road, such as is termed laHobN, (S, K,) or simply, a road. (TA.) So also AltHm. Lth.) ＝ -A2- laHabahu and lHRbh↓ He smote him with a sword: (K:) or wounded him with it. (Th.) ― -b2- laHabahu and lHRbh↓ He made a mark, or impression, upon it. (K.) ― -b3- He flogged him with whips, and made marks, or scars, upon him. (TA.) ― -b4- laHabahu, (inf. n. laHobN, TA,) He cut it (i. e. flesh-meat) lengthwise. (K.) ― -b5- laHaba (inf. n. laHobN, TA,) He stripped off meat from the bone. (S, K.) ― -b6- He (a butcher) took what was on the back of the slaughtered camel. (TA.) ― -b7- He peeled a stick or the like, (S,) or anything. (TA.) ― -b8- It (the portion next the back-bone, on either side, of a horse, (K,) or his rump, TA) was smooth, and sloping downwards: syn. UimolaOasRa fiI HuduwrK. (K.) ― -b9- laHaba, aor.
laHaba
, inf. n. luHuwbN, It (a road) became conspicuous, clear, or open: (K:) as though it peeled [the surface of] the ground. (TA.) ― -b10- laHaba, inf. n. laHobN, He made a road conspicuous, or clear. (K, TA.) So in the saying of Umm-Selmeh to 'Othmán, laA tuEafRi TariyqFA kaAna rasuwlu AllRehi SlEm laHabahaA Do not thou efface a road which the Apostle of God, &c., made conspicuous, or clear. (TA.) ＝ -A3- laHaba (inf. n. laHobN, TA,) (assumed tropical:) Inivit feminam. (K.) See laxaba. ― -b2- laHaba bih AlOaroDa He threw him down prostrate upon the ground. (K.) ― -b3- laHaba, (inf. n. laHobN, TA,) He (a man) passed, or went along, through the land: (TA:) or he went right on, or straight on: (S, K:) or he hastened in his pace; went quickly. (K.) ＝ -A4- laHiba, aor.
laHaba
, [inf. n. laHabN,] He (a man) became emaciated by reason of old age, (S, K,) and weakness. (TA.)

2 laHRaba
2: see 1.

8 UilotaHaba
8: see 1.

laHobN c
laHobN and laAHibN↓ (S, K: the latter word of the measure faAEilN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: i. e. maloHuwbN: S) and mulaHRabN↓ (K) A conspicuous road: (S, K:) a wide, extended, road, that is not interrupted. (TA.)

laHiybN c
laHiybN A she-camel having little flesh in her back: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) originally, it seems, in the sense of maloHuwb, as though meaning “ peeled ” by travel; and afterwards, its original attributive character being forgotten among a people, used without p [when not preceded by the noun which it qualifies, as when preceded by that noun]. (TA.)

laAHibN c
laAHibN: see laHobN.

miloHabN c
miloHabN Anything with which a thing is cut or peeled: (S, K:) cutting, or sharp, iron. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A great reviler, or vilifier, of obscene tongue. (S, K.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A chaste, or an eloquent, tongue. (T.)

maloHuwbN c
maloHuwbN Smooth, and sloping downwards: an epithet applied to the portion next the back-bone, on either side, [or to the rump,] of a horse. (TA.) [See an ex. voce quSobN.] ― -b2- A man of little flesh; emaciated: as though peeled. (TA.)

mulaHRabN c
mulaHRabN Cut in pieces: syn. muqaTRaEN. (S.) ― -b2- See laHobN.

1 laHata c
1. laHata, aor.
laHata
, (inf. n. laHotN, TA,) He beat, struck, or smote, a person with a staff, or stick. (K.) ＝ -A2- laHata, aor.
laHata
, (inf. n. laHotN, TA,) He peeled, or unbarked, a staff, or stick: (K:) or sawed it, and peeled, or unbarked it: as also naHata. (IAar.) ― -b2- hecaA rajulN laA yaDiyruka Ealayohi naHotFA walaHotFA expl. by mA yzydk Elyh nHtA AllXEr wlHtA lh (tropical:) [This is a man than whom none will be more useful to thee in the trimming of verses: yDyrk, which is written without the syll. points, is probably a mistake for yaDurRuka: see art. Dr]. (IAar.) ― -b3- laHatahu biAlEacoli, aor.
laHata
, inf. n. laHotN, [He trimmed him with reproof]: a phrase similar to that immediately preceding. (TA, app. from IAar.) ― -b4- laHatahu, aor.
laHata
, inf. n. laHotN, (assumed tropical:) He took what he had, leaving him nothing; as also lataHahu. (TA.) ＝ -A3- laHata Inivit puellam: as also naHata, but this latter is not so well known. (TA, art. nHt.)

barodN baHotN laHotN c
barodN baHotN laHotN i. q. SaAdiqN; (Sgh, K;) [i.e., Vehement, or intense, cold: see baHotN: and see also laxotN]. laHotN is here a mere imitative sequent. (TA.)

1 laHija c
1. laHija aor.
laHaja
, (inf. n. laHajN, S,) It (a sword, S, K, or other thing, S) stuck fast in the scabbard, (S, K,) and would not come forth; like laSiba. (S.) ― -b2- laHija AlxaAtamu fiI AlUiSobaEi The sealring stuck fast upon his finger. (A.) ― -b3- laHija bayonahumu AlXRarRu Evil stuck fast between, or among, them. (TA.) ― -b4- laHija bimakaAnK He clave fast to a place; kept fast, or close, to it. (TA.) ― -b5- laHija fiI AlOamori
He entered into an affair and became entangled in it so that he could not extricate himself. (TA.) ― -b6- laHaja Uilayohi, aor.
laHaja
, inf. n. laHojN; and AltHj↓; He inclined to him, or it. (TA.) By the following words of Ru-beh,
Oawo taloHaju AlOalosunu minRaA maloHajaA
is meant, Or tongues speak of us, and incline from what is good to that which is bad. (L.) [For mnhA, in the L, I have substituted mnRA. mlHj seems to be an inf. n.] ― -b7- laHaja Uilayohi, [and AltHj↓, Golius, from Ibn-Maaroof,] He had recourse to him or it for protection or concealment. (K.) ― -b8- laHija It (a thing) became strait, narrow, or confined. (TA.)

2 lHRj Ealayohi Alxabara c
2. lHRj Ealayohi Alxabara, inf. n. taloHiyjN; and Ealayohi laHowajahu↓, inf. n. laHowajapN; He rendered the news, or information, confused to him, and told him something different from that which was in his mind: (S, K:) or the phrase with the former verb signifies he told him news, or a piece of information, different * from that which was in his mind; and that with the latter verb, he rendered the news, or information, confused to him. (Az.) See 5.

4 AlHjhu Uilayohi c
4. AlHjhu Uilayohi, He caused him to incline to him, or it. (TA.) ― -b2- AlHjhu Uilayohi, (K,) and AltHjhu↓, (S, K,) He constrained, compelled, or necessitated, him to have recourse to, or to do, it, (S, K.)

5 tlHRj Ealayohi AlOamora c
5. tlHRj Ealayohi AlOamora, and Elyh laHowajahu↓, He represented the affair to him not as it was in his mind. (L.) See 2.

8 UilotaHaja
8: see 1 and 4.

10 UisotaloHaja
10: AstlHj AlbaAba [app. He found the door stuck fast]: (A:) [but I think it not improbable that the right reading is AlbaAbu; and the meaning, the door stuck fast].

Q. Q. 1 laHowaja c
Q. Q. 1. laHowaja: see 2 and 5.

luHojN c
luHojN: see lujoHN.

laHijN c
laHijN A strait, narrow, or confined, place. (S, K.)

maloHajN c
maloHajN (K) and mulotaHajN↓ (As, S, K) A place to which one has recourse for protection or concealment; a place of refuge; an asylum. (As, S, K.) ― -b2- malaAHiju Strait, narrow, or confined, places. (S, K.) ― -b3- malaAHiyju Narrow roads in mountains. (TA.)

xuTRapN maloHuwjapN c
xuTRapN maloHuwjapN A confused and crooked business. (L.)

qufolN mulaHRajN c
qufolN mulaHRajN A lock that is not [or, app., that cannot be] opened. (A.)

mulotaHajN c
mulotaHajN see maloHajN.

1 laHada c
1. laHada (A) and AlHd↓ (L, K) (tropical:) He, or it, (as an arrow, A) declined, or deviated, from the right course: (A, L, K:) and also he, or it, inclined: you say laHada Uilayohi, (A, L, K,) aor.
laHada
; (L;) and AlHd↓ (A;) and AltHd↓; (S, L, K;) he, or it, inclined to him, or it. (A, L, K.) Some read, [in the Kur xvi. 105,] lisaAnu QlRaciI yaloHaduwna Uilayohi (tropical:) [The tongue of him unto whom they incline]. (S.) ― -b2- fiI AldRiyni AlHd↓; (S, A, L, Msb;) and laHada fiyhi, (S, L, Msb,) aor.
laHada
; (L;) (tropical:) He deviated, or swerved, from the right way, with respect to religion: (S, A, L:) he impugned religion. (Msb.) ― -b3- fiI AlHarami AlHd↓ (tropical:) He relinquished, or forsook, the right course, with respect to that which he was commanded to do, in the sacred Temple or territory of Mekkeh; (L, K;) and inclined to do wrong, wrongfully, unjustly, or injuriously: (L:) or he did wrong, wrongfully, unjustly, or injuriously, therein; (S, L, K;) and so opposed others: (Fr, L:) or he associated others with God, therein; expl. by OaXoraka biAllRehi: so in the K and Basáïr; in the latter as on the authority of Zj: or he doubted respecting God, therein: so in the L and other lexicons, as on the authority of Zj: (TA:) or he hoarded up corn in expectation of its becoming dear, therein; (L, K;) a meaning taken from a trad of 'Omar; (L;) but this is merely a kind of wrong-doing: (TA:) or he desecrated it, and violated its sanctity. (Msb.) The origin of the phrase is in the text of the Kur [xx. 26,] wamano yurido fiyhi biUiloHaAdK biZulomK, i.e. UiloHaAdFA biZulomK, the b being redundant. (S, L.) ＝ -A2- laHada Alqabora, aor.
laHada
, (inf. n. laHodN; L,) and AlHdhu↓; (A, L, K;) and laHada lahu laHodFA; and lh AlHd↓; (S, Msb;) He made a laHod to the grave. (S, A, L, K.) ― -b2- laHada QlomayRita, aor.
laHada
, inf. n. laHodN; and AlHdhu↓; and laHada lahu; and lh AlHd↓; He made a laHod for the corpse: or AlHdhu↓ has this signification; (L;) and in like manner, laHada lah laHodFA, and AlHd↓, he dug a laHod for him: (A, Mgh, Msb:) and laHadahu, he buried him; (L, K;) or put him into a lHd; and so AlHdhu↓. (Mgh, Msb.)

3 lAHdhu c
3. lAHdhu (assumed tropical:) He behaved towards him in a crooked, or perverse, manner, the latter doing the same. (K, * TA.)

4 AlHd c
4. AlHd: see 1, throughout. ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) He disputed; altercated; wrangled. (A' Obeyd, L, Msb, K.) ― -b3- AlHd bihi (assumed tropical:) He brought a reproach upon him, or held him in light estimation, or despised him, (OazoraI bihi,) and said of him what was false: (K:) or he held his clemency, or forbearance, or intellect, (Hilom,) in light estimation; or despised it; as also Oalohada bihi. (L.)

8 AltHd Uilayohi c
8. AltHd Uilayohi (tropical:) He had recourse, or betook himself, to it, or him, for refuge, protection, concealment, covert, or lodging. (A.)

laHodN c
laHodN (S, A, L, Msb, K) and luHodN↓ (S, L, Msb, K) and laHadN↓ (El-Basáïr) and maloHuwdN↓, (A, L, K,) which last is an epithet wherein the quality of a subst. is predominant, (L,) A trench or an oblong excavation, in the side of a grave; a lateral hollow of a grave; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) which is the place of the corpse; what is called DariyHN and DariyHapN is in the middle: (L:) pl. (of the first, Msb) luHuwdN and (of the second, Msb) OaloHaAdN. (L, Msb, K.) Accord. to some, lHd used in this sense is tropical; from laHada and OaloHada signifying “ he inclined, or declined. ” (MF.) [The reverse, however, is the case accord. to the A.] [See an ex. in a verse cited voce XadiydN.]

luHodN c
luHodN and laHadN: see laHodN.

laAHidN c
laAHidN: see maloHuwdN.

muloHidN c
muloHidN act. part. n. of 4, q. v.: (tropical:) One who deviates, or swerves, from the truth, and introduces into it that which does not belong to it: (ISk, L:) an impugner of religion: (Msb in art. rndq;) pl. muloHiduwna (Msb) [and malaAHicapN]. Some apply the appellation of AlmuloHiduwna especially to the Bátinees (AlbaATiniyRap), who assert that the Kur-án has an outward sense and an inward, the latter differing from the former, and known to them; by which doctrine they have perverted the law. (Msb.)

muloHadN c
muloHadN: see maloHuwdN.

maloHuwdN c
maloHuwdN (A, K) and muloHadN↓, (S, A,) or maloHuwdN lahu and lahu muloHadN↓, (L,) and laAHidN↓, (K,) A grave having a laHod made to it. (S, A, L, K.) ― -b2- See laHodN.

mulotaHadN c
mulotaHadN (tropical:) A place to which one has recourse for refuge, protection, concealment, covert, or lodging: a place of refuge; an asylum: (S, Msb, K:) so called because one turns aside to it. (S.)

1 laHisahu c
1. laHisahu, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) or laHisahu bilisaAnihi, (A,) aor.
laHasa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. laHosN (S, A, Msb, K) and maloHasN (A K) and laHosapN and luHosapN, (Yaakoob, S, K,) the last mentioned by ISk, (TA,) He licked it; (S, A, K, TA;) namely, a bowl, (S, K,) and a vessel: (S:) AllRaHosu is with the tongue: (S, K:) or laHsahu
signifies he took what was upon it, (Mgh,) or what adhered to its sides, (Msb,) with his tongue or his finger; (Mgh, Msb;) the suffixed pronoun referring to a bowl (Mgh, Msb) or some other thing: (Mgh:) and he took it (a thing) with his tongue. (TA.) It is said in a proverb, OasoraEu mino laHosi Alkalobi Oanofahu [Quicker than the dog's licking his nose]. (S, A.) See also maloHasN, below. ― -b2- laHisa AldRuwdu AlSRuwfa, (A, Mgh, Msb,) in measure like labisa, (Mgh,) or laHasa, like manaEa, (K,) inf. n. laHosN, (Mgh, Msb, K,) The worms ate the wool: (Mgh, Msb, K:) and in like manner, lHs AljaraAdu AlxuDara (A, K) and AlXRajara, (TA,) the locusts ate the green plants (K) and the trees. (TA.)

4 AlHst AlOaroDu c
4. AlHst AlOaroDu (tropical:) The land produced plants, or herbage: (S:) or began to produce leguminous plants: (K:) or produced the first of the herbage, so that the beasts saw it and desired it and licked it, not being able to eat of it anything: (TA:) or produced what the beasts of carriage might lick or eat (maA taloHasuhu): (A, TA:) or [became in such a state that] the beasts of carriage licked or ate (laHasato) its plants, or herbage. (Sgh, K.) ＝ -A2- AlHs AlmaAXiyapa (tropical:) He pastured the camels or sheep or goats with the least pasturing. (K.)

8 AltHs minohu HaqRahu c
8. AltHs minohu HaqRahu (tropical:) He took from him his (the former's, A) right, or due. (A, K.)

laHosapN c
laHosapN: see 1. [Accord. to analogy, it is an inf. n. of un.]

luHosapN c
luHosapN [The quantity that one takes by one lick with the tongue. Hence the saying,] maA laka EinodiI luHosapN I have not anything for thee, or belonging to thee. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 1.

laHuwsN c
laHuwsN: see miloHasN.

laHowasN c
laHowasN: see miloHasN.

laHRaAsN c
laHRaAsN A man who licks much what comes to him. (TA.) ― -b2- laHRaAsapN A moth-worm, that eats wool; syn. EuvRapN. (TA.) ― -b3- A lioness. (K.)

sanapN laA HisapN c
sanapN laA HisapN (tropical:) A distressful, or calamitous, year; (K;) a year that consumes all the herbage: (A, TA:) and lawaAHisu, [the pl., sinuwnN, being understood,] distressful, or calamitous, years. (A, TA.)

laA HuwsN c
laA HuwsN: see miloHasN.

maloHasN c
maloHasN is a noun of place; [signifying A place of licking; &c.;] as well as an inf. n.: and in both cases it has malaAHisu for pl. (IJ.) You say, tarakotuhu bimalaA Hisi Albaqari, (S, A, K,) or bimalaAHisi Albaqari OawolaAdahaA, (TA,) meaning, (tropical:) I left him in the places where the wild cows lick their young ones (S, ISd, A, K) from the membranes in which they are born: (ISd, TA:) or in a desert place, (S,) or in a desert, or waterless desert, (ISd, A, TA,) so that it was not known where he was; (S;) because the wild cows bring forth only in the deserts: (ISd, TA:) the former is like the saying bimabaAHivi Albaqari; (S;) and is that which ISd holds to be the right: (TA:) in the latter, mlAHs is an inf. n., in the pl. form, which is strange; because it governs AwlAd in the accus. case; and a prefixed noun [mawaADiE] is understood before it: (IJ:) some relate the saying differently, thus, bimaloHasi Albaqari OawolaAdahaA, meaning, bimawoDiEi maloHasi Albaqari OawolaAdahaA [in the place of the cows' licking their young ones]; (K;) because [some hold that] an inf. n. of the measure mafoEalN has no pl. (TA.)

muloHisN c
muloHisN: see miloHasN.

miloHasN c
miloHasN (tropical:) Greedy; as also laHowas↓ (K) and laAHuwsN↓ and muloHisN↓: (TA:) and one who takes everything that he can. (K:) or a greedy man, who takes everything that he can: (A:) one who takes everything that appears to him: (TA:) [originally, a lick-dish:] and [in like manner] laHuwsN↓ (tropical:) a man who seeks after sweets, like the fly. (A, K.) ― -b2- Also, (assumed tropical:) Courageous: (K:) as though an eater of everything that rose up to him. (TA.)

2 lHRShu c
2. lHRShu see lxRShu.

1 laHaZahu c
1. laHaZahu, (S, K,) or laHaZahu biAlEayoni, (Msb,) and laHaZa Uilayohi, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
laHaZa
, inf. n. laHoZN (Msb, K) and laHaZaAnN, (K,) He looked at him from the outer angle of the eye, (S, Msb, K,) to the right or left, (Msb, TA,) with more turning of the face than is denoted by XazorN; (Msb, K;) or without turning the face: (TA:) or he watched him with the eye: (Msb:) and hence mulaAHaZapN↓, of the measure mufaAEalapN, (K, TA,) explained by Az as signifying a man's looking from the outer angle of either eye. (TA.)

3 lAHZhu c
3. lAHZhu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. mulaAHaZapN (Msb, K) and liHaAZN, (S, Msb,) [i. q. laHaZahu, q. v. ― -b2- And hence,] (tropical:) He regarded him; had regard, or an eye, to him; paid regard, or consideration, to him; he regarded it, [namely, an affair,] or attended to it; syn. raAEaAhu. (S, Msb, TA.) ― -b3- [And (assumed tropical:) He, or it, had a relation, or an analogy, to him, or it.]

6 tlAHZwA c
6. tlAHZwA (TA) They turned their eyes, [each looking from the outer angle of his eye,] one towards another. (K, L.) ― -b2- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) They regarded one another; had regard, or an eye, one to another; paid regard, or consideration, one to another. ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) They had a mutual relation, or analogy.]

laHoZN c
laHoZN: see laHaAZN.

laHoZapN c
laHoZapN A look from the outer angle of the eye; a sidelong glance; an ogle; a look from the side next the ear: pl. laHaZaAtN: the dim. is luHayoZapN. (TA.) Hence the saying jalasotu Einodahu laHoZapF I sat with him the like of [the time occupied by] a look from the outer angle of the eye. (TA.) And fiI laHoZapK [In the twinkling of an eye]. (K in art. srE; &c.)

laHaAZN c
laHaAZN, (S, Msb, K,) with fet-h, (S, Msb,) like saHaAbN, (K,) or liHaAZN↓, (T, IB, Mgh, Msb,) with kesr, (T, IB, Msb,) which latter is the form commonly known, (IB,) or the latter is incorrectly used for the former by some who twist the sides of the mouth in utterance, (MF,) or is [only] an inf. n. of laAxaZa, (S,) The outer angle of the eye, (T, S, Mgh, &c.,) next the part between the eye and the ear; (T, Mgh, Msb;) as also laHoZN↓: pl. of the former luHuZN: and of the latter OaloHaAZN. (TA.) You say, fatanatohu bilaHaAZihaA [She captivated his heart with the outer angle of her eye], and biOaloHaAZihaA [with the outer angles of her eyes]. (TA.)

liHaAZN c
liHaAZN: see laHaAZN.

laHiyZN c
laHiyZN (assumed tropical:) Like. (K.) You say, huwa laHiyZu fulaAnK. (assumed tropical:) He is the like of such a one. (TA.)

rajulN laHRaAZN c
rajulN laHRaAZN [A man who has a habit of looking from the outer angle of the eye]. (TA.)

maloHaZN c
maloHaZN syn. with [the inf. n.] laHoZN: or it signifies mawoDiEu laHoZK [i.e. the place at which one looks from the outer angle of the eye]: pl. malaAHiZu. (TA.)

maloHuwZN c
[maloHuwZN (assumed tropical:) Regarded; had in view.]

OaHowaAluhumo mutaXaAkilapN mutalaAHiZapN c
OaHowaAluhumo mutaXaAkilapN mutalaAHiZapN (tropical:) [Their states, or conditions, are similar; such as have mutual relation, or analogy]. (TA.)

1 laxRato Eayonuhu c
1. laxRato Eayonuhu, (S, L, K,) aor. talixRN, inf. n. laxRN and laxiyxN, (L,) His eye shed copious tears, (S, L, K,) and its lids became rough. (L.) ― -b2- laxixato Eayonuhu, as also laHiHato, His eyelids stuck together, by reason of a white thick matter collected in their corners. (L.) See lHR. ― -b3- laxRa fiI kalaAmihi, [aor., accord. to analogy,
laxixa
,] He was obscure and barbarous in his speech. (K.)

8 AltxR Ealayohimo Oamoruhumo c
8. AltxR Ealayohimo Oamoruhumo Their affair, or case, became confused, or perplexed, to them. (S, K. *) ― -b2- AltxR It (herbage) became tangled, or luxuriant. (S, K.)

laxRapN c
laxRapN Obscureness and barbarousness in speech. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A dirty, stinking, woman. (K.)

waAdK laAxRN c
waAdK laAxRN, (As, Ibn-Ma'een, K,) and laAHRN, (K,) or this is incorrect, (Ibn-Ma'een,) A valley having intricate defiles, or narrow passes: (K:) or, abounding with trees, and intricate; as also mulotaxRN↓: (L:) or, intricate by reason of its trees: (As:) or it is lAx, without teshdeed, [i. e. laAxN, or, as its derivation presently mentioned implies, laAxK,] (Sh, K,) from OaloxaI, distorted (L, K) [but in the former written AlxMC] in the mouth. (L.) ― -b2- jawofN lAxRN A deep valley. (IAar.)

laxolaxaAniIRN c
laxolaxaAniIRN, (S, K,) fem. with p, (L,) A man whose speech, or utterance, is characterized by what is termed laxolaxaAniyRap, or barbarousness, or vitiousness, &c.: (L:) not chaste in speech, or utterance. (S, K.)

laxolaxaAniyRapN c
laxolaxaAniyRapN A barbarousness, or vitiousness, in speech, or utterance; a want of chasteness therein; an - impotence, or impediment, or a difficulty, therein. (AO, S, L, K.) It is a quality of the dial. of the Arabs of the desert of Esh-Shahr and 'Omán; as when they say, for maA XaMCa QllRehu, maXaMCa QllRehu: (Eth-Tha'álibee:) or is derived from laxolaxaAnu, the name of a tribe: or, as some say, of a place. (L.) naZara fulaAnN naZara AllRaxaloxaAniyRapi Such a one looked with the look of barbarians, or foreigners; or, of those who are barbarous in speech. (As.)

sakoraAnu mulotaxRN c
sakoraAnu mulotaxRN, (S, K,) vulg. muloTaxRN, (S,) or mulaTRaxN, (as in some copies of the S and K,) but this should not be said, (K,) A drunken man confused in his intellect, (S, L,) and not understanding anything: (L:) or, full of drink; (K;) as also murotaxRN. (TA in art. rx.) ― -b2- See laAxRN.

1 laxaba c
1. laxaba He slapped a person; struck him with the open hand. (K.) ＝ -A2- laxaba, aor.
laxaba
and
laxuba
, (inf. n. laxobN, TA,) Inivit feminam: (Kr, K:) but the word commonly known, related by Yaakoob and others, is naxaba. (ISd.)

3 lAxbhu c
3. lAxbhu, inf. n. mulaAxabapN (and lixaAbN, TA), He slapped him, being also slapped by him. (K.)

laxabN c
laxabN The trees which produce what is called muqolN, q. v. (K.)

mulaxRabN c
mulaxRabN One who is slapped much, or violently, in altercations. (K.)

laxotN c
laxotN Great, or big, in body: (Lth, Sgh, and some copies of the K:) or great, or big, and corpulent. (So in the other copies of the K.) ― -b2- A woman in whom the division between the vagina and the rectum has been broken through; syn. mufuDaApN. (K.) ― -b3- HarRN saxotN laxotN Vehement, or intense, heat. (Lth, K.) [See also saxotN: and see laHotN.] Thought by ISd to be arabicized. (TA.)

2 laxRaSa
2: lxRShu, (A, TA,) inf. n. taloxiySN, (S, A, K,) He explained, expounded, or interpreted, it; (S, A, K;) he made it clear; (A, K;) namely, language: (A:) taloxiySN and taboyiynN and XaroHN and taxoliySN all signify the same: (A:) he went to the utmost point in explaining it, expounding it, interpreting it, and making it plain: namely, a thing; as also lHRShu. (TA.) You say, laxRiSo liI xabaraka Explain thou to me thy news, or information, thing after thing. (TA.) And it is said in a trad. of 'Alee, qaEada litaloxiySi maA Qlotabasa EalaI gayorihi He sat to make clear what was confused and dubious to others. (TA.) ― -b2- He made it near: [the inf. n. being explained in the TA by Altqryb; but I incline to think that this is a mistranscription, for AltREoriybu; and that the meaning is, he made it clear, plain, distinct, or perspicuous:] he abridged it: he restricted, or limited, himself in it, namely, a saying, and abridged of it what was needful. (TA.)

mulaxRaSN c
mulaxRaSN The sum or result or conclusion [of a thing]. (TA.)

superEntry.entry:
1 ladR c
1. ladR, originally ladida, (second pers. ladidota, L,) aor.
ladada
, (L, Msb,) inf. n. ladadN (S, A, L, Msb,) He was violent, or vehement, in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation. (S, A, L, Msb.) ― -b2- ladRahu, (S, L, Msb, K,) aor.
ladada
, (S, L, Msb,) inf. n. ladRN, (L, Msb,) He overcame him in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation: (S, * L, K: *) or he opposed him violently, or vehemently, in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation. (Msb.) ladidota, (in some copies of the K, ladadota,) inf. n. laddN, (IKtt, L: in the K, ladRN:) Thou becamest such as is called OaladR [violent, or vehement, in contention, &c.]. (IKtt, L, K.) ― -b3- ladRahu Eani AlOamori, (inf. n. ladRN, L,) He restrained, withheld, debarred, hindered, or prevented, him from doing the thing: (L, K: *) he made him to return or revert, or turned him back or away, with gentleness, from the thing, or affair; like radRahu: (T and L, art. rd:) of the dial. of Hudheyl. (L.) ＝ -A2- ladRahu, (K,) or ladRahu biAllRaduwdi, (M,) aor.
laduda
, (L,) inf. n. ladRN and luduwdN; (M, K;) and AldRhu↓; (S, L, K;) and ladRahu AllRaduwda; (M, L, K;) He administered to him the medicine, or draught, termed laduwd. (S, * M, L, K. *) The action termed AllRadRu is the taking a child's tongue, and drawing it to one side, and pouring medicine in the other side, between the tongue and the side of the mouth. (Fr, L.) ― -b2- ludRa He had a medicine, or draught, of the kind termed laduwd administered to him. (S, L, K.) See also 8. ― -b3- ladadotuhumu AlnRaSiyHapa (tropical:) I administered to them sincere, or faithful, advice, or counsel, like as one administers the medicine, or draught, termed laduwd. (L.)

2 ldRd bihi c
2. ldRd bihi i. q. ndRd bh, (L, K,) i. e., He rendered him notorious, or infamous. (L.)

3 lAdRhu c
3. lAdRhu, inf. n. lidaAdN (A, Msb) and mulaAdRapN, (A,) He contended with him violently, or vehemently, in an altercation; in a dispute; in a litigation. (A, Msb.) ― -b2- maA zilotu OulaAdRu Eanoka I ceased not to repel from thee; or, to defend thee. (S.)

4 AldRhu c
4. AldRhu He found him to be such as is called OaladR [violent, or vehement, in contention, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b2- AldR bihi He opposed him in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation. (TA.) See also 1 and 3.

5 tldRd c
5. tldRd (tropical:) He turned his face to the right and left, (S, L, K,) in confusion, perplexity, or amazement: (L, K:) from AllRadiydaAni signifying “ the two sides ” of the neck. (S, L.) ― -b2- He tarried, or waited, in expectation. (K, TA.)

8 AltdR c
8. AltdR, (S, L, K,) and AltdR laduwdFA, (S, L,) He swallowed a medicine, or draught, of the kind termed laduwd. (S, * L, * K.) See also ludRD. ＝ -A2- AltdR Eanohu He declined from him, or it. (K.)

ladRN c
ladRN: see laAdRN. ― -b2- A [sack of the kind called] juwaAliq: (S, L, K:) like labiydN. (TA.)

laduwdN c
laduwdN: see laAdRN. ＝ -A2- laduwdN and ladiydN↓ A medicine (or draught, As, L) that is poured into one of the two sides of the mouth (As, S, L, K) by means of the instrument called musoEuT: (L, K:) pl. OalidRapN: (S, L, K:) from AllRadiydaAni signifying “ the two sides ” of a valley. (S, L.) It is said in a proverb, jaraI minohu majoraI AllRaduwdi [It acted upon him, or affected him, like the medicine,
or draught, termed laduwd; i. e., unpleasantly, or disagreeably]. (ISk, S.) See Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 282

ladiydN c
ladiydN: see laduwdN. ＝ -A2- ladiydaAni The two sides of a valley: (S, A, L:) each of them is called ladiydN: (L:) and the two sides of the neck, (S, A, L, K,) below the ears: (L, K:) or the two lateral muscles of the neck: (M, L:) the two sides of the mouth: (A, L:) and of the penis: (L:) and (as some say, L) of anything: (L, K:) pl. OalidRapN: (S, L, K:) and ladiydN, accord. to AA, signifies the outside of the neck. (L.) ＝ -A3- See laAdRN.

laAdRN c
laAdRN and laduwdN↓, (S, L, Msb, K,) the latter having an intensive sense, and ladRN↓, which is an inf. n. used as an epithet [and therefore also intensive], (Msb,) A man who overcomes in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation: (S, * L, K: *) or, who opposes violently, or vehemently, and very violently, or vehemently, in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation: (Msb:) and OaladRu↓ (S, L, Msb, K) and OalanodadN↓ and yalanodadN↓ (S, L, K) a man violent, or vehement, in contention, or altercation; in dispute; in litigation: (S, L, Msb:) or difficult therein, and vehement in war: (IKtt:) or a contentious, disputatious, or litigious, (L,) and tenacious adversary, who will not incline to the truth: (L, K:) the fem. of OladRu↓ is ladRaMCu: (L, Msb:) and the pl, ludRN (S, L, Msb, K) and lidaAdN: (L, K:) the O in OalanodadN↓ and the I in yalanodadN↓ are letters of quasi-coördination, [i. e., added to render those two words quasi-coordinate to safarojalN,] as is shown by the two dáls being not incorporated by idghám; for it is allowable to add a letter at the beginning of a word for the purpose of quasi-coördination when the word has another augmentative letter: (IJ, L:) the dim. of OalnodadN↓ is OulayodRu↓, because it is originally OaladRu, the n being added to render it quasi-coördinate to safarojalN. (S, L.) qawomFA ludRFA in the Kur, [xix. 97,] is said to signify A people who are adversaries perverted from the truth: or, who are deaf to the truth. (L.) You say also, huwa XadiydN ladiydN [assimilating the second epithet in form to the first, He is strong, and one who overcomes in contention, &c.] (A.)

OaladRu c
OaladRu and OalanodadN and yalanodadN and OulayodRu: see laAdRN.

maloduwdN c
maloduwdN A man who has had a medicine, or draught, of the kind termed laduwd administered to him. (S, L, K.)

AlmutaladRadu c
AlmutaladRadu (tropical:) The neck. (A, L, K.)

maA liI Eanohu mulotadRN c
maA liI Eanohu mulotadRN I have no way of avoiding, or escaping, it: (S, L, K:) as also muHotadRN. (S, L.)

1 ladVba
1: and 3. ladaba and laAdaba: see lacaba.

superEntry.entry:
1 lacRa c
1. lacRa, (T, M, L, Msb, K,) second per. lacicota, (Msb,) aor. yalacRu, (T, Msb,) inf. n. lacaAcapN (A, L, Msb) and lacaAcN (Msb) and lacRapN; (A;) and AltcR↓, inf. n. UiloticAcN; (A;) It (a thing) was, or became laciyc [i. e. pleasant, delightful, delicious, luscious, sweet, or savoury; see lacRapN, below; and see TaAba]; (T, M, L, Msb, K;) an object of desire, or a thing desired. (L.) ― -b2- lacRahu, (M, L, K,) first pers. lacicotu, (T, S, Msb,) aor. yalacRu, (T, M, L, Msb,) inf. n. lacRN (M, L) and lacRapN (Msb) and lacaAcN and lacaAcapN, (S, M, L, K,) He found it laciyc [i. e. pleasant, delightful, delicious, luscious, sweet, or savoury; he delighted in it; he took pleasure, or delight, in it]; (S, L, Msb, K;) as also lacRa bihi, and AltcRhu↓, and bihi AltcR↓, and AstlcRhu↓: (M, K:) or he counted, accounted, reckoned, or esteemed, it pleasant, &c.; (L;) as also lacRa bh, and AltcRhu↓, and bh AltdR↓, (A, L,) and AstlcRhu↓: (S, L, Msb:) lacicotu AlXRaIoCa and lacicotu bh and Uisotalocacotuhu are syn.; (En-Nadr, T, L;) and so are bh Uilotacacotu↓ and bh talacRacotu↓. (S, L, Msb.) ― -b3- caA mimRaA yalucRuniI, and yulacRicuniI↓, [and yulicRuniI, (see an ex. of its act. part. n. voce muricRN, in art. rc,) This is of the things that please, or delight, me]. (A.)

2 lacRaRa
2: see 1.

3 lAcR AlrRajulu QmoraOatahu c
3. lAcR AlrRajulu QmoraOatahu, inf. n. mulaAcRapN and licaAcN, [The man gave pleasure, or delight, or enjoyment, to his wife, receiving the same from her,] on the occasion of contact in the act of concubitus. (A.) See also 6.

4 Oalocaca
4: see 1.

5 talacRacotu c
5. talacRacotu [I became pleased, or delighted; or I pleased, or delighted, myself]. (A.) ― -b2- See also 1.

6 talaAcRaA c
6. talaAcRaA [They (a husband and his wife) gave each other pleasure, or delight, or enjoyment,] on the occasion of contact in the act of concubitus. (A.) See also 3.

8 Uilotacaca
8: see 1.

10 Uisotalocaca
10: see 1. ― -b2- [AstlcR also signifies He experienced pleasure, or delight.]

lacRN c
lacRN Sleep. (IAar, T, S, L, K.) ― -b2- See also lacRapN and laciydN.

lacRapN c
lacRapN Pleasure; delight; contr. of OalamN; (M, L, K;) so explained because it happens not save to one who is of sound constitution, free from pains; syn. with XahowapN [in one of the senses of this latter word], or nearly so: (TA:) pleasantness; delightfulness; deliciousness; lusciousness, sweetness: (the Lexicons passim: see the intrans. v. lacRa, of which it is an inf. n.) pl. lacRaAtN. (S, L, Msb, K.) ― -b2- lacowaI↓, of the measure faEolaI, also signifies the same as lacRapN, and is formed by the change of one of the two dháls into w; [in the L I;] a change similar to that in taqaDRaI. (L.) It occurs in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, relating to the present world, qado maDaI lacowaAhaA wabaqiIa balowaAhaA [Its pleasure, or delight, or pleasantness, or delightfulness, hath passed away, and its probation remaineth]. (L.) ― -b3- Also lacRapN and lacaAcapN↓ and laciycN↓ and lacowaI↓ The eating and drinking in a state of ease, comfort, or pleasure, and competence. (IAar, T, L.) ― -b4- See laciycN.

laciycN c
laciycN and lacRN↓ are used in the same manner, as epithets, (Lth, T, L,) from the intrans. v. lacRa, (L,) signifying Pleasant, delightful, delicious, luscious, sweet, or savoury; (the Lexicons passim;) desirable, or desired: (L:) pl. of both, licaAcN; and of the latter, [or of both,] lucRN. (M, K.) ― -b2- XaraAbN laciycN, and lacRN↓, (S, M, L,) and kaOosN lacRapN, (M, L,) and XaIoCN laciycN, and lacRN↓, (A,) A pleasant, delightful, delicious, luscious, sweet, or savoury, beverage, or wine, and cup of beverage, or wine, and thing]. ― -b3- [You say] lahu EayoXN lacRN↓ [He has a pleasant, or delightful, life]: and mino huwa fiI lacRK↓ EayoXK [He is in a pleasant, or delightful, state of life]. (A.) ― -b4- rajulN lacRN↓ A man of pleasant, or delightful, conversation, or discourse. (A.) ― -b5- A man in the enjoyment of pleasure, or delight: (M, L:) and OalicRapN [pl. of lacRN] Those who take their pleasures, or delights. (K.) ― -b6- AllRaciycu and AllRacRapu↓ Wine: pl. lucRN and licaAcN. (K.) ― -b7- See lacRapN.

lacaAcapN c
lacaAcapN: see lacRapN, and 1.

lacowaI c
lacowaI: see lacRapN.

caA OaToyabu waOalacRu c
caA OaToyabu waOalacRu [This is more. or most. pleasant and delightful, &c.] (A.)

malacRN c
malacRN A place of lacRap [i. e. pleasure, or delight]: pl. malaAcRu. It is said in a trad. UicaA rakiba OaHadukumu AldRaAbRapa faloyaHomilohaA EalaI malaAcRihaA [When any one of you rides the beast of carriage, let him urge it to run upon the places that are pleasant to it]; i. e. let him make it run upon plain, or even, not rugged, ground, (L.)

AallRaco c
AallRaco and AallRaci [thus written with two láms] dial. forms of AlRaciI: dual AllRacaA, with the n elided: pl. AlRaciyna; and sometimes, in the nom. case, AlRacuwna. (S.) Their proper art. is lcI. (IB, K.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce tazabRaI.]

1 lacaba c
1. lacaba, aor.
lacuba
, inf. n. lucuwbN; and laAcaba↓; He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in a place: (K:) or correctly written with d, unpointed: but IDrd doubts whether correctly with c or with d. (TA.) See also lazaba.

3 laAocaba
3: see 1.

1. lazRa AlXRaIoCu biAlXRaIoCi, (TK,) [aor., app.
laziza
,] or lazRahu, aor.
lazuza
, (so in a copy of the Msb,) inf. n. lazRN, (Msb, K,) The thing clave to the thing: (Msb, K, * TK:) it stuck, or adhered, to it. (TA.) See also 8. ― -b2- [Hence,] lazazota biI yaA fulaAnu (tropical:) [Thou hast importuned me, or wearied me by thine importunity, O such a one]. (A.) ＝ -A2- lazRahu, (S, K,) aor.
lazuza
, (S,) inf. n. lazRN (S, K) and lazazN, (K, and so in a copy of the S,) or lazaAzN, (L, and so in a copy of the S,) He fastened it, or made it fast; or he bound it, or tied it; syn. XadRahu: and he stuck it, or made it to adhere; (S, K;) as also AlzRhu↓, (K,) inf. n. UilozaAzN. (TA.) [But it is afterwards said in the TA, that, accord. to the TS, Oalozazotu bihi in the sense of OaloSaqotu bihi was disallowed by As.]) You say also, lazRahu bihi, (TK,) inf. n. lazRN, (K,) He made it to cleave to it; (K, * TK;) like the lizaAz of a house or chamber. (Lth, TA.) And luzRaA They (two camels) were tied together: and they (the two shanks of a camel) were straitly connected in the shackles. (TA.) ― -b2- He fastened it, namely a door, with a lizaAz, or bar; he barred it. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- He thrust or pierced him [with a spear or the like]. (K, * TK.) ― -b4- lazRahu UilaI kacaA (tropical:) He necessitated him, or constrained him, to have recourse to, or to do, such a thing. (A, TA.)

2 lazRazahu c
2. lazRazahu He (God) caused him to be compact and strong in make. (S, K.)

3 laA zazotuhu c
3. laA zazotuhu, (inf. n. lizaAzN, TA,) I associated with him; became his companion. (S, * K, * TA.)

4 AlzRhu c
4. AlzRhu: see 1.

8 AltzR bihi c
8. AltzR bihi It became coupled with it, and stuck to it. (A.) See also 1.

rajulN kazRN lazRN c
rajulN kazRN lazRN A niggardly, tenacious, man: (AZ, TA:) or the latter epithet is an imitative sequent. (S, K.) ― -b2- lazRu XarRK: see lizaAzu XarRK.

lizRN XarRK c
lizRN XarRK: see lizaAzu XarRK.

lazazN c
lazazN: see lizaAzN. ＝ -A2- Straitness, difficulty, distress; or the like; syn. XidRapN. (TA.) ― -b2- A state of crowding together of people in a narrow compass. (Msb.) ― -b3- EayoXN lazazN A strait, or difficult, life (Msb.)

lizaAzN c
lizaAzN A piece of wood with which a door is fastened; the bar of a door; (A, * K, * TA;) as also lazazN↓. (K.) [Said in the S, where it is not explained, to be from lizaAzu xaSomK, q. v. infra.; but accord. to the A, it is proper, not tropical.] ＝ -A2- huwa lizaAzu maAlK (tropical:) He is one who [by close and constant attention] takes good care of camels, or other property. (A, TA.) [Hence,] jaEalotuka lizaAzFA lifulaAnK (tropical:) I have made or appointed thee [to be a manager of such a one;] not to suffer such a one to disobey or oppose. (A, * TA.) ― -b2- huwa lizaAzu xaSomK (tropical:) [He is one who cleaves to an adversary in contention or litigation]. (S, A.) ― -b3- UinRahu lizaAzu xuSuwmapK (tropical:) Verily he is pertinacious in contention or litigation; commissioned and able to manage it. (TA.) ― -b4- fulaAnN lizaAzu XarRK, (TA,) and XarRK laziyzu↓, and XarRK lizRu↓, (K,) and lazRu XarRK, (TA,) (tropical:) Such a one is one who pertinaciously adheres to evil or mischief. (K, TA.)

lazuwzN c
lazuwzN an imitative sequent to EajuwzN. (K.)

laziyzu XarRK c
laziyzu XarRK: see lizaAzN.

milazRN c
milazRN, applied to a man, and in like manner, without p, to a woman, (tropical:) Vehement, or pertinacious, in adhering. (TA.) ― -b2- Vehement in contention or litigation; (S, K;) pertinacious in adhering to that which he desires, or seeks, to obtain. (S.)

mulazRazN c
mulazRazN, (S, K,) or mulazRazu Alxaloqi, (A,) A man (A, TA) compact and strong in make; (S, * K, * TA;) having a well-knit frame. (A.)

1 lazaO c
1. lazaO and AlzO↓, (K,) or the former only, (TA,) He filled (K) a water-skin or the like. (TA.) ＝ -A2- lazaOahu, aor.
lazaAa
; and lzROh↓, (K,) and AlzOh↓; (TA;) He gave him [a thing]. (K, TA.) In the K, this portion is confused, as well as defective. (TA.) ＝ -A3- lazaOato She (a woman) brought forth. (K.) [You say] qabaHa AllRehu OumRFA lazaOatohu, (TA,) or lazaOato bihi (S,) [May God remove far from good, or prosperity, the mother that brought him forth!] ＝ -A4- lazaOa; (K;) and lzRO↓, (As, S, K,) inf. n. taloziYapN; (As, S;) He tended camels well. (As, S, K.)

2 lazRaAa
2: see 1.

4 AlzO c
4. AlzO He satiated sheep &c. (K) with pasture. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See 1.

5 tlzRO riyRFA c
5. tlzRO riyRFA It, or he, was, or became, filled to saturation, or satiety. (K, * TA.)

1. lazaba, aor.
lazuba
, inf. n. luzuwbN, It was, or remained, fixed, settled, firm, or constant. (K.) ― -b2- lazaba, aor. and inf. n. as above, It (mud &c., S) adhered, clave, or stuck. (S, K.) ― -b3- lazuba, aor.
lazuba
, inf. n. lazobN and luzuwbN, [It became commixed, or commingled: it intermixed; or it became contracted;] one part of it entered into another. (K.) ― -b4- lazaba and lazuba It (mud) cohered, and became hard. (K.) ― -b5- lazaba, aor. and inf. n. as at first, It was a time of drought, of no rain. (K.) ＝ -A2- lazabatohu AlEaqorabu i. q. lasabatohu; The scorpion stung him. (Kr, K.)

6 tlAzb AltRamoru c
6. tlAzb AltRamoru The dates stuck together. (L, art. nDH.)

lazobN c
lazobN Strait; narrow; difficult. E. g. EayoXN lazobN A strait, or difficult life. (TA.)

lizobN c
lizobN A narrow road, or way. (K.)

lazabN c
lazabN immediately following EazabN, (in the CK, garabN,) [meaning a man “ who has no wife, ”] is an imitative sequent [used by way of pleonasm and corroboration]. (K.) So likewise lazabapN after EazabapN. (Ibn-Buzruj.)

lazibN c
lazibN Little in quantity or number: pl. lizaAbN. (K.) E. g. maACN lazibN Little water. (TA.)

lazobapN c
lazobapN Adversity; difficulty; distress; (S, K;) drought: (S:) pl. lizabN (IJ, K: in the CK lazobN) and lazobaAtN: (S, K:) the latter with the z quiescent, because it is [originally] an epithet. (S.) E. g. OaSaAbatohumo lazobapN Distress and drought befell them. (S.) ― -b2- sanapN lazobapN A severe year; a year of drought. (TA.)

laAzibN c
laAzibN Adhering, or adhesive, or cohesive, clay or mud. (S.) ― -b2- Being, or remaining, fixed, settled, firm, or constant. (S.) ― -b3- SaAra AlXRaIoCu Darobapa laAzibK The thing became fixed, settled, firm, or constant, (S, K,) and severe: (TA:) [or, a constant infliction:] or, indispensable, or necessary: i. e., the blow of a sword that sticks, or remains fixed, [in the wound]. (Aboo-Bekr, cited in the TA.) lAzb is here the same as lAzm: (K:) the latter is the original word; the m being changed into b; and is also used in this phrase: (TA:) but lAzb, in this in-
stance, is the more chaste. (S.) En-Nábighah says,
falaA taHosibuwna Alxayora laA XarRa baEodahu
walaA taHosibuwna AlXRarRa Darobapa laAzibi
[Then think ye not that good shall have no evil after it, nor think ye that evil shall be a constant infliction]. (S.) Sgh says, of the conversion of riwaAgapN into riyaAgapN, or of w into I because of kesreh before it, hecaA Alqalobu layosa biDarobK laAzibK [This conversion is not a necessary sort.] (TA in art. rwg.)

milozaAbN c
milozaAbN Very avaricious; tenacious, or niggardly: (S, K:) pl. malaAziybu. (S.)

1 lazija c
1. lazija, aor.
lazaja
, (S, M, K,) inf. n. lazajN and luzuwjapN (M) and luzuwjN; (Msb;) and tlzRj↓; (M;) It (a thing, S) stretched out, in a neut. sense: it roped; or drew out, with a viscous, glutinous, clammy, cohesive, sticky, ropy, or slimy, continuity of parts: syn. tamaTRaTa and tamadRada: (S, K:) it was, or became, viscous, glutinous, clammy, cohesive, sticky, ropy, or slimy, so as to adhere to the hand and the like. (Msb.) ― -b2- lazija bihi It adhered to him, or it, as glue or the like; syn. gariIa. (S, K.) E. g. Oakalotu XayoYFA falazija biOaSaAbiEiI I ate a thing and it adhered to my fingers. (Msb.) ― -b3- [And] tlzRj↓ It (food, or ointment,) became [viscous, glutinous, clammy, cohesive, sticky, slimy, ropy, or mucilaginous,] like xiTomiIR [or marsh-mallow]. (M, &c.) ― -b4- AlnRabaAtu tlzRj↓ i. q. talajRana: (S, K:) i. e., The herbage became flaccid, and one part thereof inclined over another: (TA:) [or became flaccid, and of a viscous consistency, or viscous or mucilaginous in its juice; as appears from what here follows]. Ru-beh says, [in the S, El-'Ajjáj,] describing a pair af asses, male and female,
wafaraEaA mino raEoIi maA talazRajaA
[And they finished pasturing upon what had become flaccid, and of a viscous consistency]. For, says J, [immediately after citing these words of the poet,] when herbage begins to dry up, its juice thickens, and becomes like the mucilage of the xiTomiIR [or marsh-mallow]. (TA.) Or the words of the poet, above quoted, signify, And they finished pasturing upon what they had searched after constantly, or time after time: for talazRujN also signifies the searching of a beast of carriage after herbage and leguminous plants, constantly, or time after time: and the two asses are here the agents of the verb tlzRjA. (L.)

5 talazRaja
5: See 1. ― -b2- tlzRj raOosuhu His head remained unpurified of its dirt (S, K) after he had washed it. (Yaakoob, S.)

lazijN c
lazijN (S, M, Msb) and mutalazRijN↓ (M), A thing stretching out, in a neut. sense: roping; or drawing out, with a viscous, glutinous, clammy, cohesive, sticky, or slimy, continuity of parts: syn. mutamaTRiTN and mutamadRidN: (S:) viscous, glutinous, clammy, cohesive, sticky, ropy, or slimy, so as to adhere to the hand or the like: (Msb:) balogamN lazijN [Viscous, glutinous, cohesive, sticky, or ropy, phlegm]. (TA.) zabiybapN lazijapN A sticky raisin. (L.)

rajulN lazojapN c
rajulN lazojapN, and lazijapN, and laziyjapN, A man who keeps to his place, and does not quit it. (K.)

mutalazRijN c
mutalazRijN: see lazijN.

, He thieved, or stole: (A:) [see luSuwSiyRapN, and the other nouns mentioned therewith, some of which, if not all, are app. inf. ns. of this verb:] and tlSRS↓ signifies the same; or he was thievish: (S, * Msb, * TA:) [or he practised theft:] or he thieved, or stole, repeatedly: (A, TA:) and he acted as a spy; syn. tajasRasa. (A, K.) ＝ -A2- laSRa baAbahu, (TA,) inf. n. laSRN, (A, K,) He closed, or locked, his door; syn. Oagolaqahu and OaTobaqahu; (A, K, TA;) as also raSRahu. [This verb probably has all the significations indicated by the explanations of laSaSN below.]

(K) [and in the TA said to be so in the T: but this is probably a mistake for liSaASN: for ISd says,] the word has no pl. of pauc.: (M:) and malaSRapN is a quasi-pl. n.: (IJ, M:) the pl. of liSRapN, (M,) or laSRapN, (K,) is liSRaAtN, (M,) and laSRaAtN, (K,) and laSaAYiSu, (M, K,) which last is extr. [with respect to rule]: (M:) and the pl. of liSotN is luSuwtN. (M.)

(TA.) ― -b3- Also, Nearness of the forehead to the eyebrow. (IKtt, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also luSuwSiyRapN.

laSaASN c
laSaASN: see what next follows.

luSuwSN c
luSuwSN: see what next follows.

luSuwSapN: see what next follows.

luSuwSiyRapN (S, M, K [in the CK without tesh-deed]) and laSuwSiyRapN, (Ks, S, M, and in a copy of the K,) the latter of which is the more chaste, though the other is the regular form, (TA,) and luSuwSapN↓, (M, A, and so in the CK in the place of the form next preceding,) or laSuwSapN↓, (as in some copies of the K and in the TA) or luSuwSN↓ and laSuwSN↓, (as in a copy of the Msb,) and laSaASN↓ and laSaSN↓, (K,) Thieving; or thievishness. (S, M, A, Msb, K.)

OalaSRu c
OalaSRu, (S, M, K,) or OalaSRu AlOaDoraAsi, (A,) A man (M, A) whose [teeth called] ADrAs are near together (S, M, A, K) so that no interstice is seen between them: (M:) as also OaraSRu: (M, A, K, art. rS:) fem. laSRaMCu. (M.) ― -b2- Also, the masc. (As, TA) and fem., (K,) or OalaSRu Alfaxicayoni, (A,) One whose thighs cleave together, there being no space between them. (As, A, * K.) [See also OaraSRu.] Hence, (TA,) the Zenjee is said to be OalaSRu AlOaloyatayoni, (K,) i. e. Having the buttocks cleaving together. (TA.) And OalaSRu, (S,) or OalaSRu Almanokibayoni, (A,) Having the two shoulderjoints near together, almost touching the ears. (S, A.) ― -b3- Also the fem., applied to a woman, Impervia coëunti; (M;) as also raSRaMCu. (M, art. rS.) ― -b4- And, applied to a forehead (jabohap), Narrow. (K.) ― -b5- And, applied to a sheep or goat, Having one of her horns extending forwards and the other backwards. (Z, Sgh, K.)

malaSRapN quasi-pl. n. of liSRN. (IJ, M.) ― -b2- OaroDN malaSRapN A land in which are thieves, or robbers: (S, M:) or in which are many thieves or robbers. (K.)

galaqN maloSuwSN c
galaqN maloSuwSN [A closed lock]. (TA.)

laSaba

miloTaON and miloTaOap: see laATiYapN, and also arts. lTI and lT. ― -b2- The former is also explained as signifying The pericranium itself; a thin cuticle, or membrane, between the bone of the scull and its flesh: accord. to IAth and the L. (TA.)

1 laTavahu c
1. laTavahu, (aor.
laTiva
, inf. n. laTovN, L,) He struck him with the flat of the hand; or, with a broad piece of wood: (IAar, K:) he slapped him with his open hand; syn. SakRahu; (K;) like laTamahu. (TA.) [See also laTasahu.] ― -b2- laTavahu biHajarK He threw a stone at him; (K;) as also laTasahu. (TA.) ＝ -A2- laTavahu He collected it together. (K.) ＝ -A3- laTavahu AlOamoru, (aor.
laTiva
, inf. n. laTovN,) The affair was difficult, or troublesome, to him. (K.) ― -b2- laTavahu, aor.
laTiva
, inf. n. laTovN, It (a load, or an affair,) was heavy or burdensome, and hard, or grievous to him. (L.) ― -b3- laTavN, [aor.
laTuva
,] inf. n. laTovN, It became corrupt. (IAar, K.)

6 talaATava Almawoju c
6. talaATava Almawoju The waves dashed together, or against each other. (K) ― -b2- tlATt Alqawomu The people struck each other with their hands: (K:) or, with swords. (TA.)

malaATitu c
malaATitu Places that are struck (tuloTavu) by a load, or burden, or by beating: (K:) a quasi-pl. n., or a pl. without a sing., or having a pl. respecting which the lexicologists do not agree. (MF.)

mulaATivN c
mulaATivN Collecting; or a collector; syn. jaAmiEN: (K:) selling; or a seller; or buying; or a buyer; syn. baAYiEN. (AA.)

1 laTaHahu c
1. laTaHahu, aor.
laTaHa
, (inf. n. laToHN, S,) He struck him with the palm of his hand; (K;) as also laTaxahu: or he struck him, not violently, with his open hand: (TA:) or he struck him, not violently, with the palm of his hand and the like: (T:) or he struck him gently on the back (S, K) with the palm of the hand; like HaTaOahu. (S.) ― -b2- laTaHa bihi He threw him, or cast him, upon the ground. (S, K.)

laToHN c
laToHN A soil, or pollution, or taint, (like laToxN,) of which, when it is rubbed, there remains no sign. (T, M, K.)

1 laTaxahu c
1. laTaxahu, (S, K, &c.,) aor.
laTaxa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. laToxN, (S,) He defiled, befouled, polluted, dirtied, soiled, sullied, smeared, besmeared, daubed, bedaubed, bespattered, [rubbed over, or overspread,] sprinkled or splashed, him, or it, (S, L, Msb, K,) as a garment, (Msb,) biIdA The original has unclear characters above the ب and the ى
with such a thing, (S,) as with ink. (Msb.) [See also 2.] ― -b2- laTaxahu biXarRK, (L,) or bisuwoCK, (Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, He sullied, or bespattered, him with evil [by charging him therewith]: (L:) he [aspersed him; or] charged, reproached, or upbraided, him with evil. (Msb.) laTaxahu biOamorK qabiyHK He charged, reproached, or upbraided, him with something bad, evil, abominable, or foul, either said or done. (L, arts. lTx and Tyx.) ― -b3- luTixa biXarRK, (S, K,) a verb like EuniIa, [pass. in form but neut. in signification,] (K) He became [aspersed, or] charged, reproached, or upbraided, with evil. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See art. lTH.

2 lTRxhu c
2. lTRxhu He defiled, befouled, polluted, dirtied, soiled, smeared, besmeared, daubed, bedaubed, bespattered, [rubbed over, or overspread,] or splashed, him or it, much. (Msb.) [See also 1.] ― -b2- He daubed him over with perfume &c. (S, K, art. Dmx, &c.)

5 tlTRx c
5. tlTRx He, or it, (as a garment, Msb,) became defiled, befouled, polluted, dirtied, soiled, besmeared, bedaubed, or bespattered; (S, L, Msb, K;) [or became so much; or he defiled, &c., himself; or did so much;] bikacaA with such a thing, (S,) as with ink. (Msb.) ― -b2- tlTRx biqabiyHK, (S, L, K, art. Tyx, &c.) and mino qabiyHK, (L,) i. e. [He became charged, reproached, or upbraided, with] something bad, evil, abominable, or foul, either said or done. (L, arts. lTx and Tyx.) tlTRx biXarRK He did evil [and thus defiled himself; he defiled himself by doing evil]. (L.)

laToxN c
laToxN [and laToxapN↓] A small portion or quantity; a particle; of clouds (S, L, K) and the like, (K,) and of news, or tidings, or information: (L:) and [a small quantity] of rain. (K in art. cyl.) ― -b2- laToxN [A soil, or pollution, or taint]. (See laToHN.) ― -b3- [And laToxapN↓ A soil, a splash.]

laTixN c
laTixN A man (L) dirty (L, K) in eating. (K.) ― -b2- Anything defiled, dirtied, or besmeared, with something of a different colour. (L.)

laToxapN c
laToxapN see laToxN.

luTaxapN c
luTaxapN and liTRiyxN↓ A stupid man; one of little sense; (K;) in whom is no good: (TA:) pl. of the former luTaxaAtN. (K.)

laTuwxN c
laTuwxN A thing with which another thing is defiled, polluted, dirtied, or besmeared, (K,) and with which its colour is changed. (TA.)

luTaAxapN c
luTaAxapN What remains of a soil, or pollution, or the like. (L.)

liTRiyxN c
liTRiyxN: see luTaxapN.
