superEntry.entry:
1 laZRa c
1. laZRa: see 4. ― -b2- [The inf. n.] laZRN is also syn. with TarodN [The act of driving away; &c.]. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.)

3 mulaAZRapN c
3. mulaAZRapN, inf. n. of laAZRa: and, as also liZaAZN, irregularly, of talaAZRuwA: see 4, and 6.

4 AlZR bihi c
4. AlZR bihi, (T, S, M, K, *) inf. n. UiloZaAZN, (T, S,) He kept, or clave, or adhered, (T, S, M, K,) to him, (AZ, T, S,) not quitting him, (T,) and to it: (T, S, M:) he applied himself to it perseveringly, assiduously, constantly, or incessantly; (A'Obeyd, * S, * M, TA;) as also AlZR Ealayohi: (M:) and bihi laZRa↓, (IDrd, M, TA,) [aor., accord. to general rule,
laZiZa
,] inf. n. laZRN and laZiyZN↓, (K, TA,) or the latter is a subst. from AlZR bh; (M, TA;) in the former sense, (K,) and in the latter. (M, K.) You say, AlZR biAlkalimapi He kept to the expression. (M.) And hence, OaliZRuwA fiI AldRuEaMCi biyaA caA AljalaAli waAlUikoraAmi Keep ye in prayer to [the expression] yA cl AljlAl wAlAkrAm; (S, M, * TA; *) and repeat it often: (TA:) a saying of Ibn-Mes'ood. (S, TA.) Hence also, (S, M,) fiI AlHarobi AlmulaAZRapu↓ (Lth, T, S, M) The keeping, or applying oneself, perseveringly, assiduously, constantly, or incessantly, to fighting. (M, TA.) ― -b2- He remained, stayed, dwelt, or abode, (S, K,) in it, namely a place; (S;) as also AlZR Elyh. (TA.) ― -b3- AlZR AlmaTaru The rain continued, (S, M, K, *) and was incessant. (M.)

6 talaAZRuwA c
6. talaAZRuwA, inf. n., irregularly, mulaAZRapN↓ and liZaAZN, They kept, or applied themselves, perseveringly, assiduously, constantly, or incessantly, to fighting, one with another. (M.) talaAZRN is also syn. with taTaArdN: (K, TA:) you say, marRati AlfurosaAnu talaAZRu [The horsemen passed by charging upon, assaulting, or attacking, and fighting, one another]. (TA.)

laZRN c
laZRN, (K,) or laZRN kaZRN, (T, S, M,) A man hard, or difficult, in disposition; (S, K;) as also laZolaAZN↓: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) or a man hard, o difficult, in disposition, (T, M;) and treated with severity, or rigour, (T,) or straitened; (M;) as also milaZRN↓ and miloZaAZN↓: (M:) kZR is app. an imitative sequent. (M.) You say, UinRahu laHadiydN laZolaAZN↓ Verily he is [sharp and] evil (zaEir) in disposition. (TA.)

laZolaAZN c
laZolaAZN: see laZRN, in two places. ― -b2- It also signifies Chaste in speech; or eloquent. (TA.) ― -b3- And sometimes, (Fr,) A hot day. (Fr, K.)

muliZRN c
muliZRN Keeping, cleaving, or adhering; (T;) not quitting. (T, S.) You say, huwa muliZRN bihi He is keeping, cleaving, or adhering, to him; (T;) not quitting him. (S, T.) ― -b2- A man much attached, addicted, or given, to a thing; (T;) who applies himself perseveringly, assiduously, constantly, or incessantly, (T, S,) to it; as also miloZaAZN↓: (T:) or the latter signifies very persevering, assiduous, or constant. (S, K.)

milaZRN c
milaZRN Keeping, cleaving, or adhering, fast: applied to a creditor. (TA.) ― -b2- See also laZRN.

miloZaAZN c
miloZaAZN: see muliZRN, and laZRN.

laZaON c
laZaON A little (and mean, or contemptible, TA) thing; a little. (K.)

dictScrap.label: lZI: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 laEiba c
1. laEiba, aor.
laEaba
, inf. n. laEibN (which is the original [and most common] form, TA) and liEobN (S, K: the latter of these inf. ns. contracted from the former, Msb) and laEobN (K: also contracted from the first: not heard by IKt; but authorized by Mekkee, and, accord. to him,
agreeable with a constant rule, applicable in the case of any word of a similar measure having a guttural letter as its medial radical, whether a noun or verb: (TA:) and OuloEuwbapN (S, K) and taloEaAbN; (K; but this last has an intensive, or a frequentative, signification; S;) and lERb↓ (K) and tlERb↓ (S, K: but this last has a frequentative [or an intensive] signification; S; [and so too has that immediately preceding it;]) and tlAEb↓; (K;) He played, sported, gamed, jested, or joked: contr. of jadRa, which signifies “ he was serious, or in earnest. ” (K.) [You say] bayonahumo OuloEuwbapN Between them is playing, sporting, or the like. (K.) [And so] laAEabahaA↓, (inf. n. mulaAEabapN and liEaAbN, TA,) He played, sported, gamed, jested, or joked, with her: (K:) [he toyed, dallied, or wantoned, with her:] and laAEabotu AlrRajula, inf. n. mlAEbp, I played, &c., with the man. (S) ― -b2- laEibati AlrRiyHu biAlmanozili, and talaAEabat↓, (tropical:) [The wind sported with the lighting-place, or place of abode]: i. e., obliterated the traces of it. (TA.) ― -b3- laEiba binaA Almawoju [The waves sported with us]: the commotion of the waves is called “ sporting ” because it does not convey the voyagers to the quarter whither they desire to go. (TA, from a trad.) ＝ -A2- laEaba, (and laEiba, K,) aor.
laEaba
, inf. n. laEobN; (S, K;) and AlEb↓; (K;) He (a child, S) slavered; drivelled; emitted a flow of slaver or drivel from his mouth. (S, K.) The first word is the most approved: (TA:) or AlSRabiIRu AlEb↓ signifies the child became slavering, or drivelling. (S.)

3 laAoEaba
3: see 1.

4 OaloEabahaA c
4. OaloEabahaA He made her to play, sport, or game, &c., (with him: accord. to the CK:) or he brought her a thing with which to play, &c. (K.) ＝ -A2- See 1.

5 tlERb c
5. tlERb He played time after time. (S.) See 1.

6 talaAoEaba
6: see 1.

10 AstlEbt AlnRaxolapu c
10. AstlEbt AlnRaxolapu The palm-tree produced some unripe dates after its other we had been cut off: (K:) or produced, or put forth, a spadix or more, having yet upon it some remains of its first produce of fruit. (Aboo-Sa'eed.)

laEobN c
laEobN for EalobN: see the latter.

liEobN c
liEobN: see laEibN

laEibN c
laEibN and liEibN↓ (with two kesrehs, agreeably with a constant rule obtaining in cases of this kind, [whereby the measure faEilN is changed into fiEilN, the medial radical letter being a guttural,] TA, [but in the CK and a MS. copy, liEobN↓, which is also regularly changed from the first,]) and OuloEubaAnN↓ and luEabapN↓ (K) and luEobapN↓ (TA, as from the K, [but not found by me in any copy of the latter work,]) and tiloEiybapN↓ and tiloEaAbN↓ (K) and tiloEaAbapN↓ (S, K) and taloEaAbN↓ and taloEaAbapN↓ and tiliERaAbN↓ and tiliERaAbapN↓ (K: the last like tiliqRaAmapN: the p is added to give [additional] intensiveness to the signification, as in the cases of EalRaAmapN and nasRaAbapN: it is also used by En-Nábighah El-Jaadee in the place of an inf. n.: TA) and laEuwbN↓ [which is common to both genders] and laERaAbN↓ (A, &c.) One who plays, sports, games, jests, or jokes, much, or often; a great player, sporter, &c. (S, K.)

liEibN c
liEibN: see laEibN.

laEobapN c
laEobapN (Th, S) and luEobapN↓ (ISk, S, K) A turn in play, in a game, &c.; a single act of a play or game &c. (S, K, &c.) [You say] limana AllRuEobapu↓ [Whose turn is it to play?] with dammeh to the l, because it is a subst.; (ISk;) [and] OuqoEudo Oaforuga mino hecihi AllRuEobapi↓ [Sit until I finish this turn of the game]: but accord. to Th, it is better to say mn hch AllRaEobapi, with fet-hah; because what is meant is a single turn in the game. (S.) ― -b2- laEibotu laEobapF waAHidapF [I played one game]. (Fr.) ＝ -A2- AllRaEobapu AlbarobariyRapu (in some copies of the K, AllRuEobapu↓) A certain medicine, resembling what is called AlsRuwranojaAnu, which fattens. (K.)

luEobapN c
luEobapN Anything with which one plays, as XiToranoj and the like, (S, K,) and narod. (S.) See also laEobapN. ― -b2- A man with whom one plays, sports, or jests: (K:) one who is a laughing-stock: (TA:) a stupid fellow, or fool, whom one mocks, laughs at, or ridicules; a stupid laughing-stock (K.) ― -b3- An image or effigy [with which to play: a puppet: so the word signifies in the present day]. (K.) [It was probably sometimes applied to A crucifix. And hence, or perhaps from its resemblance to a man with outstretched arms, it is applied by some post-classical writers to A cross; and anything in the form of a cross.] ― -b4- The image that is seen in the black of the eye when a thing faces it; also called EayorN. (Aboo-Tálib, in L, art. Eyr.) ― -b5- See laEibN.

liEobapN c
liEobapN A mode, or manner, of playing, sporting, gaming, &c. You say, fulaAnN Hasanu AllRiEobapi [Such a one has a good manner of playing, &c. (S.)

luEabapN c
luEabapN: see laEibN.

luEaAbN c
luEaAbN What flows from the mouth; slaver; drivel. (S, K.) ― -b2- [Mucilage of plants. See S, art. lzj &c.] ― -b3- luEaAbu AlnRaxoli (tropical:) The honey of the date-palm. (S, K.) ― -b4- luEaAbu AlXRamosi (tropical:) A thing (that one sees, TA) as though descending from the sky, at the time of the mid-day heat; (K;) what one sees in a time of intense heat, resembling cobwebs: [i. e. gossamer:] also said to be the saraAb, or mirage: (S:) it is what is called muxaATu AlXRayoTaAni, and sahaAmN, and riyqu AlXRamosi, resembling threads, seen in the air when the heat is intense and the air calm: and he who asserts the lEAb AlXms to be the srAb says what is false; for that is the srAb that is seen at mid-day resembling running water: only he knows these things who has been constantly in the deserts, and has journeyed during the mid-day heats. (Az.) [In Egypt, in very hot and calm weather, I have seen, though very rarely, great quantities of the filmy substances above mentioned, resembling delicate and silky white cobwebs, generally of stringy forms, floating in the air.]

jaAriyapN laEuwbN c
jaAriyapN laEuwbN A playful, sportive, or gamesome, damsel: (S:) one who coquets prettily, with affected coyness: (K:) pl. laEaAYibu. (TA.) See also laEibN.

laERaAbN c
laERaAbN One whose business or occupation is playing, gaming, or the like; a player by profession. (TA.) See also laEibN.

laAEibN c
laAEibN Playing, sporting, gaming, jesting, or joking. (TA.) See also laEibN. ― -b2- laA yaOoxucanRa OaHadukumo mataAEa Oaxiyhi laAEibFA jaAdRFA [By no means shall any one of you take the property of his brother in play (and) in earnest]: by this is meant taking a thing without meaning to steal it, but meaning to vex and anger the owner; so that the taker is in play with respect to theft, but in earnest in annoying. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- UinRamaA Oanota laAEibN [Thou art only playing]: said to anyone who does what is unprofitable. (TA.)

OuloEuwbapN c
OuloEuwbapN A thing with which one plays (Mz, 40th nwE.) [See also luEobapN.] ― -b2- Also an inf. n. of laEiba. (S, K.)

OuloEabaAnN c
OuloEabaAnN: see laEibN.

maloEabN c
maloEabN A place of playing, sporting, gaming, or the like; a place where plays, games, or sports, are performed: (S, K:) pl. malaAEibu. (TA.) ― -b2- malaAEibu AlrRiyHi [pl. (tropical:) The sporting-places of the wind;] places where the wind blows, or has blown, vehemently: syn. madaArijuhaA. (K.) ― -b3- tarakotuhu fiI malaAEibi AljinRi (tropical:) [I left him in the sporting-places of the Jinn, or genii]: i. e., in such a place that he did not know where he was. (TA.)

muloEibapN c
muloEibapN and (as in the CK and a MS. copy) miloEabapN↓ A garment without sleeves, in which a boy plays. (K.)

mulaERibN c
mulaERibN [Exuding mucilage]; applied to a plant: likened to a foolish person slavering: (TA, in art. Hmq.) [See Albaqolapu AlHamoqaACu in art. Hmq.]

mulaAEibu ZilRihi c
mulaAEibu ZilRihi A certain bird; (S, K;) found in the desert; (TA;) sometimes called xaATifu ZilRihi, (S, Msb,) [see art. xTf,] because of the swiftness with which it pounces down: it has a green (or gray, OaxoDar,) back, white belly, long wings, and short neck. (Msb.) Of two you say
mulaAEibaA ZilRayohimaA; and of three, mulaAEibaAtu OaZolaAlihinRa; because the appellation becomes determinate. (TA. [But see ZilRN.])

vagorN maloEuwbN c
vagorN maloEuwbN Teeth, or fore teeth, &c., having slaver or drivel, upon or about them. (S, K.)

talEaAbN c
talEaAbN and tiloEaAbN, taloEaAbapN and tiloEaAbapN, tiloEiybapN, tiliERaAbN and tiliERaAbapN, see laEibN.

1 laEivN c
1. laEivN, aor.
laEava
, (inf. n. laEavN, TA,) He (a man, TA) was heavy and slow. (K.)

OaloEavu c
OaloEavu A man (TA) heavy and slow. (K)

1 laEaja c
1. laEaja, aor.
laEaja
, (inf. n. laEojN, TA) It (a beating, TA) burned the skin: it pained the body: (K:) it (a beating) pained a person, and burned the skin: (S:) it (anything burning) pained: it (love, or grief,) burned his heart. (TA.) [See baEaja.] laAEijN is numbered amongst the [few] inf. ns. of the measure faAEilN [like qaAYimN]; and means as explained below. (TA.) ― -b2- laEaja fI AlSRadori It (an affair) was unsettle in the bosom; syn. xalaxa. (K.)

3 lAEjhu c
3. lAEjhu It (a thing, or an affair,) distressed him. (K.)

4 AlEx AlnRaAra fiI AlHaTabi c
4. AlEx AlnRaAra fiI AlHaTabi He kindled fire in the fire-wood. (K.)

8 AltEj c
8. AltEj He burned, or was distressed and disquieted, by reason of grief, or solicitude. (K.)

laAEijN c
laAEijN: see 1. ― -b2- Ardour of love, or desire, or the like; syn. lawoEapN. (TA.) ― -b3- Burning or ardent, love: (L:) love that burns the heart. (S.) [See HubRN.] ― -b4- bihi laAEiju AlXRawoqi, and lawaAEijuhu, He suffers the burning pain, and pains, of longing desire. (A.)

mutalaERijapN c
mutalaERijapN A woman who burns with lust. (K.)

1 laEisa c
1. laEisa, aor.
laEasa
, (K,) inf. n. laEasN, (TA,) [He vas, or became, characterized, by what is termed laEasN and luEosapN; (see the former of these words below;)] he had a blackness, deemed beautiful, in the lip. (K.)

laEasN c
laEasN The colour of the lip when it inclines a little to blackness; which is deemed beautiful: (S:) or a blackness, deemed beautiful, in the lip (As, A, K, TA) and in the gum; (As, TA;) as also luEosapN↓ [which is likewise syn. with the former word in the other senses here explained]: (A:) or blackness [blending] with redness: and, accord. to El-'Ajjáj, luEosapN↓ is in the whole of the person: Az says, that laEasN of the complexion is a blackness thereof. (TA.) See also OaloEasu.

luEosapN c
luEosapN: see laEasN.

OaloEasu c
OaloEasu Having a blackness, deemed beautiful, in the lip: fem. laEosaMCu: pl. luEosN: (K:) the pl., applied to girls and to women, signifies [as above; or] having a blackness in their lips; (TA;) or having lips of a colour inclining a little to blackness, which is deemed beautiful: (S:) the fem. is also applied to a lip, (Xafap,) signifying of a colour inclining a little to blackness, which is deemed beautiful; (S;) or having a blackness, deemed beautiful; and in like manner the pl. to lips: (A:) and the masc. to the external skin, (baXar); so applied by El-'Ajjáj: (TA:) and the fem. to a girl, as signifying having in her complexion the least degree of blackness, and tinged with redness, (A, K, TA,) not of a clear hue: (TA:) and the pl. to girls, as signifying having a blackness in their complexions. (Az, TA.) ― -b2- You also say, (S, K,) sometimes, (S,) nabaAtN OaloEasu, meaning Abundant and dense herbage; (S, K;) because such inclines to blackness. (S.)

dictScrap.label: lET lEf lEq lEm lEn: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 lagaba c
1. lagaba, aor.
laguba
(S,) and
lagaba
(K); and lagiba, aor
lagaba
; (S, K;) but this latter is of weak authority; (S;) and laguba, aor.
laguba
; (Lb, K;) inf. n. lagobN, (K,) which is said to be inf. n. of lagaba, aor.
laguba
, (TA,) and luguwbN, (S, K,) inf. n. of lagaba, aor.
laguba
, and of lagiba, (S,) and laguwbN, (K,) which deviates from constant rule, like waDuwCN and qabuwlN, (TA,) and lagabN, which is said to be inf. n. of lagiba, agreeably with analogy; (TA;) He was fatigued, tired, or wearied, (S, &c.,) in the greatest degree, or to the utmost: (M, K:) or he was languid in consequence of fatigue: or he was fatigued, tired, or wearied, in spirit, or mind: but most agree, as to the signification, with the S and K. (TA.) ― -b2- lagaAbapN (S, K: in the CK, and app. in most MS. copies of the K, expressly said to be lugaAbapN, with dammeh:) and luguwbapN (K) [app. inf. ns., of which the verb is laguba, aor.
laguba
,] The being stupid, and weak: or [if substs.] stupidity, and weakness. (S, K.) ― -b3- lagaba Ealayohimo, aor.
lagaba
, (inf. n. lagobN, S,) He spoiled, or marred, their affair, scheme, plot, or the like: syn. Oafosada Ealayohimo: [Oamorahumo, or the like, being understood]. (El-Umawee and S.) ― -b4- lagaba Alqawoma He spoke ill, or corruptly, to the people: syn. HadRavahumo HadiyvFA xalofFA. (K.) ＝ -A2- lagaba He (a dog) lapped, or drank by lapping. (K.)

2 lgRb daAbRatahu c
2. lgRb daAbRatahu He laded his beast with more than it was able to bear. (TA.) See 4 and 5.

4 Oalogabahu c
4. Oalogabahu He fatigued, tired, or wearied him. (S, K.) ― -b2- Also, and tlgRbhu↓ and lgRbhu↓, It (journeying, or travel,) fatigued, tired, or wearied, him in the greatest degree, or to the utmost. (K.) ＝ -A2- Algb AlsRahoma He made the feathers of the arrow to be what are termed lugaAb. (K.)

5 tlgRb c
5. tlgRb: see 4. ― -b2- He chased, hunted, or pursued, long: syn. of the inf. n. Tuwlu AlTRarodi. (S, K.) ― -b3- A poet says,
talagRabaniI dahorN falamRaA galabotuhu
gazaAniI biOawolaAdiI faOadorakaniI AldRahoru
[Fortune long pursued me; and when I overcame him, he attacked me with my children; and so fortune overtook me]. (S.) ― -b4- tlgRbhu He undertook the management of it, and did it, and was not unequal to it. (TA.) ― -b5- tlgRb AldRaAbRapa He found the beast of carriage to be fatigued, tired, or weary; or so in the utmost degree. (TA.) See 2.

lagobN c
lagobN (S, K; for which El-Kumeyt has used lagabN↓, like as naharN is used for nahorN, because of the guttural letter; S) and lugaAbN↓ (S) and lagiybN↓ (as in the S and the CK and a MS. copy of the K) or lagibN↓ (as in the TA, from the K) Bad, disordered, or illcomposed, feathers [of an arrow]: syn. riyXN faAsidN: (S, K:) as the longer [or wider] lateral halves of feathers (buTonaAn) [when they have not the shorter, or narrower, lateral halves interposed between two of them]: contr. of luWaAmN: (S:) or the feathers termed lugaAb↓ are the longer [or wider] lateral halves; and a single one of them is called lugaAbapN; [accord. to which explanation, lgAb is a coll. gen. n.;] contr. of lWAm: or the feathers of an arrow, when not equal, even, or uniform, are thus termed; and when equal, even, or uniform, they are termed lWAm: (TA:) lWAm and lgAb are terms applied to two descriptions of feathers; the former, to those whereof a longer [or wider] lateral half is next to a shorter [or narrower] lateral half; and this is the best that can be; and lgAb and lgb are terms applied to those whereof two longer [or wider] lateral halves, or two shorter [or narrower] lateral halves, are next each other. (As.) ― -b2- lagobN and lugaAbN↓ An arrow badly trimmed, or shaped; (K;) badly made: or one of which [all] the wings consist of the longer [or wider] lateral halves of feathers: or one which has two longer [or wider] lateral halves of feathers, or two shorter [or narrower] lateral halves, next each other: or one of which the feathers are incongruous; one in the contr. case being termed luWaAmN: or one that does not go far. (TA.) ― -b3- riyXa bilagobK [It (an arrow) was feathered with bad feathers]. ― -b4- A surname of a man, brother
of Taäbbata-Sharran: (TA:) incorrectly written by J riyXu lagobK. (K.) ― -b5- lagobN (tropical:) Corrupt, or vitious, speech, or discourse; (K;) not rightly aimed, directed, or disposed; evil, bad, foul. (TA.) ― -b6- kufRa EanRaA lagobaka Turn away from us thine evil, corrupt, or foul, speech. (TA.) ― -b7- lagobN (like wagobN, TA) and laguwbN↓ (tropical:) A weak, stupid, man. (S, K.) See an ex. voce kitaAbN. ― -b8- lagobN The flesh that is between the vanaAyaA, or four front teeth. (K.)

lagabN c
lagabN: see lagobN. ― -b2- Oaxaca bilagabi raqabatihi He overtook him. (K.)

lagibN c
lagibN: see lagobN.

laAgibN c
laAgibN and lagobaAnu↓ Fatigued, tired, or wearied; or so in the utmost degree. ― -b2- saAgibN laAgibN and sagobaAnu lagobaAnu: see art. sgb. (TA, art. sgb.) riyaAHN lawaAgibu (tropical:) [Languid winds.]. (TA.)

lugaAbN c
lugaAbN: see lagobN.

lagiybN c
lagiybN: see lagobN.

lugaAbapN c
lugaAbapN: see 1.

lugobaAnu c
lugobaAnu: see laAgib.

malogabapN c
malogabapN [A cause of fatigue, tiring, or weariness]: from [AllRagobu as signifying] AlUiEobaACu: pl. malaAgibu. (TA.)

lagiyvN c
lagiyvN i. q. galiyvN, (from which it is formed by transposition, TA,) in its two meanings: (K:) wheat mixed with barley; like bagiyvN: (TA:) [and food mixed with poison, by which vultures are killed].

lugRaAvN c
lugRaAvN [pl. of laAgivN] Sellers of wheat mixed with barley; as also bugRaAvN. (L.)

1 lagada c
1. lagada, (aor.
lagada
, T, L, K, inf. n. lagodN, T, L,) He made camels to turn back to the right way, or road: (S, L, K:) or he made camels to keep to the road, or, to the right way. (T, L.) ― -b2- lagadahu, inf. n. lagodN, He hit, or hurt, his lugoduwd. (IKtt.)

lugodN c
lugodN and lugoduwdN↓ and ligodiydN↓ A certain portion of flesh in the Haloq [or fauces]: or what resembles redundant portions of flesh within the ear [more fully described below]: or the flesh which surrounds the furthest part of the mouth, towards the Haloq [or fauces]: (K:) pl. (of lgd, S) OalogaAdN; and (of lgdwd, S, and lgdyd, TA) lagaAdiydu: (S, K:) or the AlgAd are portions of flesh by the lahaAp; also called lagaAniynu [and lgAdyd]: (A'Obeyd, L:) or the lgAdyd↓ are what resemble redundant portions of flesh within the two ears, inside the mouth; also called the nagaAnig, and the lagaAniyn: (Zj, in his Khalk el-Insán:) [see Alfunadobapu:] or the portions of flesh that are between the Hanak [here app. signifying the soft palate] and the side of the neck; as also the AlgAd: (S:) or outer part of the lgAnyn, which is a name given to the flesh between the nakafataAni and the tongue, internally: (AZ, L:) or the lgd is in the place of the nkftAn, at the root of the neck; also called lgdwd↓ and lgdyd↓: (TA:) or the interior of the naSiyl [or part between the neck and head, beneath the jaw-bone,] between the Hanak [here app. meaning as explained above] and the side of the neck; as also lgdyd↓, and lgdwdAni↓, (JK,) for this description applies to two parts [corresponding each to the other, on the right and left]: (L:) [in the present day it is applied, with apparent correctness, to the gill, or gills, or flesh beneath the lower jaw, of a man or woman, whether in the middle or on either side, and more especially when large:] or the place where ends, at its lower part, the lobe of the ear; (AZ, L, K;) and also called the nakafap: (AZ, L:) or the AlgAd and lgAdyd↓ are the roots of the two jaw-bones. (L.) ― -b2- EilojN Daxomu AllRagaAdiydi, and AlOalogaAdi, [A sturdy, and big, or coarse, man, large in the gills]. (A.) ― -b3- sabRaniI HatRaI OaHomaI lugodahu [He reviled me until he heated his gills; i. e.,] until he became hot (AiHotamaI) by reason of anger. (A.)

lugoduwdN c
lugoduwdN and ligodiydN: see lugodN throughout.

jaMCa mutalagRidFA c
jaMCa mutalagRidFA He came in a state of rage. (S, K. *)

1 lagazahu c
1. lagazahu, aor.
laguza
, (TK,) inf. n. lagozN, (IF, A, Msb, K,) He turned it from its proper mode or manner; distorted it. (IF, A, Msb, K, TA, TK.) ― -b2- [Hence,] lagaza jiHaratahu, and OalogazahaA↓, He (a jerboa) made his burrows winding, or tortuous, and perplexing to the enterer thereof. And lagaza fiI Haforihi, and Oalogaza↓, He pursued a winding, or tortuous, course in his burrowing. (A.)

2 lagRaza
2: see 4.

3 raOayotuhu yulaAgizuhu wayulaAmizuhu c
3. raOayotuhu yulaAgizuhu wayulaAmizuhu (tropical:) [I saw him talking enigmatically, or obscurely, with him, or to him, and making signs with him, or to him.] (A, TA.) [See also 3 in arts. Hjw and EI.]

4 Oalogaza
4: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Algz kalaAmahu, (A, K,) and Algz fiI kalaAmihi, (S, A, Msb, K,) signify alike: (K:) or the former, (tropical:) He made his speech, or language, enigmatical, or obscure; not plain: (A:) and the latter, (S, A,) or both, (K,) he made his meaning enigmatical, or obscure, in his speech, or language; (S, A, K;) as also lgRz↓: (A:) or the second, he used parabolical language: (Msb:) or both, he concealed a meaning different from that which he made apparent: or he was equivocal, or ambiguous, in his speech, or language, for the purpose of concealment: as in the following verse, cited by Fr:
walamRaA raOayotu AlnRasora EazRa Oabona daOuyapa
waEaXRaXa fiI wakorayohi jaAXato lahu nafosiI
(tropical:) [And when I saw that the vulture had overcome the raven, and nested in his nest, (lit., in his two nests,) my soul, or stomach, heaved thereat]: the poet likens hoariness to the vulture, because of its whiteness [or grayness]; and youthfulness to the black raven, because the hair of youth is black. (TA.) You say also, Algz fiI yamiynihi (tropical:) He practised [equivocation, or ambiguity, (see lugRayozaI,) or] concealment, [by a mental reservation, or otherwise,] towards the person sworn to, in his oath: the doing of which is forbidden. (A.)

lagozN c
lagozN: see lugazN, throughout.

lugazN c
lugazN: see lugazN, throughout.

lagazN c
lagazN: see lugazN, throughout.

lugazN c
lugazN (S, A, K) and lugozN↓ and lagozN↓ (K) and lagazN↓ and lugayozaMCu↓ (TA) A winding, or tortuous, excavation or burrow: this is the primary signification: (IAar, in explanation of lugozN:) the burrow of a jerboa, which he makes between the qaASiEaMC and naAfiqaMC, burrowing strait downwards, and then turning crosswise to the right and left, so that his place becomes concealed: (S, K, * TA:) or the burrow of the [lizard called] DabR, and of the jerboa, (A, K,) and of the rat or mouse: (K:) pl. [of the first four] OalogaAzN. (S, A.) ― -b2- Hence, (K,) OalogaAzN (tropical:) Winding, or tortuous, roads, or ways, perplexing to him who pursues them. (A, * K.) You say, Uilozami AljaAdRapa waUiyRaAka waAlOalogaAza (tropical:) [Keep thou to the main road, and avoid the winding, or tortuous, by-ways, which perplex him who pursues them]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- Hence also, (S,) lugazN (S, A, Sgh, Msb, K [omitted in the copies of the K consulted by the author of the TA, through inadvertence, as he observes, but mentioned in the CK,]) and lugozN↓ [which is now the most common form] and luguzN↓ and lagazN↓ (Sgh, K) and lugRayozaI↓, (S, K,) with teshdeed to the g, and not a dim., because the I of the dim. does not occupy a fourth place, but like xuDRaAraI and XuqRaAraI, (S,) and lugayozaMCu↓, (Az, K,) like HumayoraMCu, (K,) [and app. lugRayozaMCu↓ also, with teshdeed, (see what follows,)] and OuloguwzapN↓, (K,) (tropical:) An enigma; a riddle; enigmatical, or obscure, language: (S, A, K:) or parabolical language: (Msb:) pl. (of the first four, K, TA) OalogaAzN. (S, A, Msb, K.) And in like manner, yamiynN lugRayozaMCu↓, accord. to Z, with teshdeed to the g mentioned by Sb with xulRayoTaMCu, or, accord. to Az, without teshdeed, [lugayozaMCu,] which he regards as the dim. of the form with teshdeed, like as
sukayotN is of sukRayotN, (tropical:) An oath in which is equivocation, or ambiguity, and concealment [by mental reservation or otherwise]. (TA.)

luguzN c
luguzN: see lugazN.

lagRaAzN c
lagRaAzN (tropical:) One who often, or habitually, speaks evil of others in their absence; (K, TA;) as though he did so in equivocal or ambiguous language. (TA.)

lugayozaMCu c
lugayozaMCu: see lugazN, in three places.

lugRayozaI c
lugRayozaI and lugRayozaMCu: see lugazN; the second in two places.

OuloguwzapN c
OuloguwzapN: see lugazN.

1 lagaTa c
1. lagaTa, aor.
lagaTa
, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. lagoTN (S, Msb, TA) and lagaTN, (TA,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) and ligaATN; (S, TA;) and lgRT↓; (K;) and AlgT↓, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. AilogaATN; (S, Mgh;) He spoke clamorously, confusedly, and indistinctly: (Msb:) or, said of a number of men, (S, Mgh, K,) they uttered a sound, noise, or cry; and a clamour, confused noise, or mixture of voices or cries: (S, K:) or they uttered indistinct, and unintelligible sounds or noises or cries. (Mgh, K.) And lagaTa, aor.
lagaTa
, inf. n. lagoTN and lagiyTN, is said of the pigeon, and of the [bird called] qaTaA, [meaning, It uttered its cry, or cries;] (K;) or of each of these you say, lagaTa biSawotihi, and AlgT↓. (TA.) [Hence,] Oatayotuhu qabola lagiyTi AlqaTaA, and lagoTihi, [I came to him before the crying of the katà,] meaning, early in the morning. (TA.) [See also laAgiTN.]

2 lagRaTa
2: see 1.

4 OalogaTa
4: see 1, in two places. ＝ -A2- AlgT labanahu, (L, K,) inf. n. as above, (L,) He threw heated stones into his milk, and so caused it to make the sound termed naXiyX. (L, K.)

lagoTN c
lagoTN: see what next follows.

lagaTN c
lagaTN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and lagoTN↓ (Ks, K) Clamorous, confused, and indistinct, speech: (Msb:) or sound, noise, or cry; and clamour, confused noise, or a mixture of voices or cries: (S, K:) or indistinct and unintelligible sounds or noises or cries: (Mgh, K:) pl. OalogaATN, (K,) of the latter as well as of the former. (TA.) You say, samiEotu lagaZa Alqawomi [I heard the clamorous, and confused, and indistinct speech, &c., of the people, or company of men]. (TA.)

laAgiTN c
laAgiTN [part. n. of 1]. You say, Oatayotuhu qabola AlqaTaA AllRaAgiTi [I came to him before the crying katà], meaning, early in the morning: pl. lugRaTN. (TA.) [See also 1.]

1 lafaOa c
1. lafaOa, aor.
lafaAa
, inf. n. lafoCN and lafaMCN; and AltfO↓; He stripped off, or peeled off, (K,) meat from a bone. (AZ, S.) ― -b2- lafaOati AlrRiyHu AlsRaHaAba Eano wajohi AlsRamaMCi (assumed tropical:) [The wind stripped off the clouds from the face of the sky]. (S.) ― -b3- lafaOa, inf. n. lafoCN, He peeled a bone (TA) or a stick. (S.) ― -b4- lafaOa He beat (S, K) with a staff or stick. (S.) ― -b5- He turned a person back, or away, from his purpose. (K.) ― -b6- lafaOa i. q. UigotaAba; (assumed tropical:) He traduced a person behind his back, or in his absence, but saying of him what was true. (K.) Thought to be tropical, from the same verb signifying “ he peeled. ” (TA.) ＝ -A2- lafiICa, aor.
lafaAa
, He, or it remained, or endured. (K.) ＝ -A3- lafaOahu HaqRahu He gave him the whole of what was due to him: (like lakaOahu: T:) or lfOh signifies he gave him less than his due. (K.) Accord. to Aboo-Turab, the verb is used in these two contr. senses. (TA.)

4 AlfO c
4. AlfO He caused to remain, or endure. (K.)

8 UilotafaAa
8: see 1.

lafaMCN c
lafaMCN Deficiency: (IAth:) raDiytu mina AlwafaMCi biAllRafaMCi [I was content with a deficiency instead of full payment]: from a trad. (TA.) ― -b2- Less than what is just, or right. (K.) ― -b3- A little thing; a little. (K.) ― -b4- Dust; earth. (K.) ― -b5- Small bits of rubbish on the ground. (TA.)

lafiyoYapN c
lafiyoYapN A piece of meat stripped off, or peeled off, from a bone: (TA:) a piece of meat in which is no bone: (S:) pl. lafiIoCN [but this is rather a coll. gen. n., or it is doubtful] and lafaAyaA. (TA.)

1 lafatahu c
1. lafatahu, aor.
lafita
, (K,) inf. n. lafotN, (S,) He twisted, wrung, or turned, him, or it, (S, K), in a way different from his, or its, [proper] direction: as when you grasp a man's throat, and twist or wring it. (TA.) ― -b2- tilofitu Albaqarapu AlxalaI bilisaAnihaA [The cow turns about the fresh herb with her tongue]. (S, from a trad.) [For AlxalaA, as in copies of the S, I have substituted AlxalaI. To this action is likened a hypocrite's reading of the Kur-án.] ― -b3- lafatahu He twisted, or wrung, his neck, and broke it; as also Eafatahu and Hafatahu. (Az, in TA, art. Hft.) ― -b4- lafatahu Almawotu Death took him away suddenly; as also falatahu. (T, TA, art. flt) ― -b5- lafatahu, aor.
lafita
, inf. n. lafotN, He turned him aside, to the right or left. (Msb.) ― -b6- lafatahu Eini AlXRaIoCi aor.
lafita
, inf. n. lafotN, He turned away, averted, or diverted, him from the thing. (TA.) So in the Kur, x., 79. (Fr.) ― -b7- maA lafataka Eano fulaAnK What hath turned thee away, or averted thee, or diverted thee, from such a one (Fr.) ― -b8- lafatahu Eano raOoyihi (tropical:) He turned him from his opinion. (S, K.) ― -b9- lafata wajohahu EanRiI He turned away, or averted, his face from me. (S.) ― -b10- lafata AlmaAXiyapa, aor.
lafita
, (inf. n. lafotN, TA,) He beat the camels or sheep or goats, not caring which of them he struck. (K.) ― -b11- lafata AlokalaAma, aor.
lafita
, inf. n. lafotN, (tropical:) He sent forth, or uttered, words, without caring what might be the meaning. (TA.) ＝ -A2- lafata XayoYFA, [aor.
lafita
,] inf. n. lafotN, He stirred a thing about and over, like as flour is stirred about and over with clarified butter, &c. (TA.) [See lafiytapN.] ― -b2- lafata AllRiHaMCa Eani AlXRajari He removed, or pulled off, the peel, or rind, from the trees: (K:) or, accord. to the A, Eani AlEuwdi from the twig, or branch. (TA.) ― -b3- lafata AlrRiyXa EalaI AlsRahomi He put the feathers upon the arrow not so that they were well-composed, or equal, or even, or uniform, (gayora mutalaAYimK [i. e., not so that they were what is termed luWaAm,]) but as they happened to be. (K.)

5 talafRata
5: see 8.

8 Altft c
8. Altft and tlfRt↓, (S, K,) [He looked aside, or about,] the latter of which signifies more than the former, (S,) are from lafatahu Eano raOoyihi: (K:) you say, Altft UilaI AlXRaIoCi, and Uilayohi tlfRt↓, He turned his face towards the thing. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, mA Altft Uilayohi He regarded not him or it; he paid no regard, or attention, to him or it. (The lexicons, &c., passim.)] ― -b3- Altft biwajohihi yamiynFA waXimaAlFA He turned his face to the right and left. (Msb.)

lifotN c
lifotN The half of a thing; syn. XqRN: and its side; syn. SigowN: (S, K;) i. e., jaAnibN. (TA.) ― -b2- laA talotafito lifota fulaAnK Look not towards such a one. (S.) ＝ -A2- A cow, or bull; syn. baqarapN. (K.) ＝ -A3- A woman who is stupid, foolish, or of little sense. (K.) See also Oalofatu. ＝ -A4- The vulva of a lioness. (K.) ＝ -A5- [A name now given in Egypt to the Brassica napus of Linn., a edulis; (Delile, Flor. Aeg., No. 597;) the rape;] i. q. salojamN [a name given in Egypt to the Brassica napus of Linn., β oleifera: (Delile, ubi supra, No. 598:)] (S, K:) Az. says, “ I have not heard it from any person confided in for accuracy, and know not whether it be Arabic or not: ” (TA:) Ibn-El-Kubbee asserts it to be a Nabathean word. (MF.)

lafatN c
lafatN The having one of his horns twisted upon, or over, the other. Said of a he-goat. (S.)

lufatapN c
lufatapN A man who beats (much TA) his camels or sheep or goats, not caring which of them he strikes. (K.)

lafaAtN c
lafaAtN: see Oalofatu.

lafuwtN c
lafuwtN A woman who looks aside much, or often, at things. (TA.) ― -b2- A woman who, when she hears a man speak, looks aside towards him. ('Abd-el-Melik Ibn-'Omar.) ― -b3- A woman whose eye does not remain fixed towards one place, the object of whose care is that thou shouldst be heedless of her, and that she may make signs with her eyes, or the like, to another. (Th, K.) ― -b4- A woman who has a husband, and who has a child by another husband, (S, K,) and who therefore turns her regard much towards her child, (S,) and is occupied by him so as to be diverted from her husband. (TA.) ― -b5- A she-camel that is unquiet (DajuwrN) on the occasion of her being milked, (K,) that looks aside at the milker, and bites him; wherefore he strikes her with his hand, and thereupon she yields her milk: this is the case when her young one has died: whence this epithet is proverbially applied to him who is disobedient. (TA.) ― -b6- Difficult, or stubborn, of disposition. (K.) But in the S is said what is at variance with this. (TA.) See lafaAtN, mentioned with Oalofatu, ― -b7- Accord. to some, A woman in whom is crookedness and contraction; expl. by AltI fyhA AltwAC wAnqbAD. (TA.) ― -b8- A woman went to calumniate, or slander. (A in art. xft.)

lafiytapN c
lafiytapN [A certain kind of gruel] made by straining water [or juice, or a decoction,] of the white colocynth, then putting it into a stone cookingpot, and cooking it until it has become thoroughly done and thickened, and then sprinkling flour upon it: (AHn:) or thickened EaSiydap: (IAth, K:) or thick ESydp (S) of habiyd, i. e. HanoZal, [or colocynth]: (TA:) so called because it is stirred about and over liOanRahaA tulofatu OaIo tulowaI: (S:) [see lafata XayoYFA:] or broth resembling Hayos: (K:) i. q. EafiytapN. (TA, art. Eft.) [See also waTiyYap.]

Oalofatu c
Oalofatu Strong-handed, who hoists, or wrings, him who strives, or grapples, with him. (TA.) ― -b2- A he-goat having crooked horns. (TA.) lafotaACu A she-goat having crooked horns. (K.) ― -b3- A he-goat having one of his horns twisted (S, K) upon, or over the other. (S.) ― -b4- lafotaACu A woman having distorted eyes; syn. HawolaACu. (K.) ― -b5- Oalofatu (in the dial. of Keys, S) Stupid; foolish; of little sense; (S, K;) like OaEofatu (S) [and OaEofaku]: fem. lafotaACu: [see also lifotN:] so too lafaAtN↓: (K:) or this signifies stupid, foolish, or of little sense, and of difficult, or stubborn disposition: (S:) [see also lafuwtN:] or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, as mentioned in a marginal note in a copy of the S, lafaAtN↓ and its syn. hafaAtN are correctly written lafaApN and hafaApN, for in a case of pause they are pronounced lafaAho and hafaAho: see hafaAtN. (TA.) ― -b6- (In the dial. of Temeem, S,) Left-handed; who works with the left hand; (S, K;) as also Oalofaku. (TA.)

AlmutalafRitapu c
AlmutalafRitapu The highest bone in the place where the head joins the neck. (L.)

10 Astlfv maA Einodahu c
10. Astlfv maA Einodahu He elicited, and exhausted, (UisotanobaTa waQsotaqoSaI,) what [information, &c.] he had, or possessed. (K.) ― -b2- Astlfv AlrRiEoIa He consumed the whole of the pasture, leaving nothing of it. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Astlfv HaAjatahu He accomplished his want. (K.) ― -b4- Astlfv Alxabara He concealed the news. (K.)

Oalofavu c
Oalofavu Stupid; foolish; of little sense: (K:) like Oalofatu. (TA.)

4 Oalofaja c and Oulofija
4. Oalofaja Oulofija He (a man) clave to the ground by reason of sorrow, grief, or solicitude, or of want. (L.) ― -b2- Alfj, inf. n. UilofaAjN, He, or it, constrained, compelled, or necessitated, a person, to have recourse to one, or to others, not of his family; (K;) constrained him to beg of such. (L.) ― -b3- OalofajaniI UilaI celika AlUiDoTiraAru Necessity constrained me to have recourse to that. (AZ.) ― -b4- Oalofaja, [not Oulofija, as might be thought from the signification of the part. n. mulofajN,] (inf. n. UilofaAjN; S;) and Astlfj↓; (L:) He became a bankrupt; syn. Oafolasa: (S, K:) he was, or became, poor: (TA:) he became destitute, possessing nothing. (A 'Obeyd.)

10 Astlfj c
10. Astlfj: see 4. ― -b2- Also, He was, or became, constrained to have recourse to a thing: or was in need. (TA.)

lafojN c
lafojN Abasement; abjectness. (IAar, K.)

lufojN c
lufojN The channel of a torrent. (L.)

mulofajN c
mulofajN (S, K) and mulofijN↓ (ISk) and musotalofajN↓ (K) or musotalofijN (as in the L.) A man in a state of bankruptcy: a bankrupt; syn. mufolisN: (S, K:) or the former, poor: (ISk:) or a bankrupt and in debt: (IAth:) or destitute; possessing nothing: (A 'Obeyd:) the first extr. [with respect to rule], (S, K,) like muHoSanN from OaHoSana, and musohaba from Oasohaba. (S.) [See musohabN.]

mulofijN c
mulofijN: see mulofajN.

musotalofajN c
musotalofajN, (as in the K,) or musotalofijN↓, (as in the L [and this latter I think the correct mode of writing the word in all the senses here explained, for I do not find it noted as extr. with respect to rule like mulofajN,]) [part. n. of 10, q. v.: and] i. q. mulofajN, q. v. (K.) ― -b2- One whose heart forsakes him, or fails him, by reason of fear, or fright. (K.) ― -b3- Cleaving to the ground by reason of emaciation, (K,) or of sorrow, grief, or solicitude, or of want; as also mlfj [i. e. mulofijN and mulofajN: see 4]. (TA.)

musotalofijN c
musotalofijN: see musotalofajN.

1 lafaHatohu AlnRaAru c
1. lafaHatohu AlnRaAru, (S, M, K,) aor.
lafaHa
, (M,) inf. n. lafoHN and lafaHaAnN, (M, K,) The fire smote, or hurt, his face; as also lfHt wajohahu: (M, O:) the fire burned him; (TA;) as also nfHth AlnAr biHarRihaA; (S, K;) and in like manner the hot wind called samuwm: (S:) lafaHato and nafaHato are syn., except that the effect of AlnRafoH is greater than that of AllRafoH: (Zj:) or lafoHN relates to a hot wind; and nafoHN, to a cold, or cool, wind: (As, S:) you also say lfHth AlsRamuwm meaning the smwm blew in his face. (L.) ― -b2- Also lafaHahu, aor.
lafaHa
, He smote, or struck, him, with a sword, (S, K,) lightly, or slightly: you say lafaHotuhu biAlsRayofi lafoHapF I struck him with the sword a light, or slight, blow. (S.)

OaSaAbaha lfoHN mino HaruwrK wasamuwmK c
OaSaAbaha lfoHN mino HaruwrK wasamuwmK A burning gust of hot night-wind, and of hot day-wind, smote him. (L.) ― -b2- OaSaAbahu mina AlHarRi lafoHN wamina Albarodi nafoHN [A blast of heat smote him, and a blast of cold]. (A.) ― -b3- You say also lawaAfiHu AlsRamuwim [pl. of laAfiHapN↓, and meaning Burning blasts of the smwm]. (S, K in art. sfE.)

lafoHapN c
lafoHapN A light, or slight, blow with a sword. (S.)

luqRaAHN c
luqRaAHN A certain well known plant, (K,) of the kind termed yaqoTiyniIRN, (L,) which people smell, (S.) yellow, and of sweet odour, (A, L,) resembling the baAcinojaAn (S, A, K,) when it becomes yellow; (S, A;) [accord. to Golius, app. on the authority of Ibn-Beytár, the same which the Syrians and Egyptians call XamRaAmN, q. v.]. ― -b2- Also, The fruit, or produce, (vamarap,) of the yaboruwH [or mandrake, which is called by this name (ybrwH) in the present day]; (K;) thus correctly written, with the I before the b [not bbrwH, as in the CK and some MS. copies]. (TA.) [It seems that the application of the term lfRAH to both the mandrake and the XmRAm has led to confusion, and occasioned Linnæus to call the latter “ cucumis dudaim. ” See also yaboruwHN, and magodN.]

laAfiHapN c
laAfiHapN: see lafoHN.

1 lafaZahu c
1. lafaZahu, (S, M, Msb, K,) and lafaZa bihi, (M, K,) aor.
lafiZa
, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. lafoZN; (T, S, M, Msb;) and lafiZahu, and lafiZa bihi, aor.
lafiZa
; (Ibn-
Abbád, K.) but the former is that which is commonly known; (TA;) He ejected it; cast it forth; [disgorged it;] (T, S, M, Msb, K;) namely a thing that was in his mouth; (T;) his spittle, &c.; (Msb;) from (mino) his mouth. (S, TA.) And lafaZa alone, [elliptically,] He ejected what had entered between his teeth, of food. (TA.) You say also, lafaZati AlHayRapu samRahaA (tropical:) [The serpent ejected its poison.] (TA.) And lafaZa EaSobahu, lit. He ejected his spittle that stuck and dried in his mouth; meaning (tropical:) he died; (T, TA;) as also lafaZa nafosahu, aor.
lafiZa
, inf. n. as above; (M, TA;) and lafaZa alone. (M, K.) And jaMCa waqado lafaZa lijaAmahu, [as to the letter and the meaning like jaMCa waqado dalaqa lijaAmahu,] (tropical:) He came harassed, or distressed, by thirst and fatigue. (Ibn-'Abbád, M, Z, K.) And lafaZati AlrRaHimu maMCa AlfaHoli (tropical:) The womb ejected the seminal fluid of the stallion. (TA.) And lafaZahu AlbaHoru (assumed tropical:) The sea cast it forth upon the shore; (Msb, TA;) namely a fish; (TA;) or a beast. (Msb.) And lafaZa AlbaHoru bimaA fiyhi UilaI AlXRuTuwTi (assumed tropical:) The sea cast forth what was within it to the shores. (M.) And qaMCati AlOaroDu OukolahaA walafaZato xabiyoYahaA (tropical:) The earth disclosed her vegetables, and revealed her hidden things. (TA in this art. and in art. qyO.) And lafaZati AlOaroDu AlmayRita (assumed tropical:) The earth cast forth the dead; (T, Msb;) did not receive, or admit, the dead. (M.) And lafaZati AlbilaAdu OaholahaA (tropical:) [The countries cast forth their inhabitants]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] lafaZa biAlkalaAmi, (S, K,) and biqawolK, (Msb,) and biAlXRaIoCi, (M,) and lafaZa Alqawola, (TA,) aor.
lafiZa
, inf. n. lafoZN, (M,) He uttered, spoke forth, or pronounced, (S, M, Msb, K,) the saying, (S, K,) and a saying, (Msb,) and the thing; (M;) as also bihi tlfRZ↓. (S, Msb, K.) It is said in the Kur, [l. 17,] maA yalofiZu mino qawolK (tropical:) [He doth not utter a saying]: where Kh. reads mA yalofaZu: both forms of the verb being used in this sense [as is implied in the K.]. (TA.)

5 talafRaZa
5: see 1, last signification.

lafoZN c
lafoZN, originally an inf. n., (S, Msb,) is used as a subst., (Msb,) signifying (tropical:) An expression; i. e. a word; [more precisely termed lafoZapN↓;] and also a collection of words, a phrase, or sentence; (I'Ak &c.;) [each considered as such, without regard to its meaning; a word itself; and a phrase itself;] the latter also called lafoZN murakRabN, a compound expression, an expression composed of two or more words: (Expos. of the Ajroomeeyeh, by the sheykh Khálid; &c.:) and malofaZN↓ signifies the same (TA:) pl. of the former OalofaAZN; (S, Msb;) dim. OulayofaAZN: (Har., p. 595) and of the latter malaAfiZ. (TA.) [Hence, lafoZFA wamaEonFI (tropical:) With respect to the word, or words, or wording, and the meaning: and with respect to the actual order of the words; and the order of the sense. And lafoZFA warutobapF (tropical:) With respect to the actual order of the words, and the order of the proper relative places. And lafoZFA wataqodiyrFA (tropical:) Literally and virtually. And laA waAHida lahu mino lafoZihi (tropical:) It has no singular formed of the same radical letter: i. e., it has no proper singular: said of a word such as qawomN and rahoTN &c.] ― -b2- See also lufaAZN.

lafoZapN c
lafoZapN: see lafoZN.

lafoZiIRN c
lafoZiIRN [Of, or relating to, a word, or collection of words, verbal:] opposed to maEonawiIRN.

lafaZaAnN c
lafaZaAnN Loquacious; a great talker: but this is a vulgar word. (TA.)

lufoAZN c
lufoAZN [app. a coll. gen. n., of which lufaAZapN↓, q. v., is the n. un., as seems to be indicated in the S, TA,] What is cast, or thrown, away; (M, TA;) as also lafoZN↓: the latter on the authority of IB. (TA.)

lifaAZN c
lifaAZN (assumed tropical:) Leguminous plants [put forth by the earth]. (Sgh, K.)

lafiyZN c
lafiyZN and malofuwZN↓ Ejected; cast forth. (M, K.) ― -b2- (tropical:) [Uttered, spoken forth, or pronounced.]

lufaAZapN c
lufaAZapN What is ejected, or cast forth, from the mouth: (S, K:) such as particles of the toothstick, or stick with which the teeth are cleaned: (TA:) and what is cast, or thrown, away, of food: pl. lufaAZaAtN: (Har, p.W#x661;W#x668;W#x665;:) see also lufaAZN. ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) A remain, remainder, or residue, of a thing, (K, TA,) little in quality. (TA.)

laAfiZN c
laAfiZN [act. part. n. of 1: fem. with p]. You say, fulAanN laAfiZN (tropical:) Such a one is dying. (TA.) ― -b2- AllRaAfiZapN The she-goat, (T, S, M, K,) or ewe; (M, K;) because she is called to be milked, while ruminating, and thereupon ejects her cud, and comes joyfully to be milked: (T, * S, M, * K: *) or the bird that feeds her young one from her beak; because she puts forth what is in her inside and gives it for food: (S, K *:) or the domestic cock; (S, K;) because he takes the grain with his beak, and does not eat it, but throws it to the hen: (K:) or (tropical:) the mill; (T, S, M, K;) because it casts forth what it grinds, (T, TA,) of the flour: (TA:) or (tropical:) the sea; (S, M, K;) as also laAfiZapu, determinate [as a proper name]; (K;) because it casts forth (S, M) what is in it, (M,) [namely] ambergris and jewels: (S:) in this last sense, and as applied to the cock, (Sgh,) the p is to give intensiveness to the signification. (S, Sgh.) It has one or another of these significations in the saying, AsomaHu mino laAfiZapK [More liberal, or bountiful, than a she-goat, &c.,] (T, S, K,) and OasoxaI mino laAfiZapK (M, TA) and Oajowadu mino laAfiZapK [which mean the same]. (TA.) laAfiZapN also signifies Any bird that feeds his female, (T,) or that feeds his young bird, (M, K,) from his beak. (T, M, K.) And AllRaAfiZapu (tropical:) The earth; because it casts forth the dead. (TA.) And (tropical:) The present world; because it casts forth those who are in it to the world to come. (T, K, TA.)

malofaZN c
malofaZN: see lafoZN.

malofuwZN c
malofuwZN: see lafiyZN.

dictScrap.label: lfE lfq lfm lq: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
2 lqRbhu bikacaA c
2. lqRbhu bikacaA, inf. n. taloqiybN, He called him, or named him, by such a by-name, or surname, or nickname; he surnamed him, or nicknamed him, so. (S, K.) See laqabN. ― -b2- lqRb AlUisoma biAlfiEoli [i. e., biAlfaACi waAlEayoni waAllRaAmi] He called the noun by an appellation in which its radical letters were represented by f, E, and l; this appellation being its measure; as when jaworabN is called fawoEalN. (TA.) [But this signification belongs to the conventional language of lexicology and grammar.]

5 tlqRb bikacaA c
5. tlqRb bikacaA He was by-named, surnamed, or nicknamed, so. (S, K.) See laqabN.

3 laAqabahu c
3. laAqabahu, inf. n. mulaAqabapN, He called him by a byname, surname, or nickname; the latter doing to him the like. (TA.)

6 talaAqabuwA c
6. talaAqabuwA They called one another by by-names, surnames, or nicknames. (TA.)

laqabN c
laqabN A by-name; a surname; a nickname; syn. nabazN: (S, K:) a name of reproach; an opprobrious appellation: in this sense forbidden: (Msb:) it is said in the Kur, xlix., 11, laA tanaAbazuwA biQloOaloqaAbi Call not one another by nicknames; i. e., let not one of you call another by a name which he dislikes: (Jel:) also a by-name, or surname, which is not one of reproach: such are the surnames given to certain Imáms; AlOanomaXu and
AlOaxofaXu and AlARaEoraju and the like; and such are not forbidden, because by them is not meant reproach, or disparagement, but they are meant as mere appellations given with the approval of the persons to whom they are applied. (Msb.) [A laqab is distinguished from a kunoyap, q. v.] Pl. OaloqaAbN. (S, K.) ― -b2- [laqabu QsomK The appellation given to a noun by substituting f, E, and l for its radical letters. See 2.]

1 laqava c
1. laqava, [aor.
laquva
,] inf. n. laqovN; and lqRv↓, inf. n. taloqiyvN; He mixed [a thing]. (K.) [The former verb is as above accord. to the TK: but it seems to be implied in the K that it is laqiva, aor. laqiva, as well in the above sense as in that here following.] ― -b2- laqiva, aor.
laqiva
, inf. n. laqovN, He took [a thing] quickly, and altogether. (K.) But this is not of established authority. (TA.)

2 laqRava
2: see 1.

1 laqiHato c
1. laqiHato, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
laqaHa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. laqaHN (S, Msb, K,) and laqoHN (K) and laqaAHN; (S, K;) and luqiHato biAlowaladi, in the pass. form; (Msb;) She (a camel) conceived, or became pregnant; (Msb, TA;) received [into her womb] the seed of the stallion. (K.) ― -b2- laqiHato (inf. n. laqaHN, syn. HabalN, K, TA: in the CK jabalN:) (tropical:) She (a woman) conceived, or became pregnant. (Sh, T, L.) ― -b3- AimoraOapN sariyEapu AllRaqaHi A woman quick in conceiving, or becoming pregnant. The like is said with respect to any female. Perhaps the word thus used has this signification properly, or perhaps tropically. (TA.) ― -b4- OasarRato laqaHFA, and laqaAHFA, She (a camel) concealed her having conceived, or become pregnant: i. e., she did not show signs of her having conceived by raising her tail and elevating her nose. (L.) ― -b5- laqiHati AlnRaxiylu, or luqiHat, (as in different copies of the S,) (tropical:) [The palm-trees became fecundated by the process termed UiloqaAHN: see 4]: and of a single palm-tree (naxolapN) you say laqiHato, or luqiHato, without teshdeed; (so, again, in different copies of the S;) and talaqRaHato↓. (S, art. Obr) ― -b6- laqiHa AlEijaAfu, inf. n. laqaHN, (tropical:) The lands in which was no good became fecundated. (L.) [See also OaEojafu.] ― -b7- laqiHati AlHarobu: see a verse cited voce En.

2 laqRaHa
2: see 4.

4 AlqH AlfaHolu AlnRaAqapa c
4. AlqH AlfaHolu AlnRaAqapa, (S, Msb,) inf. n. UiloqaAHN; (Msb;) and lqRHhA↓, (A,) [inf. n. taloqiyHN;] The stallion-camel made the she-camel to conceive, or become pregnant; impregnated her; got her with young. (Msb.) ― -b2- AlqH AlnRaxolapa, inf. n. UiloqaAHN, [and quasi-inf. n. laqaAHN, q. v.; et vide infra;] and lqRHhA↓, inf. n. taloqiyHN; (S, Msb, A, K;) and laqaHahaA↓, inf. n. laqoHN; (K;) (tropical:) He fecundated the palm-tree by means of the laqaAH↓, or spadix of the male tree, which is bruised, or brayed, and sprinkled [upon the spadix of the female]: (A:) or, by inserting a stalk of a raceme of the male tree into the spathe [of the female, after shaking off the pollen of the former upon the spadix of the female; for such is the general practice]: this is done in the following manner: you leave the spathe of the [female] palm-tree two or three nights after its bursting open: then you take a stalk of a raceme of the male tree, which is best if old, of the preceding year, and insert it into the spadix [of the female, after shaking off the pollen, as above mentioned]; and this you do according to a certain measure: it should not be done but by a man acquainted with the manner of proceeding in this case; for if he be ignorant, and do too much, he turns the spathe, and mars it; and if he do too little, many of the dates produced will be without stones; and if he do it not at all to the palm-tree, he will derive no advantage from the spadix thereof that year: (L:) laqaHN↓ is the name of that which is taken from the male palm-tree (AlfuHRaAl: so in the L: in the K, AlfaHol:) to be inserted in the other, [namely the spathe of the female]. (L, K.) [See also laqaAHN. In the CK, for Uisomu maA Ouxica Alx, we find Asm mACK Axc Alx, giving a different and false meaning.] jaMCanaA zamanu AllRaqaAHi, or AltRaloqiyHi↓, The time of the fecundating of the palm-trees has come to us. (L.) ― -b3- OaloqaHati AlrRiyHu AlsRaHaAba (S) (tropical:) The wind impregnated, or fecundated, the cloud, or clouds; (L;) and in like manner, AlqHt AlrRiyaAHu AlXRajara wanaHowahu [The winds fecundated the trees] (K) [and the like]. (TA.) ― -b4- AlqH bayonahumo XarRFA (tropical:) He engendered, or caused, evil, or mischief, between them. (A.) ― -b5- Eaqolahu jarRaba AlOumuwra falaqRaHato↓ (tropical:) [He became experienced in affairs, and they fecundated his intellect]. (A.) ― -b6- AlnRaZaru fiI EawaAqibi QloOumwuri QloEuquwli taloqiyHu↓ (tropical:) [Consideration of the results, or issues, of things is (a means of) fecundation of the intellects]. (A.) ― -b7- laA tuloqiHo siloEataka biAlOayomaAni (tropical:) [Make not thy merchandise productive of a high price by means of oaths]. (A.)

5 tlqRHt c
5. tlqRHt She (a camel) pretended that she had conceived, or become pregnant, (by raising her tail, in order that the stallion might not approach her, TA,) when this was not really the case. (Fr, S, K.) ― -b2- See 1.

10 AstlqHt AlnRaxolapu c
10. AstlqHt AlnRaxolapu (tropical:) The palm-tree attained to the proper period for its being fecundated by the process termed UiloqaAHN: [see 4: or required to be so fecundated]. (K.)

laqaHN c
laqaHN: inf. n. of 1. q. v. ― -b2- see OaloqaHa AlnRaxolapa, and see laqaAHN.

laqoHapN c
laqoHapN: see liqoHapN and laquwHN.

liqoHapN c
liqoHapN (K) and laqoHapN↓ (TA) (assumed tropical:) A woman suckling; or a woman who suckles. (K.) ― -b2- See laquwHN.

laqaAHN c
laqaAHN (tropical:) The thing [namely flowers or pollen] with which a female palm-tree is fecundated, (S, L, K,) taken from a male palm-tree; (L;) the spadix of a male palm-tree, (A, K,) with which a female palm-tree is fecundated, it being bruised, or brayed, and sprinkled [upon the spadix of the female]. (A.) [See also laqaHN, voce OaloqaHa, and liqaAHN] ＝ -A2- HaIRN laqaAHN A tribe that does not submit to kings, (S, K,) and that has not been governed by a king: (L:) or, that has not suffered captivity in the time of paganism. (S, K.) ― -b2- See 1.

liqaAHN c
liqaAHN The semen genitale (L, K) of a stallion camel, and horse, and (tropical:) of a man. (L.) I'Ab, being asked respecting a man who had two wives, one of whom suckled a boy, and the other a girl, [not his own children,] whether the boy might marry the girl, answered “ No; because the lqAH [i. e., liqaAH or laqaAH↓, as shown below,] is one: ” meaning, says Lth, that the semen genitale which impregnated them both, and which was the source of the milk of both, was one, and that the two sucklings had thus become as though they were the children of the two women's husband: but, says Az, lqAH may here be a quasi-inf. n., syn. with UiloqaAHN; like EaTaMCN and UiEoTaMCN &c.: (L:) [and the like is said in the Msb.] laqaAHN↓ and liqaAHN, with fet-h and kesr, are substs. from OaloqaHa, [q. v.] syn. with UiloqaAHN, signifying impregnation, or the getting with young; and so in the answer of I'Ab above mentioned. (Msb.)

laquwHN c
laquwHN A camel (S, K) itself: (S:) pl. liqaAHN. (S, K.) ― -b2- See laAqiHN. ― -b3- laquwHN and liqoHapN↓ (S, Msb, K) and laqoHapN↓, (Msb, K,) applied to a she-camel, i. q. HaluwbN [meaning Milch, and a milch camel]: (S, Msb, K:) but Az says, that the former only is used as an epithet; you say nAqp laquwHN, and not nAqpN liqoHapN, but hecihi liqoHapN fulaAnK: (TA:) or laquwHN is [an epithet] applied to a she-camel during the first two or three months after her having brought forth; and after this she is termed labuwnN: (AA, S, K:) and accord. to some, liqoHapN↓ signifies a milch camel abounding with
milk: or a she-camel from the time when the hump of her young one becomes fat, until the expiration of seven months, when she weans her young one, and this she does at the [auroral] rising of Canopus: (TA:) [which rising, in central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight was between the 30th of July and the 12th of August:] also liqoHapN↓ and laqoHapN↓ a she-camel that has lately brought forth: (L:) pl. of laquwHN, liqaAHN (S, Msb, K) and laqaAYiHu; (ISh;) and pl. of liqoHapN↓ (and of laqoHapN↓, K, TA,) liqaHN (S, Msb, K) and liqaAHN. (ISh, Th, Msb.) ― -b4- The Arabs also said liqaAHaAni OasowadaAni [Two black herds of milch camels], like as they said qaTiyEaAni; for they said liqaAHN waAHidapN in like manner as they said qaTiyEN waAHidN and UibilN waAHidapN. (S.) ― -b5- Almusolimiyna OadirRuwA liqoHapa↓ (tropical:) Milk ye the milch camel of the Muslims: occurring in a trad., alluding to the tribute (faIoC and xaraAj) whence were derived the stipends and fixed appointments of the persons addressed, and to the collecting it with equity. (TA.)

laqRaAHN c
laqRaAHN A fecundator of palm-trees. (Az, TA in art. jnI.)

lAqiHN c
lAqiHN (IAar, S, K) and laquwHN↓ (K) and maloquwHapN↓ (Msb) A she-camel having just conceived, or become pregnant; (IAar, K;) as also qaAriHN: afterwards, when her pregnancy has become manifestly apparent, she is termed xalifapN: (IAar:) pl. of the former lawaAqiHu (K) and luqRaHN; (TA;) and of the second, luquHN. (L, K, TA: in the CK luqRaHN.) ― -b2- riyaAHN lawaAqiHu (S, K, &c.,) (tropical:) Pregnant winds; so called because they bear the water and the clouds, and turn the latter over and about, and then cause them to send down rain; (TA;) or because they become pregnant, and then impregnate the clouds: (IJ:) the sing. is riyHN laAqiHN, the contr. of which is termed riyHN EaqiymN [or “ a barren wind ”]: (ISd:) or ryH lAqH signifies caAtu laqalaAHK [possessing that which impregnates]; like as dirohamN waAzinN signifies cuw wazoni; rajulN raAmiHN, cuw rumoHK: (AHeyth:) or ryAH lwAqH signifies impregnating, or fecundating, winds; (S, K;) as also malaAqiHu↓ [pl. of muloqiHapN]: (K:) or it is not allowable to say malaAqiHu; (S;) but this is the regular form of the word; because the wind impregnates the clouds; (IJ;) and thus lwAqH is extr.: or, as some say, the proper original word is muloqiHapN; but the winds do not impregnate unless they are themselves pregnant; as though they were pregnant with good, and, when they raised the clouds, transmitted to them that good. (S.) ― -b3- HarobN laAqiHN (K) (tropical:) War pregnant [with great events.] (TA.)

muloqiHN c
muloqiHN A stallion camel: pl. malaAqiHu. (S, K.) ― -b2- See laAqiHN. ― -b3- (tropical:) A man to whom offspring is born. Occurring in a trad. (TA.)

muloqaHapN c
muloqaHapN A female camel that has her young one in her belly: pl. malaAqiHu: (S, K:) a pass. part. n. from OaloqaHa. (Msb.)

maloquwHapN c
maloquwHapN (IAar, S, K, &c.) and maloquwHN, (IAar,) which latter is also used in a pl. sense, (As,) What is in the belly of a she-camel: (A 'Obeyd, T, S, K, &c.:) or what is in the back of the stallion camel; [meaning his progeny in the elemental state;] (Aboo-Sa'eed, K;) but the former, says Az, is the correct signification: (L:) maloquwHapN is for maloquwHN bihi, converted into a subst., (Msb,) from luqiHato, like maHomuwmN from HumRa, and majonuwnN from junRa: (S:) pl. malaAqiyHu. (A 'Obeyd, S, K, &c.) The Muslims are forbidden to sell malaAqiyH and maDaAmiyn. (L.) [See the latter of these words.] ― -b2- AlmalaAqiyHu is also used (sometimes, TA) to signify The mothers: and its sing. is maloquwHapN. (K.) ― -b3- See laAqiHN.

1 laqisato nafosuhu c
1. laqisato nafosuhu, (S, A, K,) aor.
laqasa
, (S, K,) inf. n. laqasN, (S, TA,) His soul [or stomach] heaved; or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; or became heavy; syn. gavato, [q. v.,] (S, A, K,) and xabuvato; (S, K;) mina AlXRaIoCi in consequence of the thing. (S, K.) Mohammad desired his followers to use this expression instead of xabuvato nafosuhu, which he disliked. (K, TA.) ― -b2- With UilI AlXRaIoCi following it, His soul strove with him to incline him to the thing, (K,) and became greedy for it. (TA.) [But Az seems to disapprove of this explanation.]

laqisapN c
laqisapN, as an epithet applied to nafosN, is the part. n. of laqisato in the [first and] second of the senses explained above. (TA.)

1 laqaTahu c
1. laqaTahu, (S, Mgh, * Msb, K,) aor.
laquTa
, inf. n. laqoTN, (Msb, TA,) He picked it up, took it up, raised it, (Mgh,) or took it, (S, K,) from the ground, (S, Mgh, K,) without trouble or fatigue; as also AltqThu↓: (S:) or both signify he took it from a place where it was not thought to be; this being the primary signification: and hence, he took it. (Msb.) It is said of a man: and you say also, laqaTa AlTRaAYiru AlHabRa [The bird picked up from the ground the grains]. (Msb.) The Arabs say to a calumniator, UinRa Einodaka diykFA yalotaqiTu↓ AlHaSaI [Verily thou hast a cock that picks up pebbles]. (TA.) And it is said in a proverb, OaSayoda Alqunofuci Oamo laqoTahu [Is it by the hunting of the hedgehog or the picking up thereof from the ground?] applied to a poor man who becomes rich suddenly. (TA.) [In Freytag's Arab. Prov. (i. 726,) OaSayodu Alqunofuci Oamo luqaTapN: and there asserted to be said of him who finds a thing which he had not sought: or, accord. to Sharafed-Deen, of a thing of the nature of which we may be uncertain.] You say also, laqaTotu AlEilomi mina Alkutubi (assumed tropical:) [I picked up science, or knowledge, from books;] I acquired science, or knowledge, from this and that book. (Msb.) And laqaTotu OaSaAbiEahu (assumed tropical:) I took off his fingers, by cutting, without [the main part of] the hand. (Msb.)

3 mulaAqaTapN c
3. mulaAqaTapN A horse's lifting the legs all together in the pace called taqoriyb: (AO, K: *) or, in the pace called xabab, of a horse, it is similar to munaAqalapN. (JK.) ＝ -A2- Also, (K,) and liqaATN↓, (TA,) The being over against, or facing. (K, TA.) You say, daAruhu biliqaATi daAriI His house is over against, or faces, my house. (Lh, K.) And laqiytuhu liqaATAF I met him face to face. (IAar.)

5 tlqRT fulaAnN AltRamora c
5. tlqRT fulaAnN AltRamora, or AlvRamara, (S, accord. to different copies, and K, *) Such a one, [picked up, or] took up from the ground, from this and that place, the dates, or the fruits. (S, K. *)

8 AltqThu c
8. AltqThu: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- Also, He collected it. (Msb.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) He stumbled upon it, or lighted on it, (K, TA,) unexpectedly, (TA,) without seeking; (K, TA;) such a thing, for instance, as a well, and herbage. (TA.) You say also, waradotu AlXRaIoCa QlotiqaATFA (tropical:) I came upon the thing unexpectedly, or unawares; (S, TA:) and laqiytuhu QlotiqaATFA (tropical:) I met him unexpectedly: (TA:) AltqATA in this sense being one of those inf. ns. which are used as denotatives of state. (Sb, TA.)

laqaTN c
laqaTN What is picked up, or taken from the ground, (S, Msb, K,) of a thing; (S, Msb;) as also luqoTapN↓ and luqaTapN↓ and luqaATapN↓: (K:) or ↓this last signifies what one picks up, of lost property; as also luqaATN↓, with the p elided; and luqaTapN↓ like ruTabapN: (Msb:) or luqaATapN↓ signifies also what falls, or drops, of a thing that is worthless, (K, TA,) or paltry, and is taken by any one who chooses to take it: (TA:) and the same, what is picked up from the stumps of the branches of palm-trees, [app. meaning dates picked up thence,] after the cutting off of the dates: (TA:) IAth says, that luqaTapN↓, with damm to the l and fet-h to the q, is often mentioned in trads., and signifies property which is found: (TA:) Az says, that luqaTapN, with fet-h to the q, signifies a thing which one finds dropped, or thrown down, and takes; (Mgh, Msb;) and that all the lexicologists and skilful grammarians say so; (Msb;) and in like
manner, A 'Obeyd, on the authority of As and of El-Ahmar; (TA;) only Lth, of all whom he has heard, saying that it is luqoTapN↓, with sukoon; (Mgh, Msb;) and Fr: (TA:) IF and ElFárábee and others mention only luqaTapN↓; and some reckon the pronunciation with sukoon as an error of the vulgar; and the reason is this; that the original word is luqaATapN↓, which, in consequence of its being in frequent use, as applied to what is picked up in plundering, is contracted, sometimes, by the elision of the p, into luqaATN↓, and sometimes, by the elision of the A into luqaTapN↓; and if they made the q quiescent, there would be two alterations in the word, and such double alteration does not exist in chaste language: (Msb:) IB, however, says that luqoTapN↓ is correct; and he approves it; because fuEolapN has the sense of a pass. part. n., as in the instance of DuHokapN; and fuEalapN has the sense of an act. part. n., as in the instance of DuHakapN; and that it occurs in poetry: and IAth observes, that some say thus; but that luqaTapN↓ is more common and more correct. (TA.) Anything that is scattered, of ears of corn, or of fruit; n. un. with p: (TA:) what is picked up, or taken from the ground, (S, Msb, K,) by men, (S,) of ears of corn; (S, Msb, K;) as also luqaATN↓, with damm: (S:) and laqaATN↓, like saHaAbN, the ears of corn which the reaping-hooks miss, (AHn, K,) and which men pick up. (AHn.) What is picked up from a mine: (Msb:) pieces of gold found in a mine; (K;) or such are termed laqaTu maEodinK: (S:) or laqaTN signifies pieces of gold, or of silver, like what are termed Xacor, and larger, in mines; which are the best thereof: and one says cahabN laqaTN: (Lth:) and mulotaqaTN↓, also, signifies gold found in a mine. (TA.) You say also, fiI hecaA AlmakaAni laqaTN mina AlmarotaEi In this place is some small quantity of pasturage. (S.) And fiI AlOaroDi laqaTN lilomaAli In the land is pasturage not much in quantity for the beasts. (TA.) The pl. is OaloqaATN. (TA.)

luqoTapN c
luqoTapN: see laqaTN, throughout the first sentence. ― -b2- Accord. to Lth, it [also] signifies A man who repeatedly and perseveringly seeks after things to be picked up, and picks them up: (TA:) and some say, that luqaTapN↓ signifies one who picks up: but the more common and correct signification of this latter is “ property which is found, ” as before stated. (IAth.)

luqaTapN c
luqaTapN: see laqaTN, throughout the first sentence: — and see luqoTapN.

laqaATN c
laqaATN: see laqaTN, in the latter part of the paragraph.

luqaATN c
luqaATN: see laqaTN, in three places.

liqaATN c
liqaATN: see 3. ― -b2- [The act of picking up the ears of corn which the reaping-hooks miss;] the act denoted in the explanation of laqaATN. (JK, K, TA.) You say, huwa yataEayRaXu biAlilRqaATi Eani AllRaqaATi [He constrains himself to obtain the means of life, or he obtains what is barely sufficient for his sustenance, by picking up, or gleaning, from the ears of corn which the reaping-hooks have missed]. (TK: but there given without any syll. signs.) [If the reading intended be biAllRaqaATi Eani AllRiqaATi, the meaning of liqaATN is The act of missing ears of corn with the reapinghook; as is implied in the K, where laqaATN is imperfectly explained: but this I think improbable.] laqaATN and liqaATN are [respectively] like HaSaAdN [as signifying what is “ reaped ”] and HiSaAdN [as signifying the act of “ reaping ”]. (TA.)

laqiyTN c
laqiyTN i. q. maloquwTN↓; (Msb, K;) i. e. A thing that is picked up, taken up, raised, (Mgh,) or taken, (Msb, K,) from the ground, (Mgh, K,) or from a place where it was not thought to be. (Msb.) ― -b2- And, generally, (Mgh,) A foundling; or child that is cast out, (Az, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and found by a man, (Az, TA,) or picked up; (S;) or because it is cast out with the object of its being picked up: (Mgh:) not what Lth asserts it to be; i. e. a child that is cast out in the roads, and there found, whose father and mother are unknown: of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Az, TA:) and maloquwTN↓ signifies the same: (K:) [pl. of the former, luqaTaMCu.] ― -b3- Also, A well upon which one lights unexpectedly, or unawares, (Lth, K,) without seeking it. (Lth.)

luqaATapN c
luqaATapN: see laqaTN, first sentence, in four places.

laqiyTapN c
laqiyTapN applied to a man, and to a woman, (tropical:) Low, ignoble, base, vile, or mean; (K, TA;) as also laAqiTapN↓ applied to a man; (TA;) and so saAqiTN maAqiTN laAqiTN↓, used together. (L in art. sqT.) It occurs in this sense preceded by saqiyTapN; but you say saqiyTN when alone. (TA.)

laqRaATN c
laqRaATN: see laAqiTN.

laqRaATapN c
laqRaATapN: see laAqiTN.

laAqiTN c
laAqiTN and in an intensive sense laqRaATN↓ and [in a doubly intensive sense] laqRaATapN↓ A man [who picks up things from the ground; and the second, who does so much, or often; and the third, who does so very much, or very often: or] who takes things from places where they were not thought to be: (Msb:) and all signify a man who picks up the ears of corn [that fall] when the crop is reaped, and [the fruit that falls] when the ripe dates are cut from the raceme: (TA:) and the first and second, a bird that picks up grains. (Msb.) ― -b2- likulRi saAqiTapK laAqiTapN↓ For every saying that falls from one, there is a person who will take it up: (Msb in art. sqT:) or for every word that falls from the mouth of the speaker, there is a person who will hear it and pick it up and publish it: (S, * K:) a proverb, (TA,) relating to the guarding of the tongue: (K:) the p in lAqTp is to give intensiveness to the meaning, (Msb, in art. sqT,) or for the purpose of assimilation: (Msb in that art., and in the present one:) if you say likulRi DaAYiEK, or the like, you say laAqiTN. (Msb in the present art.) ― -b3- AlHaSaI laAqiTapN↓ The qaAniSap [meaning stomach, &c.,] of a bird, (S, K,) in which pebbles become collected: (S:) or the omasum (qibRp) of a sheep or goat [and the corresponding ventricle of a camel, as is shown in the TA in art. HSl; also called laqRaATapu AlHaSaI (see qurayoHaMCu);] because it conveys thereinto whatever it eats of earth and pebbles; (A, TA;) as also AllRaAqiTapN [alone]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- laAqiTN also signifies (tropical:) Any freedman, or emancipated slave: (K:) or the slave of a freedman. (S in art. mqT, and TA in art. sqT:) the slave of the lAqT is called maAqiTN; and the slave of the mAqT is called saAqiTN: and hence the saying, huwa saAqiTu bonu maAqiTi boni laAqiTK. (K, TA [but in the CK, for huwa we find banuw, with the necessary difference in what follows it.]) See art. sqT. ― -b2- See also laqiyTapN: and see OaloqaATN, which may be a pl. of laAqiTN; as in luqRaATN, which is explained with OaloqaATN.

laAqiTapN c
laAqiTapN: see laAqiTN, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also laqiyTapN.

OaloqaATN c
OaloqaATN pl. of laqaTN, q. v. ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A small number of men, separated, or scattered, or dispersed. (S.) ― -b3- [Also, perhaps as pl. of laAqiTN, like as OaSoHaAbN is pl. of SaAHibN,] (tropical:) The refuse, or lowest, or basest, or meanest sort, of mankind, or of people; (K, * TA;) as also luqRaATN↓ [which is doubtless a pl. of laAqiTN, like as suqRaATK is of saAqiTN, and muqRaATN of maAqiTN]. (IAar, in TA, art. xXr.)

maloqaTN c
maloqaTN [A place where a thing is picked up:] a place where a thing is sought, or to be sought: a mine: (TA:) [pl. malAqiTu.] ― -b2- OaSobaHato maraAEiynaA malaAqiTa mina Aljadobi Our places of pasturage became dried up, and destitute of herbage, by reason of the drought. (As.)

miloqaTN c
miloqaTN A thing with which, (K,) or in which, (Jm,) one picks up, or takes up, from the ground: (Jm, K;) as also miloqaATN↓. (TA.)

miloqaATN c
miloqaATN: see miloqaTN. ― -b2- The [instrument called] minoqaAX, (K, TA,) with which hair is plucked up. (TA.)

maloquwTN c
maloquwTN: see laqiyTN, in two places. IAth explains maAlN maloquwTN as signifying property found. (TA.)

mulotaqaTN c
mulotaqaTN: see laqaTN, last sentence but two. ― -b2- Also, applied to a thing, i. q. saAqiTN (assumed tropical:) [Vile, mean, or paltry]. (TA.)
