dictScrap.label: lqE lqf lqm lqn lqI lk: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 lakaOa c
1. lakaOa, aor.
lakaAa
, (K,) inf. n. lakoCN, (TA,) He beat a person (K) with a whip. (TA.) ― -b2- lakaOa bihi AlOaroDa He cast him upon the ground. (AZ, S.) [See zakaOa, and lataOa.] ― -b3- lakaOahu He prostrated him. (K.) ＝ -A2- lakaOahu He gave him the whole of what was due to him: (K:) like lafaOahu. (T.) ＝ -A3- lakiYa, aor.
lakaAa
, He stayed, dwelt, or abode, (K,) in a place: like lakiIa. (TA.) lkY bimawoDiEK He kept, or remained fixed, in a place. (K, * TA.)

5 tlkRO Ealayohi c
5. tlkRO Ealayohi He excused himself to him; he pleaded an excuse to him. (K.) ― -b2- tlkRO Eanohu He was slow to do it; delayed to do it; (S, K, TA;) excused himself, or pleaded an excuse, for not doing it; refused to do it, or abstained from doing it. (TA.)

malokabapN c
malokabapN A she-camel compact in flesh: (K:) or abounding with fat, and compact in flesh. (AA, T.) ― -b2- The conduct of a pimp: syn. qiyaAdapN (L.)

1 lakava c
1. lakava, [aor.
lakuva
,] inf. n. lakovN (and likaAvN, IAar), He struck, or smote; (K;) accord. to IAar, who does not particularize the hand, nor the foot: (TA:) or, with his hand, or his foot, accord. to some: (TA:) or, with [perhaps a mistake for upon] the mouth. (Kr.) [See also lkd.] ― -b2- lakatahu, [aor.
lakuva
,] He overburdened him. (K.) ― -b3- lakiva, aor.
lakava
, [inf. n. lakavN,] He (a camel) was affected with the disorder called lakavN, or lukaAvN. (K.) ― -b4- lakiva bihi, aor.
lakava
, It (dirt [see lakovN]) adhered to it; (K;) i. e., to the vessel. (TA.) [See also lakida and lakiEa.]

lakovN c
lakovN The dirt of milk, which congeals upon the edge of the vessel, and is removed with the hand. (TA.)

lakavN c
lakavN and lukaAvN↓ (as also nukaAvN, TA,) A disorder in the mouths of camels, resembling pustules. (Lh, K.) ― -b2- lukaAvapN↓, A disorder that attacks sheep or goats in the sides of the mouth and in the lips, resembling an ulcer; happening on their first cropping plants when they are short, with small branches. (L.)

naAqapN lakivapN c
naAqapN lakivapN A fat she-camel. (K.)

lukaAvN c
lukaAvN A shining stone in gypsum. (Fr, K.) ＝ -A2- See lakavN.

lukaAvapN c
lukaAvapN: see lakavN.

lukRaAvN c
lukRaAvN [pl. of laAkivN?] Preparers of gypsum: (K:) not those who traffick therein. (TA.)

lukaAviIRN c
lukaAviIRN A man (TA) very white: (K:) from lukaAvN as signifying a shining stone in gypsum. (TA.)

1 lakida Ealayohi c
1. lakida Ealayohi, (As, S, L, K,) and bihi, (L,) aor.
lakada
, (K,) inf. n. lakadN; (As, S, L;) and bh tlkRd↓; (A;) It (dirt) clave, or stuck, to him, or it. (As, S, A, L, K.) ― -b2- lakida bifiyhi It (a glutinous thing that had been eaten of) left part of its substance, or its colour, sticking to his (the eater's) mouth. (L.) ― -b3- lakida It (his hair) became compacted together, or matted, (L,) by reason of dirt. (A.) ― -b4- lakida bihi, and Altkd↓, He kept to, or clave to, and did not quit, him, or it. (L.) See also 3.

3 lAkdhu c
3. lAkdhu He kept, clave, or clung, to him. (L.)

5 talakRada
5: tlkRd It (a thing) clave together, one part to another. (S, L, K.) ― -b2- He became thick (and compact, TA,) in his flesh. (K.) ― -b3- See 1. ― -b4- tlkRdhu He embraced him; put his arms round his neck. (As, L, K.)

8 Uilotakada
8: see 1.

milokadN c
milokadN A thing resembling a muduqR [or pestle], with which one bruises, brays, or pounds. (S, L, K.)

1 lakazahu c
1. lakazahu, aor.
lakuza
, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. lakozN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) He struck him upon the breast (AO, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) with the fist: (AO, S, Mgh, Msb:) and upon the Hanak [or part beneath the chin]: (A, K:) and upon the neck: (K:) or upon any part of the body with the fist: (AZ, S, Msb:) or with the extremities of the fingers: (TA, art. lqz:) he pushed, or impelled, or repelled, him: (TA, ibid.:) he thrust or pierced him [with a spear or the like]: (TA, art. lz:) lakozN is also syn. with wakozN [which has several significations, some of which are indentical with some explained above]. (K.) You say also, lakazahu bijumoEi kafRihi He struck him upon the breast, or the part called Hanak, with his fist. (A.)

3 lAkzhu c
3. lAkzhu, inf. n. mulaAkazapN, [He contended with him in striking upon the breast, or the part beneath the chin, &c., with the fists.] (A, TA.)

6 tlAkzA c
6. tlAkzA [They two contended in striking each other upon the breast, or the part beneath the chin, &c., with their fists]. (A, TA.)

lakozapN c
lakozapN A blow upon the breast, (A, Mgh,) and upon the part beneath the chin, [&c.,] (A,) with the fist. (Mgh.)

mulakRazN c
mulakRazN (tropical:) A low, an abject, or a despicable, man, who is repelled (A, TA) from the doors. (TA.)

dictScrap.label: lkE lkm lkn lkI: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
lawolabN c
lawolabN: see art. lb.

mulawolabN c
mulawolabN i. q. mirowadN (S, K) and the like. (S.) Of the measure mufawoEalN: (S, K:) or, accord. to some, faEawoEalN. (TA.)

dictScrap.label: lm: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 lamaOahu c
1. lamaOahu, and lamaOa Ealayohi, aor.
lamaAa
, He smote his hand upon it, [or laid his hand upon it, or seized it,] openly or secretly. (K.) ― -b2- lamaOa AlXRaIoCa He took the whole thing; took it entirely. (K.) ― -b3- lamaOa AlXRaIoCa, (K,) inf. n. lamoCN, (TA,) He glanced, or took a slight look at the thing; beheld it quickly: like lamaHahu. (K.)

4 AlmO Ealayohi c
4. AlmO Ealayohi He (a thief, TA) took it away privily. (K.) [See also OalomaI.] ― -b2- AlmO EalaIRa HaqRiI He denied me my right, or due. (K.) ― -b3- AlmOt AldRawaAbRu AlmakaAna (S) [in the K, biAlamkaAni; but this appears, from what is said in the S and the TA, to be wrong;] The beasts of carriage left the place bare of pasture. (S, K.) ― -b4- AlmO Elyh, (K,) or bihi, (S, L,) He took, or got, possession of it; took it, got it, or held it, within his grasp, or in his possession: syn. UiXotamala Ealayohi: (S, K:) or the latter signifies he took it away; went away with it. (K.) AlmO EalaI AlXRaIoCi He got possession of the thing. (L.) cahaba vawobiI famaA OadoriI mano AlmO bh [My garment is gone, and I know not who has taken, or got, possession of it; or who has taken it away]. (S.) The phrase without negation is also used. (ISk, S.) [See also 8.]

5 tlmROt AlOaroDu bihi c
5. tlmROt AlOaroDu bihi, (K,) and Ealayohi, (S, K,) The earth enclosed him; was made even over him: and concealed him. (S, K.) See 8.

8 AltmO bimaA fiI Aljafonapi c
8. AltmO bimaA fiI Aljafonapi, and AlmO↓, and tlmRO↓, He took to himself the contents of the bowl. (K, TA.) [See also AltmE and AlmE and tlmRE.] ＝ -A2- OulotumiICa lawonuhu His colour altered, or became altered. (S,
K.) UilotamaOa is also mentioned as having the same signification. (TA.) [See also AltmE and AltmI.]

malomuWapN c
malomuWapN A place in which a thing is taken (yuWoxacu, as in some copies of the K) or found (yuwjadu, as in other copies of the K). ― -b2- A sportsman's, or hunter's, or fowler's, or fisherman's net. (K, TA.)

1 lamaja c
1. lamaja, (aor.
lamuja
, S, M,) inf. n. lamojN, (S, K,) He ate: or he ate with the extremity of the mouth: (M:) or he ate with the extremities of his mouth: (S, K:) or he took fodder, or dry herbage, with the extremity of his mouth: (T:) AZ says, I know not AllRamoj except as the act of asses, and it is like AllRamos, [probably a mistake for AllRahos, or its syn. AllRaHos,] or signifies more than this latter word. (AHn.) ― -b2- lamaja, inf. n. lamojN, Inivit feminam. (K.)

2 lamRajahu c
2. lamRajahu, inf. n. talomiyjN, He fed him with something whereby to content, or divert, him [so as to allay the craving of his stomach] before the [morning-meal called] gadaAC: see lumojapN. (TA.) And see lamaZRahu: and EajRalotumo: and EasRala. ― -b2- maA lamRajuwA Dayofahumo biXaIoCK They did not feed their guest with anything whereby to allay the craving of his stomach before the morning-meal. (S.)

5 tlmRj c
5. tlmRj He ate something whereby to content, or satisfy, himself [so as to allay the craving of his stomach] before the [morning-meal called] gadaAC. (K.) [See lumojapN: and see also lamaAjN.] ― -b2- Accord. to AA, it is like talamRaZa; [He searched repeatedly, with his tongue, after the remains of food in his mouth, and put forth his tongue and licked his lips with it;] and one says, raOayotuhu yatalamRaju biAlTRaEaAmi, i. e. ytlmRZ [I saw him searching repeatedly, with his tongue, after the remains of the food in his mouth, &c.]; and As says the like. (S.)

samojN lamojN c
samojN lamojN, (K,) or XaIoCN samojN lamojN (S,) and samijN lamijN↓, and samiyjN lamiyjN↓: (S, K:) in each of these expressions, the latter word is an imitative sequent: (AO, S, K:) [app. Very ugly: in the TA it is said, that these epithets are applied to a man, and signify cawRaAqN, app. meaning one who tastes much: and in the L it is said, that rajulN lamijN↓, after the manner of a relative noun, signifies cawRaAqN]. See lamoHN.

lamijN c
lamijN: see lamojN.

lumojapN c
lumojapN: see lamaAjN. ― -b2- Also [An early portion of food, being] That with which one contents, or diverts, himself [so as to allay the craving of his stomach] before the [morning-meal called] gadaAC. (K.) See sulofapN.

lamaAjN c
lamaAjN The least (OadonaI) [kind, or quantity,] of food, or of what is eaten: (S, K:) and sometimes, of beverage. (TA.) ― -b2- maA talamRajotu Einodahu bilamaAjK, (S, L,) and lamuwjK↓, and lumojapK↓, (L,) I ate not anything at his abode: (L:) and maA cuqotu XamaAjAF walaA lamaAjFA, (S, L,) I tasted not anything. (S, L.)

lamuwjN c
lamuwjN: see lamaAjN.

lamiyjN c
lamiyjN One who eats much; a great eater. (K.) ― -b2- Is qui multum coït: as also laAmijN↓. (K.) ― -b3- See also lamojN.

laAmijN c
laAmijN: see lamiyjN.

malaAmiju c
malaAmiju: i. q. malaAgima: (i. e., S;) The parts around the mouth. (S, K.)

rumoHN mulamRajN c
rumoHN mulamRajN A smoothed spear. (K.)

1 lamaHahu c
1. lamaHahu, (S,) or lamaHa Uilayohi, aor.
lamaHa
, (L, Msb, K), inf. n. lamoHN; (Msb;) and AlmH↓, (L, K,) or AlmHhu↓, (S, Msb,) and AltmHhu↓; (S;) He glanced, or took a light, or slight, look, at him or it; (S;) like lamaOahu; (Nh;) snatched a sight of him or it unawares: (L, Msb, K;) or, accord. to some, lamaHa signifies he looked; and AlmHhu↓, he made him to look; but the former explanation is the more correct: or lamaHa is only said of one looking from a distance. (L.) ― -b2- lamaHotuhu biAlbaSari I directed (SawRabotu) my sight towards him. (Msb.) ― -b3- lamaHa AlbaSaru The sight extended to a thing. (Msb.) ― -b4- lamaHa, aor.
lamaHa
, inf. n. lamoHN (S, K) and lamaHaAnN and talomaAHN, (K,) It (lightning, and a star,) shone; gleamed; glistened; i. q. lamaEa. (S, K.)

3 laAmaHahu c
3. laAmaHahu, inf. n. mulaAmaHapN, [He glanced at him, or viewed him lightly, or slightly, or snatched sights of him unawares, reciprocally]. (A.)

4 AlmHhu c
4. AlmHhu He made him to glance, or to take a light, or slight, look; expl. by jaEalahu yalomaHa, (K,) and jaEalahu mimRano yalomaHu. (TA.) ― -b2- See 1. ― -b3- OalomaHati AlmaroOapu mino wajohihaA, (inf. n. UilomaAHN, TA,) The woman allowed herself [or her face] to be glanced at, or to be viewed lightly, or slightly: so does a beautiful woman, displaying, and then concealing, her beauties. (T, K.)

8 OalotumiHa baSaruhu c
8. OalotumiHa baSaruhu His sight was taken away. (K.) ― -b2- See 1.

fulaAnN samoHN lamoHN c
fulaAnN samoHN lamoHN, and samiyHN lamiyHN↓: see art. smH. [lamoHN and lamiyHN in these cases seem to be merely imitative sequents.] ― -b2- laOuriyanRaka lamoHFA baASirFA (tropical:) I will assuredly show thee a manifest, or an evident, thing, matter, or affair. (S, A, K.) [See also art. bSr.]

lamoHapN c
lamoHapN, subst. from lamaHa, (S, L,) A glance, or light or slight look. (L.) ― -b2- lamoHapN A shining, gleaming, or glistening, of lightning. (S.) ― -b3- fiI fulaAnK lamoHapN mino Oabiyhi In such a one is a likeness, or point of resemblance, to his father: then they said mino Abyh malAmiHu↓, (S,) signifying likenessess, or points of resemblance; forming an extr. pl., (S, K,) as though from another word than lamoHapN: (S:) they did not say malomaHapN. (TA.) ― -b4- malaAmiHu↓ also signifies What appear of the beauties and defects of the face (K) of a human being: or the parts thereof that are glanced at, or viewed lightly or quickly. (TA.)

lamuwHN c
lamuwHN: see laAmiHN.

lamiyHN c
lamiyHN: see lamoHN.

lamRaAHN c
lamRaAHN: see laAmiHN.

lumRaAHN c
lumRaAHN Sharp hawks; syn. SuquwrN cakiyRapN. (IAar, T, K, [in the CK, zakiyRap].)

laAmiHN c
laAmiHN and lamuwHN↓ and lamRaAHN↓ Lightning, and a star, shining; gleaming; glistening: (K:) [but the second and third are intensive epithets, signifying shining much; &c.] ― -b2- OaboyaDu lamRaAHN↓ (tropical:) Intensely white. (A.) ― -b3- laAmiHu EiTofayohi A self-admiring man, who looks at his sides. (M, F.)

OalomaHiIRN c
OalomaHiIRN A man (TA) who glances much, or frequently takes light, or slight looks. (K.)

malaAmiHu c
malaAmiHu: see lamoHapN.

1 lamazahu c
1. lamazahu, aor.
lamiza
and
lamuza
, inf. n. lamozN, He made a sign to him with the eye, or the like, (S, A, * Msb, K,) as the head, and the lip, with low speech. (TA.) This is the original signification. (S, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (S, Msb, TA,) He blamed, upbraided, or reproached, him; he found fault with him: (S, Msb, K:) or he did so in his face: (TA:) or he met him with blaming, upbraiding, reproaching or finding fault: (IKtt, TA:) or he spoke evil of him, or spoke of him in a manner that he disliked, mentioning vices or faults as chargeable to him, either behind his back or before his face, though it might be with truth; syn. UigotaAbahu. (TA.) The two forms of the aor. occur in readings of the words of the Kur., [ix. 58,] waminohumo mano yalomizuka fiI AlSRadaqaAti and yalomuzuka, (S, TA,) And of them are those who blame thee with respect to the division of the alms: (Bd, Jel:) and Ibn-Ketheer reads yulaAmizuka↓. (Bd.) ＝ -A2- lamazahu, (Ks, S,) aor
lamiza
, (S,)
inf. n. lamozN, (S, A, K,) He pushed him, or impelled him, or repelled him: (Ks, T, S, A, K:) said by AM to be the primary signification: (TA:) and he struck him, or beat him. (S, A, K.)

3 raOayotuhu yulaAgizuhu wayulaAmiruhu c
3. raOayotuhu yulaAgizuhu wayulaAmiruhu [means I saw him talking enigmatically with him, or to him, and making signs with him, or to him: or, accord. to the TA, mulaAmazapN is syn. with mulaAgazapN]. (A, in art. lgz.)

lumazapN c
lumazapN One who blames, upbraids, reproaches, or finds fault with, others, much, or habitually; (S, K;) as also lamRaAzN↓, (so in two copies of the S, and in a copy of the A,) or lamaAzN↓, like saHaAbN: (K:) lumazapN is applied to a man and to a woman; for its p is to denote intensiveness, and not the fem. gender: (TA:) humazapN and lumazapN signify the same; (ISk, Zj, K;) i. e., one who speaks evil of others, or does so in their absence, though it may be with truth; (yagotaAbuhumo; and this may mean [who detracts by making signs] with the side of the mouth, or with the eye, or with the head; TA;) and defames them; (ISk, Zj, TA;) or one who often goes about with calumny, a separater of companions and friends: (Abu-l-'Abbás, TA:) and lamRaAzN↓, like XadRaAdN, a frequent, or habitual, calumniator, or slanderer: (TA:) or humazapN and lumazapN differ in signification; the latter signifying one who blames, upbraids, reproaches, or finds fault with, thee to thy face; and the former, one who does so in thine absence; (K;) and Lth says the like: (TA:) or the latter, one who speaks evil of others, though it may be with truth, (mugotaAbN,) behind the back; and the former, one who does so to the face: or the latter, one who speaks against the lineages of men; and the former, one who speaks against the characters of men: or the latter, [one who reproaches] with the tongue; and the former, with the eye: or the reverse: (K [but omitted in the CK], TA:) or the latter signifies one who excites discord, or animosity, between two persons. (TA.) See also humazapN. And see the Ksh and Bd in civ. 1.

lamaAzN c
lamaAzN: see lumazapN.

lamRaAzN c
lamRaAzN [One who makes frequent signs with the eye, or the like: fem. with p: see one ex. voce ramRaAzN]. ― -b2- See also lumazapN, in two places.

laAmizN c
laAmizN act. part. n. of 1. ― -b2- lumRaAzN [its pl.] Persons who speak evil of others, though it may be with truth, (mugotaAbuwna,) in their presence. (IAar, TA.)

1 lamasahu c
1. lamasahu, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
lamusa
(S, M, Msb, K) and
lamisa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. lamosN, (S, M, Msb,) He felt it; or touched it; syn. masRahu: (IAar, Az, IDrd, El-Fárábee, A, Msb, TA:) or he felt it, or touched it, (masRahu,) with his hand: (S, Msb, K:) or he put his hand to it: (Msb:) or he felt it with his hand for the purpose of testing it, that he might form a judgment of it; syn. jasRahu: (M, TA:) and laAmasahu↓ is syn. with lamasahu, (M, TA,) or maAsRahu: (A:) lamosN and masRN both signify the perceiving by means of the exterior of the external skin: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or they are nearly alike: (TA:) [generally, like the English words feeling and touching, respectively:] or the former is, originally, [the feeling] with the hand for the purpose of knowing the feel (masR) of a thing: (IDrd, Msb:) or, with the hand, it is the seeking for [or feeling for] a thing here and there: (Lth, TA:) mulaAmasapN is the same as mumaAsRapN (K, TA) with the hand; as also lamosN: (TA:) or a distinction is to be made between them; for it is said that lamosN is sometimes the feeling, or touching a thing with a thing; and is sometimes [for] the knowledge of a thing, though there be no touching (masR) of substance upon substance; whereas mlAmsp is mostly mutual feeling or touching, &c., being] the act of two. (IAar in TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] lamasahaA, (M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
lamusa
(M) [and
lamisa
, as implied in the K], inf. n. lamosN, (S, M,) (tropical:) Inivit eam; (I'Ab, S, M, A, Msb, K;) scil. mulierem; (A, Msb;) puellam; (K;) as also laAmasahaA↓, (M, A, Msb,) inf. n. mulaAmasapN (I'Ab, S, Msb, K) and limaAsN: (I'Ab, Msb:) and (assumed tropical:) he kissed her; by doing which, as well as by the former, one renders necessary the performance of the ablution termed wDwC. ('Abd-Allah Ibn- 'Amr, Ibn-Mes'ood.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] lamasahu, aor.
lamusa
[and
lamisa
], (A, TA,) inf. n. lamosN, (IDrd, Msb, TA,) (tropical:) He sought, [as though by feeling,] or sought for or after, it, namely, a thing, (IDrd, Msb, TA,) in any manner; (IDrd, Msb;) [as, for instance, by asking, or demanding;] as also Altmshu↓, (S, M, A, * K, TA,) [which is more common,] and tlmRshu↓: (M, TA:) or this last signifies he sought it, or sought for or after it, repeatedly, or time after time. (S, K, TA.) You say, Oulomuso liI fulaAnFA (A, TA) (tropical:) Seek thou for me such a one. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur, [lxxii. 8,] relating the words of the jinn, or genii, UinRaA lamasonaA AlsRamaMCa, (K, * TA, *) (tropical:) Verily we sought to reach heaven: or to learn the news thereof: (Bd:) or to hear by stealth what was said therein: (Jel:) or we laboured, or strove, after (EaAlajonaA) the secrets of heaven, and sought to hear them by stealth. (K.) And in a trad., bihi EilomFA mano salaka TariyqFA yalotamisu↓ (tropical:) Whoso pursueth a way whereby he seeketh after knowledge, or science. (TA.) And in another, of 'Áïsheh, EiqodiI faQlotamasotu↓ (tropical:) And I sought for my necklace. (TA.) ― -b4- lamasa AlbaSara, aor.
lamusa
, (tropical:) It took away the sight. (A, TA.) And the same, or, accord. to one relation of a trad., Altmshu↓, (assumed tropical:) It took away quickly, and destroyed, the sight; said there of certain serpents: or the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) it aimed at the eye with its bite: and lamasa Eayonahu is said to signify [(assumed tropical:) he, or it, put out his eye,] the same as samala. (TA.)

3 lAmshu c
3. lAmshu, inf. n. mulaAmasapN and limaAsN: for its proper signification, see 1, in three places. [Hence,] bayoEu AlmulaAmasapi, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb,) and bayoEu AllRimaAsi, (Mgh,) or AlmulaAmasapu fiI AlbayoEi, (K,) A mode of bargaining, which consists in saying, When thou feelest, or touchest, my garment, or I feel, or touch, thy garment, (A, K,) or when, (Mgh,) or if, (Msb,) I feel, or touch, thy garment, and thou feelest, or touchest, my garment, (Mgh, Msb,) or when I feel, or touch, the thing to be sold, (S,) the sale is binding, or settled, or concluded, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) between us, (S, Msb,) for such a sum: (S, Msb, K:) or, accord. to Aboo-Haneefeh, in thy saying, I will sell to thee this commodity for such a sum, and when I feel, or touch, thee, the sale is binding, or settled, or concluded; or in the purchaser's saying the like: (Mgh:) or, (M, Mgh, K,) as in the Sunan of Aboo-Dáwood, (Mgh,) in purchasing a commodity on the condition of feeling it (M, Mgh, * K, *) behind a garment or piece of cloth, (K,) without seeing it, (M, K,) or spreading it out and turning it over and examining it: (Mgh:) or on the condition that the feeling it with the hand shall cut one off from the choice of returning it: (TA:) the mode of bargaining thus termed is forbidden. (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- For a tropical signification of the verb, see 1.

4 OalomisoniI AljaAriyapa c
4. OalomisoniI AljaAriyapa Permit thou me to feel, or touch, the girl. (A, TA.) ― -b2- OalomisoniI QmoraOaopF (tropical:) Marry thou to me a woman. (A, TA.)

5 talamRasa
5: see 1, in two places.

8 Uilotamasa
8: see 1, in four places.

lamuwsN c
lamuwsN A she-camel of whose fatness one doubts; (O, TS, K;) on the authority of Ibn-'Abbád; (TA;) i. q. XakuwkN and DabuwvN: (A, TA:) or of whose hump one doubts, whether there be in her fat or not; wherefore it is felt: (M, L:) pl. lumusN. (M, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (tropical:) One whose origin, or lineage, is suspected; syn. daEiIRN: (K:) or in whose grounds of pretention to respect is a fault, or taint. (A, K.)

lamiysN c
lamiysN A woman soft to the feel, or touch; layRinapu Almalomasi. (K.)

lamaAsapN c
lamaAsapN, (M,) lumaAsapN, (S,) or both, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) A want: (IAar, Sgh:) or a moderate, or middling, want. (S, M, O, L.)

lamuwsapN c
lamuwsapN A road, or way: so called because he who has lost his way seeks it in order to find the track of the travellers. (K, * TA.)

laAmisN c
laAmisN act. part. n. of 1. (Msb, &c.) One says, of a woman who commits adultery, or fornication, or acts viciously, falaAnapu laA tarudRu yada laAmisK, (A, TA,) or laA tamonaEu yada laAmisK, (K,) but the latter is at variance with the written authorities, the former being the phrase commonly known, (TA,) [properly signifying, Such a woman does not repel the hand of a feeler;] meaning, (tropical:) such a woman commits adultery, or fornication, and acts viciously, (K, TA,) not repelling from herself any one who desires of her that he may lie with her; (TA;) and she is suspected of easiness, or compliance, (K, TA,) towards him who desires of her that he may lie with her: (TA:) or the meaning is, such a woman gives, of her husband's property, what is sought, or demanded, from her; and this is more probably meant in a trad. in which a man is related to have said thus of his wife; because Mohammad directed him to retain her, and did not require him to divorce her. (TA.) The like said of a man, (K,) fulaAnN laA yarudRu yada laAmisK, (A, Msb,) means, (tropical:) Such a man has in him no force of resistance, (A, Msb, K,) nor care of what is sacred, or inviolable. (TA.)

malomasN c
malomasN [A place that is felt, or touched: and it may also be an inf. n.: see lamiysN]. (K.)

UikaAfN malomuwsu AlOaHonaMCi c
UikaAfN malomuwsu AlOaHonaMCi (tropical:) An ass's saddle, or pad, of which the curved pieces of wood have been felt with the hands until they have become even: (M:) or of which any unevenness and prominence that was therein has been pared off (Lth, T, A, K) by the passing of the hand over it, (Lth, T,) or of the hands. (A.)

1 lamaZa c
1. lamaZa, (S, K,) aor.
lamuZa
, (S,) inf. n. lamoZN, (S, M,) He sought leisurely and gradually, with his tongue, after the remains of the food in his mouth, (S, K, TA,) after eating: (TA:) and he put forth his tongue, and wiped with it his lips: (S, K:) as also tlmRZ↓, (S, K,) in both senses: (K:) you say also AlHayRapu tlmRZt↓ (tropical:) The serpent put forth its tongue, (S, K, TA,) like as the eater puts it forth and wipes with it his lip: (S, TA:) or the former verb and ↓the latter signify he took with his tongue what remained in the mouth after eating: (M:) or he sought leisurely and gradually after the taste, and tasted time after time: (M, K:) or ↓the latter signifies he tasted time after time; as also tmTRq: or he moved about his tongue in his mouth after eating, as though seeking leisurely and gradually after some remains of the food between his teeth; whereas tmTRq signifies he smacked his lips: (T:) or tlmRZ↓ signifies he sought leisurely and gradually, with his tongue, after the remains of the food between his teeth after eating: or he put forth his tongue, and wiped with it his lips. (Mgh.) [Hence the saying bicikorihi maA zaAla fulaAnN yatalamRaZu↓ (tropical:) [Such a one ceased not to busy his tongue with mentioning him, or it]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- lamaZa AlmaMCa, inf. n. lamoZN, He tasted the water with the extremity of his tongue. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also 2, in two places.

2 lmRZhu c
2. lmRZhu, inf. n. talomiyZN; (TA;) or lamaZahu↓; (M as quoted in the TT [being there written without teshdeed; and both seem to be correct;]) He gave him something to taste; he fed him with something whereby to content or divert, him [so as to allay the craving of his stomach] before the morning-meal; syn. cawRaqahu and lamRajahu, (M, TA,) both of which are alike. (TA.) You say also, lamRiZo fulaAnFA lumaAZapF [Give thou to such a one, to eat,] something which he may taste time after time, or after eating which he may move about his tongue in his mouth as though seeking leisurely and gradually after some remains thereof between his teeth. (T.) ― -b2- And [hence,] lmRZhu, (M, K,) inf. n. as above; (TA;) and lamaZahu↓; (M, K;) (tropical:) He gave to him (M, K, TA) somewhat (M, TA) of his right, or due. (M, K, TA.)

4 AlmZhu c
4. AlmZhu He put the water upon the edge of his lips, (M,) or upon his lips, or lip. (K, accord. to different copies.) ― -b2- And hence UilomaAZN is used to signify (tropical:) The act of piercing, or thrusting, feebly [with a spear or the like]. (M, * TA.)

5 talamRaZa
5: see 1, in six places.

8 AltmZhu c
8. AltmZhu He ate it: (ISk, S, M, A:) or he threw it quickly into his mouth. (O, K.)

9 AlmZR c
9. AlmZR, inf. n. UilomiZaAZN, He (a horse) had a lumoZap, or whiteness upon his lower lip. (S, K.)

lamaZN c
lamaZN: see lumoZapN, in two places.

lumoZapN c
lumoZapN A whiteness in the lower lip of a horse, (S, M, K,) not being a part of the [whiteness termed] gurRap; (M;) as also lamaZN↓: (M, K:) also the former, a gurRap which descends so that it enters into the mouth of a horse, and so that he removes with it what has remained in his mouth after eating: and ↓the latter, somewhat white in the lip of a beast of carriage, not passing beyond the place where the lip closes: (M:) or the former, a whiteness upon both the lips, only. (M, K.) Also, Somewhat of whiteness in the fore leg of a horse, or in his hind leg, upon the OaXoEar [or hair which surrounds the hoof.] (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.) And A small spot (As, T, S, M, K) of white: (As, T, S, K:) and contr. of black, in the heart. (K.) It is said in a trad., that faith begins like a lumoZap in the heart; (T, S;) and as faith increases, so the latter increases. (T.) And that hypocrisy in the heart is a black lmZp, and faith is a white lmZp; and as either increases, so the lmZp increases. (M. TA.) ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) A small quantity of clarified butter, which one takes with the finger, (K, TA,) like a walnut: mentioned by Z and Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.)

lamaAZN c
lamaAZN A thing which one tastes, (K, TA), and with which one moves about the tongue in the mouth. (TA.) You say, maA lahu lamaAZN He has not anything to taste, (K, TA,) &c. (TA.) And maA cuqotu lamaAZFA I have not tasted anything. (S) And Xariba AlmaMCa lamaAZFA He tasted the water with the extremity of his tongue. (S, M, K. *) [See also what next follows.]

lumaAZapN c
lumaAZapN What remains in the mouth, (S, M, K,) of food, (S, M,) after eating: (TA:) or something which one may taste time after time, or after eating which one may move about his tongue in his mouth as though seeking leisurely and gradually after some remains thereof between his teeth. (T.) [See also what next precedes.] ― -b2- Also, A remain, remainder, or residue, of something little in quantity. (TA.)

OalomaZu c
OalomaZu A horse having a lumoZap, or whiteness, upon his lower lip: when it is upon the upper lip. he is termed Oarovamu: (S, K:) or a horse whose lower lip is white. (Mgh.)

malaAmiZu c
malaAmiZu The part around the lips of a man: (M, K:) because he tastes therewith. (M.)

mutalamRaZN c
mutalamRaZN The part of the face by which smiling is expressed; syn. mutabasRamN. (K. TA) [in the CK, erroneously, mutabasRim.]) You say, UinRahu laHasanu AlmutalamRaZi [Verily he is goodly in respect of the part of the face by which smiling is expressed]. (TA.)

dictScrap.label: lmE lmq lmk lmI: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 lahiba c
1. lahiba, aor.
lahaba
, (inf. n. lahabN, S,) (tropical:) He thirsted; was thirsty: (S, K:) [probably, burned with thirst].

2 lhRb AlnRaAra c
2. lhRb AlnRaAra [same as OalohabahaA↓, except that it has an intensive signification; He made the fire to flame, or blaze, fiercely, or intensely: or, to flame, or blaze, without smoke, fiercely, or intensely.] (K.)

4 Alhb AlnRaAra c
4. Alhb AlnRaAra He made the fire to flame, or blaze: (S:) or made it to flame, or blaze, free from smoke. (K.) ― -b2- Alhb It (lightning) flashed uninterruptedly. (K.) See also Oaholaba. ― -b3- Alhb, inf. n. UilohaAbN, He (a horse, As, or other thing that runs, Lh,) was ardent, or impetuous, in his
course, or running; (As, S;) as also Ahlb: (As:) or he ran with energy, or effort, so as to raise the dust: (K:) or he ran violently, raising the lahaba, or dust. (TA.) ― -b4- Hence, Alhb fiI AlkalaAmi (tropical:) He spoke rapidly [and with vehemence]. (TA.) ― -b5- Alhbhu AlOamoru (tropical:) The thing, or affair, excited him, and inflamed him. (TA.)

5 tlhRbt AlnRaAru c
5. tlhRbt AlnRaAru, quasi-pass. of lahRaba, (K,) [same as Uilotahabato↓, except that it has an intensive signification;] The fire flamed, or blazed, (S,) [fiercely, or intensely, or flamed, or blazed, burned without smoke, fiercely, or intensely]. ― -b2- tlhRb juwEFA, and jwEA Althb↓, (tropical:) He burned with hunger. (TA.) ― -b3- tlhRb gayoZFA He burned, and was or became hot, with wrath, or rage. (TA, art. wgr.) See 8.

8 Althbt AlnRaAru c
8. Althbt AlnRaAru, quasi-pass. of Oalohaba, (K,) The fire flamed, or blazed: (S:) or flamed, or blazed, free from smoke. (K.) ― -b2- Althb Ealayohi (tropical:) He was incensed, or inflamed with anger, against him. (TA.) ― -b3- Althb and tlhRb↓ [It (any part of the body) became inflamed]. ― -b4- See 5.

lahobN c
lahobN: see lahabN.

lihobN c
lihobN A gap, or space, between two mountains: (S, K:) or a cleft, or fissure, in a mountain: (Lh, K:) or a small gap, or ravine, such as is termed XiEobN, in a mountain: (K:) or a cleft in a mountain, afterwards widening like a road: a liSob and a XaqR are smaller than a lhb; like a small road: (Aboo-Sa'eed-Es-Sukkaree:) or a face of a mountain, resembling a wall, that cannot be ascended: (K:) and similar to this is the lhb of the sky at the horizon: or, as some say, a subterranean excavation, or habitation: syn. sarabN fiI AlOaroDi: (TA:) pl. OalohaAbN and luhuwbN and lihaAbN (S, K) and lihaAbapN. (K.) See an ex. voce karabap.

lahabN c
lahabN and lahobN↓ (K) and lahiybN↓ and luhaAbN↓ and lahabaAnN↓ (S, K), [inf. ns., of which the verb, lahiba, aor.
lahaba
, does not appear to have been used in the classical ages,] The flaming, or blazing, of fire: (S:) or its flaming, or blazing, free from smoke: (T, K:) or lahabN signifies the flame, or blaze, of fire: (S, K:) and lahiybN↓, its heat. (K.) ― -b2- lahabN Dust rising (K) like smoke. (TA.)

luhobapN c
luhobapN A clear white colour: (K:) brightness of the complexion, or colour of the skin. (TA.) ― -b2- luhobapN (in two copies of the S, lahobapN; but in the K expressly said to be with dammeh;) and luhaAbN↓ and lahabaAnN↓ (K) (tropical:) Thirst: (S, K:) [probably burning thirst].

lahabaAnN c
lahabaAnN: see lahabN and luhobapN. ― -b2- Also, The burning of coals, or embers, without blazing. (T.) ― -b3- The burning of heat upon heated ground. (TA.) ― -b4- Vehemence of heat (K) upon heated ground and the like. (ISd.) ― -b5- A hot day. (K.)

lahobaAnu c
lahobaAnu, fem. lahobaI, (tropical:) Thirsty: (S, K:) [probably burning with thirst:] an epithet applied to a man or woman: (S:) pl. lihaAbN. (K.)

luhaAbN c
luhaAbN: see lahabN and luhobapN.

lahiybN c
lahiybN: see lahabN.

luhaAbapN c
luhaAbapN A garment (kisaACN) in which a stone is put, and with which one side of the kind of camel-litter called hawodaj, or one side of a load, is balanced. (Th.)

OulohuwbN c
OulohuwbN, a subst., The ardour, or impetuosity, of a horse (&c., Lh) in his course, or running: (S:) or his energy, or effort, in his course, so that he raises the dust: or a violent run, by which the dust (AllRahabu) is raised: (TA:) or the commencement of a horse's course, or run. (K.) ― -b2- lahu OulohuwbN He runs violently, raising the dust. (TA.) See also OuholuwbN. ― -b3- Also used as an epithet: you say XadRN OulohuwbN [A violent run, in which the dust is raised]. (TA.)

milohabN c
milohabN Pleasing in beauty: (IAar, K:) and having much hair: an epithet applied to a man. (IAar.)

mulahRabN c
mulahRabN (tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, not saturated with red dye: (K:) imperfectly dyed. (TA.)

laAhuwtN c
laAhuwtN Divinity; divine nature. Mentioned here agreeably with the assertion of some, that the t is a radical letter: but this is a point that requires consideration. (TA.)

1 lahiva c
1. lahiva, aor.
lahava
, inf. n. lahavN and lahaAvN and lahavaAnN, He thirsted; was thirsty: (S, K:) or thirst heated his belly, or inside. (L.) ― -b2- lahava, aor.
lahava
, inf. n. lahovN and luhaAvN; (S, K;) and lahiva, aor.
lahava
; (TA;) and Althv↓; (K;) He (a dog, S, and a man, and, in the case of the second verb, a bird also, TA) put forth his tongue, by reason of thirst, or fatigue, or weariness: (S, K:) or lahava signifies his breath (nfs) rose, by reason of fatigue, or weariness: or he (a dog) put forth his tongue, by reason of thirst: and he (a man) was fatigued, or weary. (TA.)

8 Uilotahava
8: see 1.

luhovapN c
luhovapN Thirst. (K.) ― -b2- Fatigue. (AA, K.) ― -b3- The red speck in a palm-leaf, (K,) which you see when you split it. (TA.) ― -b4- luhaAvN [for lihaAvN, pl. of luhovapN,] The specks in palmleaves: (Fr, K:) the red specks in palm-leaves, when they are split: (Fr, TA:) accord. to rule, it should be lihaAvN, like niqaATN. (K.)

lahovaAnu c
lahovaAnu Thirsty: (S, K:) fem. lahovaI. (S.)

luhaAvN c
luhaAvN The heat, or burning, of thirst; (S, K;) vehemence of thirst. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) The severity, or vehemence, of death. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- See luhovapN.

luhaAviIRN c
luhaAviIRN (assumed tropical:) A man (TA) having many red moles (xiylaAn) on his face: (Fr, K:) from luhaAvN, signifying the “ specks in palm-leaves. ” (Fr.)

luhRaAvN c
luhRaAvN [pl. of laAhivN?] Manufacturers, with palm-leaves, of the kind of baskets called dawaAxilRu, (K,) pl. of dawoxalRahN, in which dates are put. (AA.)

fiI sakorapK malohavapN c
fiI sakorapK malohavapN In intoxication is a cause, or an occasion, of lhv [i. e., thirst; or putting forth the tongue by reason of thirst]. (TA, from a trad.)

1 lahija bihi c
1. lahija bihi, aor.
lahaja
, (S, K,) inf. n. lahajN; (S;) and Oalohaja↓, and lahowaja↓; (TA;) He became devoted, addicted, or attached, to it, (i. e., to an affair, TA,) and kept, attended, or applied himself, constantly, perseveringly, persistently, or assiduously, to it; was intent upon it; (S, K;) and accustomed, or habituated, himself to it. (TA.)

2 lahRajahumo c
2. lahRajahumo, inf. n. talohiyjN, He fed them with something whereby to ally the craving of their stomachs before the morning-meal called AlgadaMC. (El-Umawee, S, K.) [See luhojapN.]

4 Alhjhu bihi c
4. Alhjhu bihi He made him to become devoted, addicted, or attached, to it, (an affair,) and to keep, attend, or apply himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to it; to be intent upon it; and to accustom himself to it. (TA.) See 1. ― -b2- Alhj He (a man) had young weaned camels intent upon sucking their mothers, and persevering therein, (S, K,) and therefore made wooden pins, and tied them to the udders, that the young ones might not be able to suck: (S:) this form of the verb signifies the depriving the object of the quality denoted by the unaugmented verb: (L:) or he (a pastor) had young weaned camels intent upon sucking their mothers, and persevering therein, and it became necessary for him to perforate the tongue of each, and to insert in it a falokap, which is a round thing, like the falokap of a spindle, made of coarse hair (hulob), and [probably meaning or] to slit the tongue; each of which operations is performed to prevent its sucking; for the same purpose, also, a wooden pin is stuck over the nose of the young camel: the pastor in this case is termed mulohijN↓: and one does
not say Oalohajotu AlfaSiyla, but simply Oalohaja AlrRaAEiI. (T.)

11 AlhAjR c
11. AlhAjR, inf. n. UilohiyjaAjN, It (anything, S) became mixed, or confused. (S, K.) ― -b2- It (milk) thickened so that parts thereof became mixed together, but it did not become completely thick. (S, K.) ― -b3- AlhAjRt Eayonuhu His eye became infused (lit. mixed) with drowsiness. (S, K,) ― -b4- [See also mulohaAjRN.]

Q. Q. 1 lahowaja Oamorahu c
Q. Q. 1. lahowaja Oamorahu (inf. n. lahowajapN, S) (tropical:) He performed, executed, or managed, his affairs in an unsound manner. (AZ, S, K.) ― -b2- lahowaja He cooked roast meat insufficiently, or not thoroughly: (K:) or he cooked roast meat, (K,) or flesh-meat, (S,) not well; (S, K;) as also talahowaja↓. (S.) See 1.

Q. Q. 2
Q. Q. 2: see Q. Q. 1.

lahijN biOamorK c
[lahijN biOamorK Devoted, addicted, or attached, to an affair, and keeping, attending, or applying himself, constantly, perseveringly, persistently, or assiduously, to it; intent upon it; and accustoming himself to it: part. n. of 1.] You say, rajulN lahijN biXaIoCK [A man devoted, &c., to a thing]. (M in art. bl.)

lahojapN c
lahojapN and lahajapN↓ The tongue: (S, K:) or the tip, or extremity, of the tongue. (L.) ― -b2- The tongue, or dialect, or language, which a person speaks by nature and custom and education. (L.) ― -b3- fulaAnN faSiyHu AllRahojapi, and AllRahajapi↓, Such a one is of chaste tongue: (S:) or, chaste in the dialect, or language, which he speaks by nature and custom and education. (L.) ― -b4- Also, (assumed tropical:) both words, but the former is the more approved, The sound of speech. (L.)

luhojapN c
luhojapN That with which one allays the craving of his stomach before the morning-meal called AlgadaMC. (K.)

lahajapN c
lahajapN: see lahojapN.

mulohijN c
mulohijN: see 4.

mulahowajN c
mulahowajN Roast meat insufficiently cooked. (S.) ― -b2- raOoyN mulahowajN (tropical:) An unsound opinion. (A.) ― -b3- HadiyvN mulahowajN (tropical:) An unsound story, narration, or tradition. (A.)

mulohaAjRN c
mulohaAjRN Mixed; confused. (TA.) ― -b2- Milk thickened so that parts thereof are mixed together, but not completely thick. (TA.) ― -b3- raOayotu Oamora baniI fulaAnK mulohaAjRFA I saw the affair, or case, of the sons of such a one to be confused. (S.)

mulahRajN c
mulahRajN One who sleeps, and lacks power, or ability, to work. (K.)

1 lahadahu c
1. lahadahu, (aor.
lahada
, L, K, inf. n. lahodN, L,) It (a load) oppressed him, (a camel, L,) by its weight, (S, L, K,) and squeezed him: (L:) it (a heavy load) squeezed it, (namely, a camel's back or side,) or bruised it so that it swelled, and became galled: in which case, a hollow is made at the proper place in the stuffed lining of the saddle, to prevent farther injury. (L.) ― -b2- lahada He jaded his beast of carriage, and rendered it emaciated, or lean, by journeying upon it. (S, L, K.) ― -b3- lahadahu, aor.
lahada
, L, K, inf. n. lahodN, L, and lahodapN; Kr;) and lhRdhu↓, (inf. n. talohiydN; TA;) but the latter denotes frequency of the action; (S, L;) He pushed, pushed away, or repelled, him: or pushed him violently upon the chest: (L:) or he pushed him, pushed him away, or repelled him, on account of his baseness, or despicableness: (S, L, K:) or he struck him in the breasts, (L,) or in the bases of the breasts, (K,) and in the bases of the shoulder-blades: (L, K:) or he pressed, or squeezed, him; syn. gamazahu. (L, K.)

2 lahRada
2: see 1.

4 Alhd bihi c
4. Alhd bihi He instigated against him; and aided against him; and acted wrongfully, or injuriously, towards him. (JK.) ― -b2- Alhd He did, or acted, wrong, wrongfully, unjustly, or injuriously; (L, K;) [as also AlHd]. ― -b3- Alhd bihi is said of a man, with respect to another, when the former withholds one of two men and leaves the other at liberty, fighting him. [The object is, app., the former of these two, as he is the injured one.] (AA, S, L, K.) ― -b4- It is also said of a man, with respect to another, when the former acquaints one of the men with the contention or dispute of the other, or with that which the other would say to him, and makes known to him a matter which he understands from him, but which is obscure to others, and informs him of the other's argument. [The object is, app., the latter of these two, as he is the injured one.] (AA, L.) ― -b5- Also, waQllRehi maA qulotahaA UilRaA Oano tulohida EalaIRa By God, thou saidst it not save that thou mightest aid against me, is said when a man has acquainted one of the two men with that which the other would say. [It is, app., said by the latter of these two, as he is the injured one.] (AA, S, L.) ― -b6- Alhd He made, or prepared, the kind of food called lahiydap. (IKtt.) ― -b7- Alhd bihi, (inf. n. UilohaAdN, L,) He held him in light estimation, or despised him: (S, L, K:) or he held his clemency, or forbearance, or intellect, (Hilom,) in light estimation, or despised it; as also AlHd bh. (L, art. lHd.)

lahodN c
lahodN A certain disease which affects camels in the chest; (T:) an opening, or parting asunder, (UinofiraAjN,) in the chest of a camel, [app., next to either, or both, of the arms,] by reason of a push. or collision, (L, K,) or the like, (K,) or by reason of the squeezing of a load: (L:) or (so in the L: in the K, and) a tumour in the farySap [or portion of flesh between the shoulder-blade and the side], (L, K,) by reason of the pressure of a bag or the like upon the camel's back. (L.) ― -b2- Also, A certain disease, like an opening, or parting asunder, [app., in the part where the thighs unite,] (kaAlUinofiraAji,) which befalls men in the legs and thighs. (L, K)

lahiydN c
lahiydN A beast of carriage jaded, or fatigued, (S, L,) and rendered emaciated, or lean, by being ridden. (L.) ― -b2- A she-camel pressed, or squeezed, and having her flesh bruised, by her load. (Lh, L.) ― -b3- lahiydN and malohuwdN↓ A camel oppressed by the weight of a load, and squeezed: having his back or side squeezed by a heavy load, or bruised so that it is swollen, and galled: having his side squeezed by a heavy load so that a disease has been the consequence, which has disordered his lungs. (L.)

lahiydapN c
lahiydapN A kind of food of the Arabs; (L;) thin EaSiydap; (S, L, K;) not thin so as to be supped, nor thick so as to be formed into mouthfuls; thicker than Hariyqap and saxiynap, but thinner than EaSiydap [properly so called]. (S, L.)

malohuwdN c
malohuwdN: see lahiydN. ― -b2- malohuwdN and mulahRadN↓, but the latter denotes frequency of the action, A man pushed, pushed away, or repelled, on account of his baseness, or despicableness. (S, L.) See also lahadahu.

mulahRadN c
mulahRadN: see malohuwdN. ― -b2- Also, Base, or despicable, held weak, (El-Hawázinee, L,) and frequently repelled from doors. (El-Hawázinee, TA.)

Oalozamahu lahocabFA waAHidFA c
Oalozamahu lahocabFA waAHidFA, i. e. lizaAzFA walizaAmFA; in the CK, lazaAzFA; (Kr, K;) [app. meaning He made him to adhere with one adhesion].
